output: Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, I apologize once again for my delay.
This year marks the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue.
The engagement of everyone and the understanding that education, knowledge, and the integration of different cultures with one another is crucial are already established facts.
Consequently, numerous initiatives associated with this year have been undertaken by the various areas of action and intervention.
In this context, the Erasmus Mundus programme also plays its role, and within this new perspective, the new regulation is already present.

The Erasmus Mundus programme constitutes an important contribution to the creation of centres of excellence within the EU, which will, to a certain extent, help sustain the brain drain towards the European Union formula, and also represents a noteworthy role in

in the promotion of European values among nationals of third countries who come here to study and who find in the old continent an unparalleled cultural and linguistic diversity that functions as an attractive and distinct pole from models existing elsewhere in the world.
However, dialogue and interculturality have proven remarkably resilient.

The issue of Erasmus student visas worldwide, and the frequent difficulties in their acquisition and renewal, often leads to students living in a semi-clandestine situation within the European Union, as they attend master’s programs but with tourist visas and, at times, expired ones.
I consider the search for a solution that allows solidarity and transparency and effectiveness in the issuance of visas for these students to be of the greatest relevance and urgency.
Knowledge of the language itself, which enables cultural perception and mutual interaction beyond purely academic mastery, is also crucial; therefore, we ensure this premise unconditionally.
To conclude, a word of thanks to Deputy Dessa Arnês for the manner in which she conducted the entire process and for the balanced report she produced.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the authorization for the granting of State aid for the modernization and renewal of fishing fleets in the outermost regions should only be possible until the end of 2009, or should it remain in force indefinitely?
The specific characteristics of fishing activity in these regions justify that these grants may be awarded beyond 2009 without any minimal harm to the marine environment.
State aid for the modernisation and renewal of fleets in outermost regions for an indefinite period does not mean permanent and eternal aid.
would be immediately suspended if the studies and evaluation of the Scientific Council and the Regional Advisory Councils indicated such a need.
This is the solution that would best suit the very specific reality of fishing in the outermost regions.

The same reasons that underpin for the fishermen of each RUP (Regional Unit of Fisheries) an exclusive fishing reserve up to 100 miles also justify a differentiated treatment regarding assistance for the modernization and renewal of the fleet.
Fortunately, in the context of the fisheries committee, the best solutions were found that can address the specific characteristics of fishing in the outermost regions.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner Almunia, Mr. President of the Eurogroup, I want to greet not only the rapporteurs, but also the Commission for the initiative of having produced this text, the assessment of the 10 years of the Economic and Monetary Union.
It is a strategic text, and this analysis was essential.
The euro, as has been stated here today, is an undeniable success.

From Lisbon and Helsinki, from Dublin, Bratislava, the Euro has demonstrated resilience and solidity, even during the severe turbulence we have witnessed. And it is clearly important that the borders of this club are widened.
But the times we live in put the solidity of the European project to the test daily in many other dimensions.
The euro, as I mentioned, is a central instrument in the operation of the financial system.

However, the Commission’s text itself clearly points to the fundamental conclusion that neither the growth of the real economy nor convergence, in either social or spatial terms, accompanied this success.
Conversely, the Commission clearly concludes that disparities have worsened dramatically during the decade of single currency operation.
This divergence affects regions of my country in particular, particularly Northern Portugal, but also other regions of member states.

The impacts of the single monetary policy, particularly due to the exceedingly high exchange rate, have disproportionately affected regions more exposed to international competition and those with a higher export orientation.
Today, the crisis resulting from the deregulation of financial markets is violently impacting the real economy and further exacerbating the situation for many citizens and numerous regions.

These regions—those exposed to international competition, those reliant on small and medium-sized enterprises, those where access to credit is most vital—are today being victimized by this process and even risk depression.
Commissioner, President of the Eurogroup, the success of the Euro depends on the trust that European citizens place in it.
The most powerful European countries have initiated a process of national economic revitalization.
We have the particular case of initiatives concerning the automotive industry.
But Europe is more than that.
It must be considerably more than the more or less coordinated sum of national policies.
The time has come to transform the Euro into a central tool of Europe, supporting both a robust currency and a robust real economy. And to ensure the functioning of the Euro.
of mechanisms that guarantee the central objective of achieving social and regional convergence, because it is at the essence, at the core of the European project.
The debate concerning the coordination of economic policies within the Eurozone today possesses a strengthened and undeniable impact and relevance.
But coordinating national policies is not enough.
More is needed.

We have a Lisbon strategy that is a summation of national initiatives and a stability and growth pact that differentially tightens the various countries it utilizes and to which they must submit; these are limitations to which is added the limited budget at our disposal.
Crises generate opportunities.
The Monetary Union can only be sustained on a convergence of well-being among the member countries that comprise it, independently, and of their citizens, independently of where they were born.
What other way would we have of mobilizing citizens for the single currency?

The Commission must live up to its own diagnosis, and that is why we eagerly await the concrete proposals that the Commission will bring to this plenary on November 26th and present to European citizens.

It is essential that from this crisis a new phase of the Union be launched, in which the consolidation and strength of the financial system are accompanied by genuine prosperity, forged from cohesion and an economic citizenship as well.

Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. This oral question presented to the European Commission by Gerardo Galeota on behalf of the Regional Development Committee of this Parliament is entirely justified and pertinent.

In truth, it is necessary to make clear the reasons that lead the Council to block the reform of the Solidarity Fund, insofar as it is unable to reach agreement on a common position that allows for the continuation of the legislative process.
It is difficult to discern the reasons that might underlie the Council's position, save perhaps for petty financial considerations.
Doesn't the Council desire a more agile and immediate response to natural disasters?

I do not wish for the Council to offer this type of swift response to other types of catastrophes, such as severe industrial accidents, terrorist attacks, or situations seriously impacting public health.

It is important that these questions have a clear answer, just as it is important to clarify the European Commission’s view of this situation and whether it intends to take any measures to unblock the legislative process.
The value of solidarity must also be fully realized in this area.
Citizens would not understand it at all if it were not so.
I simply wish to state that I wanted to protest against the declaration made by Mrs. Luling, which intends to condition the votes of the deputies in this House, and that conditioning makes no sense.

The interpretation you are presenting is one that we do not share, and it is only in that sense that I would like to ask my colleagues, those who know what they are dealing with, who know that we are defending other interests – the interests of public health and the interests of citizens and of countries – to actually vote in favor of the report. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, for two months now, the political and media agenda has been dominated by the financial and economic crisis.
The referendum in Ireland or the difficulties in the Czech Republic regarding the Treaty of Lisbon receive scant coverage in the media.

Don't you think that, now, the Commission's information and communication strategy should be reinforced with the need and urgency of the Lisbon Treaty coming into force, also as a political response to confront and overcome the crisis in which we are living?
Mr. Acting President, Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, the powers of the world currently hold the international financial system in their hands.
is looking for a handcrafted detail and it was past due.
And therefore, perhaps it is time to resolve, incidentally, another problem we have heard about for decades.
For decades, we have heard this music of the ignoble plundering of resources, how many times, as now once again in the Congo, over the blood of the populations.

And I believe this is also the time to pursue these companies, to pursue this ignoble trade, to freeze the accounts through which the profits of shame from this exploitation of mineral resources at the cost of the blood and suffering of the populations circulate and are deposited.
I don't understand why these companies aren't listed in the same way we’ve already compiled a blacklist of terrorist organizations.

And I fail to understand why the international community is unable to pursue these businesspeople who, strictly speaking, are not businesspeople—they are genuine bandits who undermine regional and global security.
I urge the French Presidency and the Commission to lead an international initiative in this regard. Thank you very much.
We have heard here today, on several occasions, that a crisis normally generates an opportunity, and so it does.
And if we wish to seize the opportunity that is open to us, the agenda is easy to ascertain.
Firstly, we know, at the European Union level, the need we have to introduce mechanisms of transparency, regulation, and supervision in financial markets.
And it is not necessary for your Commissioner Macrivi to launch further consultations, nor is it required that the Presidency analyze and invoke additional studies and
more proposals. It is sufficient to look at the proposals that were promptly made by the socialists and that, many of them, were ultimately taken up by this Parliament.
Secondly, internationally, Europe cannot exist in the international space passively.

She must be an active agent in the construction of the new international order. She must be the advocate for a new architecture that does not leave black holes in the system as do tax havens at present.
Thirdly, we heard here today the President of the Commission state that there is a reluctance in coordinating strategies at the level of the different Member States.
It is true that had we not heard from many members of the Commission for so long that markets self-regulate and that the State should stay out.
that financial markets have no impact on growth or employment, perhaps there would be a more active and engaged spirit of solidarity at the level of different countries.
But today the proposal we have in hand is a proposal that is nothing more than a first step. If we compare it with the programs of China and the United States, on the other hand, it is not
it does not sufficiently clarify what the objective is, and the objective must be employment, and thirdly because a European program cannot be a sum of national agendas.
Today is the moment for us to demonstrate to the citizens of Europe that Europe is a network of rights, also economic, that protect them in times of crisis, in terms of
solidarity, a growth program, and support for small and medium-sized enterprises that are currently not seeing the results of interventions made at the banking level.
The real economy is precisely that, and we are here as Europeans to show citizens that Europe is here too, and above all, because of them. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, it is with particular satisfaction that I appear before you to present the work that was done jointly with everyone in this initiative report.
For me and for all those who collaborated in the unfolding of this process, we can say that we have done our work.

To all, particularly the shadow rapporteurs from the various political groups who worked so hard to reach agreements for the future, to the regional development staff who were always available, notably Miguel Telcremades and Elisa da Farra,

To the PSE staff, to Lila and Petros, and to the European Commission, which consistently made itself represented by its many diverse directorates-general, as a comprehensive report demands, it followed the work closely and permanently, making considerable efforts to ensure its successful completion.
To my office and, in particular, to Joana Benzinho, my sincere thanks to all of you for a more harmonious and structured development of coastal regions and tourism within the European Union.
The 27 Member States of the European Union collectively account for over 89,000 kilometers of coastline.

This exhibits a variety of very particular characteristics that, depending on their location, are defined either by cosmopolitanism, if we are speaking of cities like Lisbon, Copenhagen, or Stockholm,

due to the difficulties inherent in being peripheral or ultraperipheral regions, with issues of connectivity to major urban centers or experiencing accelerated desertification contexts, such as the Algarve, Liguria, the Canary Islands, or Madeira.
One way or another, everyone identifies with the notion of coastline and coastal zone and lives daily the advantages and disadvantages associated with them.
According to available data, by 2010, approximately 75% of humanity will reside in coastal zones.
According to the circuits and relationships between them, we define as the 50 km in a straight line that extends from the coastline to the inland zones.
Yes, regions and not detached maritime zones lacking an integrated vision, which these matters so desperately need, and which our ancestors would also endorse.
Here, this population will concentrate in search of opportunities and economic synergies, and in many cases, with the expectation that these will revolve around tourism.
Thus, the evident need for a pragmatic and integrated view of the impact of tourism on coastal zones took hold of our minds and led us to take action.

In the current context of financial crisis, where the impact on the real economy becomes increasingly unavoidable, tourism emerges as a sector with enormous potential to be directly or indirectly affected in a brutal manner.

Regions that for their development have an overwhelming or total dependence on this see their activity threatened and look to the future with distrust. Especially because tourism is not presently a competence of the European Union.
However, articulated measures can and should be taken, and the spirit imbued in the Treaty of Lisbon reflects that same tendency.
However, waiting until the treaty's entry into force to begin acting is waiting for the stage when we will lament spilled milk.
The current political activity surrounding tourism and the fragile reality of the regions that depend on it demand urgent and effective action from us.

The fact that these are zones structurally dependent on tourism, as an employment driver. Despite it often being seasonal employment, this labor-intensive activity cannot be overlooked in a context of pressure on urban areas and unemployment.

Therefore, this report that we now bring to you, which was already of the greatest opportunity and urgency when the Committee on Regional Development of this House decided to promote it, should now be regarded as a priority for the European Commission and the European Council.

Priority, indeed, to the numerous initiatives it incorporates, as well as those it explicitly supports and which have already been disseminated by other institutions, alongside the measures undertaken in the emergency plan.

of the Commission, among which I highlight the revision of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in which the issues associated with this sector, which is the shock it is currently experiencing, should obviously be addressed.

It is crucial to ensure the development of new segments of the economy in these coastal zones, guaranteeing their social and environmental sustainability and promoting the genuine integration of different sectoral policies, such as the maritime sector, transport,

energy the instruments of cohesion already on the ground. The new quality products policy that the revision of the CAP incorporates with the announcement of the Elchec report and the new tourism products in these coastal zones take into account their crucial contribution to the European economy.
The implementation of an appropriate and holistic vision for this policy should soon become a reality within the European Union.

And to conclude, Mr. President, only with a clear articulation of these instruments and swift, effective action involving all partners and stakeholders already on the ground, can we guarantee that we will have in the European Union a sustainable and forward-looking tourism and coastal sector. Thank you very much.
Mr. Commissioner, Madam Minister, E-Justice is an important step in accessing the law, justice, and courts.
I wish to commend this initiative, congratulate the rapporteur, and the French presidency.

The e-Justice portal was one of the projects under discussion, and it fell to Portugal, during its presidency, to lead the development and implementation of the pilot project that will allow all citizens access to services from other Member States in a simpler, cheaper, more comfortable manner, and in their own language.
This multilingual portal should be designed to serve citizens and businesses seeking legal support and basic legal advice regarding legal and cross-border issues.
E-Justice must be coordinated and overseen by a responsible unit, which will also coordinate the contributions of the various Member States and their articulation with said responsible unit.
E-Justice will serve the citizen and strengthen our democracy.
I congratulate you on the launch of the portal in December 2009. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mr. Barrou, colleagues, I congratulate the work of Carlos Coelho, the Seda Martin Ruri, and the remaining Seda.
In December 2004, the Council adopted regulations establishing standards for the security features and biometric data of passports and travel documents issued by Member States.
Now we have needed to take new steps towards combating the abduction and trafficking of children.
The use of passports by children, in accordance with the principle of one person, one passport, can be a fundamental means of overcoming this difficult and important challenge.
In my country, Portugal, the collection of fingerprints from children aged 6 and upwards is already a practice with a long tradition, which perhaps explains why it does not cause me any objection.
As a champion of the European cause, I believe that, in this matter, harmonization is important.
It reassures me to know that Member States, such as Portugal, which have long established the age of six as the minimum for collecting fingerprints, will not have to alter national legislation.
I must emphasize that the security of passports being reinforced today does not solely rely on the existence of a passport.

The passport, in and of itself, corresponds to an increase in the level of security, which extends from the presentation of the necessary documents for passport issuance, followed by the collection of biometric data, to verification and matching at cross-border checkpoints.
This report represents a further step in affirming the rights of the individual and ensuring their safety.
Mr. President, firstly, I would like to greet the rapporteur Alexander Lamsdorff and the Shadow rapporteurs, with particular recognition for Barbara Weiler.
Dear colleagues, I believe it is essential to advance towards the integration of national defense markets and even the strategic coordination of their productions.

We must move forward, effectively, with the specificities and necessary precautions toward the application of the essential rules of the internal market to the defense industries, increasing transparency in the competitions that are organized and in the contracts that are signed involving the Member States of the European Union.
But at the same time, we must assist in the development of conditions that allow for greater competitiveness of European equipment and products in global markets.

Commissioner Macrivi, it seems to me that this directive should ensure progress in the legal framework concerning public contracts in the areas of defence and security, advancing the construction of the international market.

internal and respecting, of course, the interests and rights of the Member States, especially in the field of security, and notably those who manufacture armaments, ammunition, and security equipment, such as my own country.

Mr. President, I would also underscore the provisions that facilitate easier access for small and medium-sized enterprises to this market, particularly through the improvement of subcontracting rules and the prospect of thereby advancing with greater impact and depth in decision-making.

For the creation of a genuine European market in the defence industries, which may also contribute to strengthening research and development not only within the defence industries but also across a range of European industries that benefit from the development of the defence sector.
To conclude, it is possible to refer to the obvious articulation between the defense industry and the European Union's foreign policies.
But I would like to cite, concerning the recent tenth intervention, translating a classic Roman adage: If you desire peace, prepare for war.

The European Union, as we might almost call a peaceful superpower, refers to these industries as defense industries rather than war industries, because we desire peace and not war. And for this reason, we also need defense industries.
Mr. Vice-President Barrou, I concur with your dissatisfaction.
In truth, we must be dissatisfied with the entirety of the measures, which are extensive.
The truth is that irregular immigration continues to Europe, human trafficking continues, there are zones where there is significant immigration.
emigration, notably across the Mediterranean, towards Italy. France proceeded with a set of significant bilateral cooperations, but other Member States have no effect.
It is necessary that the Commission continue without losing enthusiasm for this policy of cooperation and assistance to Member States.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, I will attempt to present the issues in a very concise manner.
First point, the matter of the European Union’s special monitoring mechanism for testing, which, as stated here, concluded on December 31, 2008.
It is lacking, Madam Commissioner, the timely and routine publication of statistical data on imports, exports, and prices, as happens in the United States.
Without this data, the European Union is unable to react against potential unfair practices, and the Commission itself becomes incapable of defining its strategy.
I requested your attention to that, similarly to what other colleagues have already done.
Secondly, producing within the European Union increasingly requires adherence to safety regulations, social standards, and environmental norms.
The RITS, for example, is a recent initiative that creates even more constraints for us.
It is important that the Commission has a clear strategy, one that is perceptible and amenable to monitoring, so that imported products have identical requirements.
In what ways are these aspects adequately addressed in the ongoing free trade agreements?
And as for Meidin, can Meidin genuinely assist in resolving this issue?
Third point. The European Union has launched an Economic Recovery Plan to combat the current crisis.
What role will trade policy play in this context?

At this moment, what is the Commission preparing to do when a series of other countries, such as China, begin to proliferate the imposition of increasingly numerous non-tariff barriers to prevent our European imports from accessing Chinese markets?

What proposal do you have regarding the updating or adjustment of the fund for globalisation, as well as the support available in structural funds frameworks to improve the immediate situation of the European textile industry?
Final question, last of all, indeed, will the crisis we are experiencing finally make the Commission sensitive to the devastating impact on the European economy of an overvalued euro?
How can the Commissioner sensitize, I conclude now, sensitize her colleagues and the entities that deal with European monetary policy, in order to rebalance? Thank you very much.

It is clear to us that we should applaud President Obama’s decision, the decision to terminate the Guantanamo facility, the prohibition of torture in interrogations, and the suspension of military trials.
However, dear colleague who is no longer present, Portugal and the Portuguese socialist government have no sense of guilt.
The Portuguese Socialist Government did not collaborate with the Bush Administration, quite the opposite.

It was precisely during the Portuguese administration, with the Portuguese government, with the initiative of Minister Luís Amado, that the possibility and the duty of the European Union and democratic countries to welcome and receive those detained without due process in Guantanamo were triggered.

This is what truly matters, this is what should be emphasized as an example to be followed by the remaining Member States of the European Union. How important it is that the resolution be approved tomorrow by all the parties that comprise this Chamber so that, in unity, the decision may have greater force.
Mr. President, thank you to colleague Napolitano for the excellent report.

14 years after Barcelona and 5 years after the first Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, we have the Union for the Mediterranean, with economic power, with parliamentary power, with civil society, with heads of government deciding jointly.
All eager to do more and better in a territory where 720 million citizens represent potential for development and peace for the world.
Secrecy limited to the economic and business sphere is a clear error.

Responding to growth crises naturally requires political responses, but responding to humanitarian crises, emergency situations, and military crises such as the one experienced at the end of 2008 and the beginning of 2009 is crucial.
Politicians and citizens must provide answers to the world’s problems.
The world demanded answers, and months later, we citizens and politicians alike, particularly within a forum such as the Union for the Mediterranean, continue to delay in responding.
I hope that, at the very least, this moment has served to learn and advance. For only those who err learn. But advancing the speed of reaction is absolutely crucial.
The interest in approving this proposed directive lies essentially in the way it can contribute to stimulating economic activity at the local level and supporting actions at the social level.
This application of a reduced rate is of great importance in the housing sector, both in construction and renovation, allowing Member States that adopt it to reduce the cost for the end user.

The provision of local services, particularly by small businesses, can also benefit from this reduction in the VAT rate, securing and generating more and better employment through the promotion of the consumption of goods and services, thereby stimulating the economy itself.

The activity of restoration, fundamental for the proper functioning of local economies and the tourism sector itself, can thus benefit significantly at the local level with this reduction in VAT taxation.
These services, dear colleagues, should not circulate within the European internal market, which will help to reduce the reserves of some Member States already verified in the Council's plan.
Therefore, I cannot agree with the extension of this reduced rate to equipment, whatever the protest.

The prudent manner in which this proposal should be handled in the European Parliament should not give grounds for governments that have some reservations regarding the European Commission’s proposal to practically use the right of veto that European legislation still assigns to them in fiscal matters.
And so here one must prudently reject alterations lacking significant meaning that only hinder the text’s acceptance.
As has been mentioned previously, not only is the excellent the enemy of the good, but he who wants everything loses everything.
This proposed directive is important not only for strengthening local economies, but also because it aligns with ambitions repeatedly expressed by various Member States.
We therefore support the Commission's proposal, as it was presented. Indeed, this was the tenor of the vote, as is the agreement of the Internal Market Committee on Consumer Protection.

I commend the work of the rapporteurs and appeal for the approval of this proposal in its exact terms as presented by the Commission and as voted on by the Parliamentary Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Thank you very much.
to disagree with my colleague Edith Estrela, and that in fact was what motivated me to speak, when she caricatured the intentions of the Czech presidency.
No one wants to send women home. The problem is that there are women who want or would like to stay at home.
Even associations seek to defend them. Women who are ignored, scorned, discriminated against, because they want to dedicate themselves to family and we do not hear them.
And that is a matter of freedom, a matter of freedom of choice, which the left so readily invokes, but which is forgotten here.
It concerns respecting or not the freedom of organization of couples.
It concerns being able to provide those who wish to do so with a greater quality of life, more fatherhood, and more quality motherhood.
That is what our society also needs to do.
We will not go there; we will not resolve the problems of birth rates and people's happiness with prejudices.
We resolve through policies adjusted to reality and the spontaneous desires of people.
Let's not go there with an obsession with the State and the market.
Let us proceed with a fair look at the family.
Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, the difficult situation at Quimonda was exacerbated by the emergence of the financial and economic crisis.
The Portuguese Government has done everything it deems appropriate and useful to help resolve the situation.
We would also like the Bavarian Government to know how to act with a strong sense of responsibility in this area.
Preserving the facilities of Munique will have a decisive impact on the Vila do Conde and Dresden units.

The Portuguese minister himself, Manuel Pinho, affirmed the great interest in enabling this company, so important for Portugal and for Europe, stating that Quimonda could be a competitive company on a global scale.
Mr. President, the Government of Portugal will maintain its efforts towards a solution that guarantees the company’s viability.
We hope that German governments, at both the federal and state level, will genuinely commit to resolving this issue.
As for me, I would like to reiterate the strategic importance of maintaining this type of industry on European territory.
that no national or state executive commits the error of allowing this company to close facilities and liquidate jobs within the territory of the Union.

Dear colleagues, we understand the need to assist in the restructuring of large automotive industry groups, but the Union’s funds and the European Commission’s efforts cannot be exhausted in these aids.

Dear Commissioner, we urge the Commission to support Quimonda, overcoming any potential communication shortcomings—this is the appeal we make to Commissioner Vladimir Spidla, to whom we are bound by ties of work and political solidarity, and to President Barroso, who will never forget that he is our compatriot and of a significant portion of Quimonda’s workers.

We must emphasize, before concluding, that the Portuguese President, Cavaco Silva, in Germany, recently stated that there was new hope regarding Quimonda and still referred to the importance, as already mentioned by colleagues, of the very economic sector in which Quimonda operates.
We take into account, therefore, that the Portuguese Government expresses its willingness to support Quimonda with whatever is necessary, considering the economic dimension of the country.
Ladies and gentlemen, let us help save Quimonda—time is of the essence.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, we have been discussing the Lisbon Strategy for years, and the times we are living in may not be the most opportune for discussing the Lisbon Strategy, but there is undoubtedly a need for a strategy.
a strategy that responds to the difficulties and challenges that the current crisis poses for us.
And that is also what we expect from the Commission.

It is essential that the Commission does not deviate from this matter, but rather possesses the capacity to coordinate actions with the governments of Portugal and the governments of Germany and the Länder of Germany.

It is essential to bear in mind that this is an industry, as has already been stated here, that is of interest to Europe due to its quality and value, the research it develops, and also the environmental quality associated with it. And it is essential that the Commission does not deviate.
I second the invitation extended by my colleague Peneda for the Commissioner and the Commission to travel to Portugal.

It is essential that the Commission bear in mind that, at this moment, Europeans are looking to Europe and expect answers from the European authorities. They need to feel that the European authorities are close to them.

European citizens do not understand a Europe that washes its hands of responsibility. Rather, they want a Europe that has the audacity to get its hands dirty and to set to work helping them overcome difficulties. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, thank you very much. I too join the tributes to Jamonet, but I requested the floor to congratulate Mr. President on the statement he made regarding the European Day in Memory of the Victims of Terrorism.
It was at my proposal that five years ago we adopted this approach, which the Council enshrined at a meeting on March 25th following the tragic attacks in Madrid.
but my intervention was an appeal.

Parliament has always remained faithful to the celebration of this date, but unfortunately, this date has yet to achieve, across the entirety of European institutions and Member States, the prominence it deserves.
I believe that the celebration of this date is one of the most important instruments we have to pay tribute to the victims, as the President did, but also to raise a level of public awareness.
I know there are some celebrations in Madrid today, but little else.
Therefore, the appeal I make to the Commission and to the Czech Presidency is that all Member States duly commemorate this date in the future. Thank you very much.
And my lords, my dear colleagues, the crisis is deeper than we anticipated and unemployment will be greater than we predicted.
There are good reasons to believe that the planned European stimulus is insufficient. But it is already clear that it is taking too long to reach citizens.
The Parliament's position is strong and it is clear. It has been and I hope it will continue to be.
Our objective is to maintain employment and to create new jobs with cohesion, with solidarity, both territorial and social.
And at this moment of crisis, citizens cannot resign themselves to a Europe that does not provide them with answers, to a Europe that is powerless in the face of the problems they are experiencing.
What is the Parliament going to ask of the Commission?

It naturally requests, through these reports, that you coordinate national interventions. It asks you to utilize all means currently at your disposal to intervene and provides you, as a budgetary entity, with all necessary conditions for this to occur.

It asks him to launch a clear European employment initiative. And it tells him that it is important to have a calendar-based agenda to implement measures regulating the financial market, as well as to bring credit to the real economy.
But what is being requested of the Council?
The Council is urged to rediscover the political will that lies at the heart of the European project’s construction.
The European Union is competition, but equally cohesion and solidarity.
And there can be no single market without that guarantee. Solidarity and cohesion.
That is precisely why we all delegated, at the European level, the national autonomies we had before joining this project. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Commissioner, anyone visiting Sub-Saharan Africa readily recognizes in most countries the enormous weakness of their health systems and the extremely negative impact this weakness has on the lives and health of the populations those services should serve.
The internationally disseminated indicators consistently confirm this.
In that sense, it is profoundly unsettling to consider that simple gestures and even rather straightforward, not particularly expensive practices could be sufficient to save many lives.

European financial support can be crucial in this regard. And we cannot fail to keep in mind how cooperation in the field of health is truly strategic and directly traverses not only one of the millennium development goals, but many of them.

Now, the Court of Accounts considered that, I quote, community funding for the health sector has not increased since 2000 in proportion to its total development aid, despite the commitments undertaken by the Commission regarding the Millennium Development Goals and the health crisis in sub-Saharan Africa.
End of quotation.

And it recognized, I quote again, that the Commission contributed significantly, through its funding to establish the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, but did not grant the same attention to strengthening health systems, which was expected to be one of its priorities.
End of quotation.

According to the Court, this occurred, I quote again, because the Commission lacked sufficient experience in health matters to ensure that the funding of assistance per lesson granted to this sector was used in the best possible way.
End of quotation.
This is, therefore, a strong challenge that the Court of Accounts is directly launching at the European Commission, and one that I support.
On our part, I want to reiterate this same challenge, now grounded in the objectivity of this data and this evaluation.
Healthcare services are already part of our development assistance priorities, but they should become an even greater part, deserving of increased funding.

Optimizing the way assistance is provided, bearing in mind the seemingly antagonistic needs of coordination in its management and proximity to beneficiary populations, is to deliver a service that can save many lives.
The European Commission cannot fail to respond positively to this challenge, and it is in this spirit that I urge it.
The colleague Bois, just now, delivered a moving intervention here and was able to put faces, human faces, on the dry coldness of these figures from the Court of Accounts.
The challenge for us, Madam Commissioner, is for our cooperation to be capable of bringing a look of joy and hope to those very faces.
And for that, Madam Commissioner, it is essential that different figures be used in the health area within our cooperation.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, once again, for sad reasons, we are discussing here the situation in Guinea-Bissau, which is truly a distressing situation.
It is a country that has experienced chronic instability for many years, which tentatively embarked on a path toward democracy in the early 1990s.

Nothing went well; there was a coup d'état, a minor internal conflict, and they are experiencing significant political and military instability, tensions, deep rivalries, and now, recently, also the very concerning presence, increasingly evident to all observers, of drug trafficking interests.

We vigorously condemn these attacks, the bombing death of the Chief of the General Staff, Tagumena Ué, and also the assassination, in particularly barbaric terms, to say nothing of savage, of President Nino Vieira.
Regardless of your past, we express our solidarity with your families, the people of Guinea-Bissau, and deeply regret and strongly condemn these attacks.
We desire a return to normality. And the lesson I draw and would like to underline in the resolution is that impunity is not a remedy.
In the past, regarding the assassination of Assumane Mané and General Veríssimo Seabra, how was it that eyes were turned away so that the perpetrators were not found and brought before justice?
It is evident that this is not a solution.
Therefore, we must make it clear to the State of Guinea-Bissau that those responsible must be found, the guilty must be brought before justice, and we must provide all necessary assistance.

I also wanted to draw attention, to conclude, to the concern with which we view the presence of drug trafficking throughout the region, the risk that this also represents for the European Union, and the shocking presence, due to its obviousness, in Guinea-Bissau.
I also wished to appeal for us to narrow the relationship with Cape Verde within this context.

We have established a special partnership with Cabo Verde. Cabo Verde has very close relations with Guinea, a great deal of knowledge, but is also very vulnerable. And that is essential for our own European security as well.
Therefore, the intensification of the special partnership with Cabo Verde is also very important in this context. Thank you very much.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues, I would first of all like to thank everyone for the work celebrated.

The three lines outlined in the Green Book—concentration, interconnectedness, and cooperation—can provide solutions to some obstacles hindering the harmonious development of the Union, particularly the negative effects associated with

concentration of economic activity, to inequalities in access to markets and services resulting from distance and divisions imposed, whether by borders between Member States, particularly those most disadvantaged, but also between regions.
We should therefore promote the improvement of synergies between these policies with effective assessment methods for their territorial impact.

Therefore, I have always advocated for the definition of supplementary qualitative indicators with the aim of improving the design and implementation of the corresponding policies on the ground, taking into account the different territorial specificities.
For the time being, GDP remains the sole eligibility criterion for receiving support from structural funds.

However, this definition of supplementary indicators and the undertaking of territorial assessments should not be the origin of further bureaucracy or delays, but rather the simplification, the implementation of new policies, and actions to support territorial cohesion.

The fifth interim report, and to conclude, Mr. President, makes a specific reference to the transition regions situated between the convergence regions and the regions of competitiveness and employment.
It is necessary to note that these regions require a clearer status, with greater security and stability for their development. Thank you very much.

Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, within the context of this significant debate concerning territorial cohesion and the future of economic and social cohesion policy, I could not fail to mention the very specific challenges facing ultraperipheral regions.

Regions that, due to the combination and persistence of a series of geographical factors, reveal significant economic and social vulnerability, particularly felt within a context of a severe international crisis such as the one we are currently experiencing.
I would thus like to appeal to the European Commission and, in particular, to Commissioner Huebner, to pay very particular attention to the effects of the current crisis on the outermost regions.

An assessment of these effects in each of the outermost regions, particularly in tourism, construction, and the rise in unemployment, would be important to allow for a European response specifically tailored to these regions.

Therefore, I challenge the European Commission to prepare a European response to the crisis for the outermost regions, one that goes beyond the measures already announced under the economic and social cohesion policy for all European regions.
A specific European response to the crisis for ultra-peripheral regions.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, in response to the global financial crisis, the European Economic Relations Plan states that cohesion policy contributes significantly to public investment by Member States and regions, and should act as a means of recovery from the current crisis.
It specifically suggests the adoption of actions in priority areas of Lisbon’s strategy, in order to achieve growth and employment.
All operational instruments seek to achieve this purpose and accelerate the attainment of results.

In this regard, the expansion of the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and the streamlining of the European Social Fund have a particular responsibility to respond to the multiple social and economic emergency situations that require support.
I am certain, today as in the past, that your action will be all the more effective the more complementary your actions and scopes have been.

However, as the provision of new funding or new lines of action was not anticipated, it is particularly important that the European Social Fund be used to its full potential in combating unemployment and the rapid increase in competitive pressure on the European economy, resulting from the current financial crisis and economic constraints.

I would like to emphasize that the Regional Committee has repeatedly identified simplification as essential for the improvement of the management and implementation of structural funds, as the European Commission now proposes.

We were requested to expedite matters, however, in this instance. And in the adoption of this regulatory package, we took it into consideration. And this cause has never shied away from assuming its political responsibilities.

Therefore, despite the multitude of perspectives that the particularity of the moment engenders, for the sake of ensuring the process's swiftness and the genuine benefit for citizens that the proposal intends, we refrain, for the time being, from presenting new proposals and alterations.

However, we wish to draw attention to the need to initiate, from now on, an assessment process of this fund, with a view to a complementary review to be carried out as soon as possible. Thank you very much.
Madam President, the crisis, among other aspects, allowed for the highlighting of strong imbalances between the countries of the Eurozone, perhaps the primary
conclusion of the Economic and Monetary Union report, on the 10th, but, above all, to the extreme vulnerability of countries that, belonging to the European Union, do not belong to the Eurozone.

Therefore, strengthening the resources available at the European level to support balance of payments crisis situations is absolutely indispensable. And therefore, we welcome the increase from 12 to 25 and then to 50 million euros of necessary resources.
However, more important is to address the root causes of problems and not merely their most evident manifestations.
Today, an expanded Europe and the Eurozone must reinterpret the meaning of European solidarity and the objectives of cohesion and genuine convergence.
It is necessary to examine the capacity of European horizontal policies, but it is also necessary to revisit new financing instruments, such as eurobonds.
Financial assistance to the balance of payments is necessary, but is far from sufficient to guarantee the sustainability of the European project and the single European currency.
Mr. Chairman of the Commission, Acting Chairman, we are in an unprecedented crisis.

It was, in fact, not the time to internally discuss how we should organize ourselves. Therefore, my hope is that the Treaty of Lisbon will be rapidly ratified so that we can face the global landscape, united and in solidarity as Europeans.

Regarding the economic crisis, in the report of which I was the author and which this Parliament largely approved, it was admitted that the recovery plan, subsequently presented by the Commission, was not sufficient.
Today, we are certain that he is not sufficient.
A crisis that began financially extends to the real economy, then to employment, and subsequently becomes social.
He is insufficient and unfocused.

Each crisis holds an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission to respond to the genuine problems of Europeans, through serious financial regulation, and not the lightest and most piecemeal possible.
possible, as it is underway. Not made of individual national plans, but of a genuine European initiative. Not through scattered means, but by focusing on the true challenge that I employ.

In every crisis lies an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission and for Europe to respond to the genuine problems of European citizens. And I hope that this will happen through a new approach to the recovery plan. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, I merely wished to express, not only on behalf of the EPP, as has already been done by many Members, but particularly on behalf of the Portuguese Members of the EPP, the great satisfaction with the outcome of the referendum in Ireland.
We believe this clearly reinforces the prospects for development and evolution of the European Union, creating conditions for a new phase.

We wished, naturally, to greet all those who contributed to the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular the Commission and the Vice-Presidential Commissioner present here, and also, naturally, the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union, which

It played here a very important role, and therefore we want to say that it is with pleasure that we observe that, despite all these vicissitudes and still awaiting the position of the Czech Republic, it will be with great joy that the Portuguese will see the name of their capital linked

We are at a decisive step in the evolution of the European Union and I wanted to say that we can also count, in this perspective, on another flag, which will also be a flag of the Portuguese MEPs of the PPE, namely, the flag of National Parliaments.
We contend that the Treaty of Lisbon represents a decisive step towards incorporating the presence of national Parliaments into European democracy as well.

And that is why we believe that this dimension—the most important dimension of democracy, the representative dimension—and not, as we sometimes hear in this Chamber, the referendary dimension, what is…

A fundamental and essential element of democracy is representation, not direct voting; furthermore, the Treaty of Lisbon represents a significant step towards increasing the participation of national representative democracies in the European process.
Therefore, we are very pleased with this decision of the Irish people.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. A brief intervention to welcome the historic and comprehensive result of the referendum in Ireland and to highlight the decisive role played by Fine Gael and its leader and incoming Prime Minister of Ireland, Enda Kenny, in leading this process.
A process in which the need to bring the European Union much closer to its citizens became strikingly clear.
They are, we are all of us, the primary recipients of all Union action.
It is fundamental that everyone be aware of the impact and benefits that Europe has daily on our lives.
Europe is our Lebensraum.
What is good for Europe is good for each Member State, is good for its citizens.
It is certainly the case of the Treaty of Lisbon.
With this treaty, it becomes far more evident that one can be, simultaneously, a proud and committed national citizen and a staunch defender of the European project.

And the European Union, having concluded a protracted debate on its organization and functioning, can now focus much more effectively and with significantly more effective instruments on the genuine problems facing Europeans: competitiveness, growth, and employment.
Concluding, Mr. President, Madam Minister, with a proposal intended for future generations.

Considering the information deficit regarding the values, skills, objectives, and mode of operation of the European Union, the European Parliament should propose, at the end of compulsory schooling in each Member State, a new subject of European studies with mandatory status.
In an objective, truthful, and concrete manner, young Europeans will genuinely learn our principles, who we are, what we do, and where we want to go.

It is through knowledge, from a young age, that they will come to understand, throughout their lives, the potential and immense utility of European identity within this unique project of voluntary sovereignty sharing on a continental scale.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Chairman of the Committee, I begin by greeting you in this first debate concerning what this new instrument of political control means for the advancement and development of parliamentary democracy in Europe.
It is European citizens, through their representatives, who stand to gain.

Considering the most recent developments—the Irish referendum, ratification by Poland, and the latest statements by the President of the Czech Republic—I would like to know your assessment of the process leading to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.
There have been efforts on the part of the Commission President.
and what is the prediction it makes regarding a potential entry into force date of the treaty, and, on the other hand, to know whether, at this moment and in light of that prediction, the Commission

some transitional treaty arrangements have already been carried out, from the Treaty of Nice to the Treaty of Lisbon, or if it is still in a, let's say, expectant phase, therefore a phase of waiting to see.

Mr. Chairman of the Commission, having heard that, I would like to know the following. At this stage, when everyone is awaiting the formation of the Commission, fundamentally, what is the perspective that you, Mr. Chairman, hold?

is whether we will now, until that moment of final ratification by the Czech Republic, have a management commission or whether they will proceed with the procedures for appointing the new Commissioners.

It is fundamental that the primary objective of the creation of the European External Action Service realize the efforts of the European institutions. To ensure the creation of an effective service, capable of articulating, formulating, and implementing a European response to current international challenges.
It must also represent more than the sum of its parts. It should be a value-added contribution relative to the current efforts of Member States and the European Union.
In this sense, it seems essential to me that what defines the specificity of the Union be at the center of this new reality. And that specificity is the community method.
That is why I give my full support to the BROC report, which advocates for and safeguards a close link between the Commission and the future service.

This purpose highlights two aspects. The importance of close coordination between the President of the Commission and the High Representative, also Vice-President of the Commission, to ensure effectiveness and proper functioning.
Finally, the need for an alliance between Parliament and the Commission to counter the emerging intergovernmental drift that could compromise the effective functioning of the service.
Parliament must therefore remain vigilant and ensure that the European External Action Service will be a center of excellence representative of the best expertise in external policy.
Thank you, Mr. President, thank you, Mr. Commissioner. Firstly, I want to reinforce the importance of this issue raised by Deputy Goularantes, because it is a matter of the most fundamental justice.

We are all perfectly aware that in a pandemic situation involving influenza A, it will be the countries of the South that will suffer most from this problem and the consequences of the virus's proliferation, and not the countries of the North.

And we witness every year with complete passivity the death of millions of citizens as a result of pandemics that have either been eradicated or have treatment in Northern countries. An immense list: malaria, dengue fever, yellow fever, tuberculosis.
We have no limits for this list and we passively witness this problem.

We effectively utilize the Southern countries as free suppliers of samples of new virus strains so that we can improve treatment in the Northern countries, but nevertheless we remain without an effective response to these problems. And therefore, to the questions that were raised, I would only like to add a few more.
We want to effectively treat this problem as a public health issue or as a business.
Because if it is viewed as a public health problem, we must guarantee equal access to treatment in all regions of the world, and to that end, efforts must be more effective.
On the other hand, I would like to ask—and I hope this isn't the case—if we are anticipating that, ultimately, vaccine stocks in Europe will become excessively abundant.
that the side effects prove so negative in this instance, and only then do we have an act of generosity and suddenly begin sending necessary vaccines to Southern countries.

And finally, I would just like to ask whether the European Union, whether we Europeans and the Commission feel comfortable with a system or a model where countries in the north address pandemics through a model of prevention, and in countries in the south it is treated as palliative care or merely with leftovers.

Thank you, Mr. President. Firstly, I want to express my full support regarding the matter raised by Mr. Roel and, above all, to highlight the underlying issue, the fundamental political issue at stake in this matter, which precisely concerns the joint programming of research.

What transpired regarding the joint programming initiative on neurodegenerative diseases and, in particular, Alzheimer's disease, was that the rules were changed mid-process; we moved from having a report to having a resolution, thereby eliminating our co-decision-making capacity in this area. We ceased to be members of parliament and became consultants instead.
And therefore, I would like to know if at least what we recommend will be considered or not.
The programming of research activities, whatever the subject matter, is a political choice, not a technical one. And in this sense, the role of Parliament should be valued and strengthened.
It seems to me that defining priorities that are political means they must be scrutinized, that they must be transparent, and that they must be democratic.
What transpired with the process concerning the joint decision and joint programming of the investigation into Alzheimer’s is a process that should not be repeated, and if it does.

Please repeat, and ensure timely notification. I therefore hope that the last thing that can happen to us is that the decisions and recommendations presented by Parliament on this matter are not considered.
Mr. Deputy, in the last month, the regions of Europe have been particularly prominent.
European Week dedicated to regions and cities, reinforces the position of regions as a fundamental part of the solution in Europe's response to global challenges.
Thus they concluded, leaving no room for doubt, President Durão Barroso, Commissioner Samesky, and the hundreds of debates that transpired.

At the most specific level as well, the holding of the significant meeting of the Conference of Presidents of the Utoporipheric Regions of Europe, which for the first time included the participation of Members of the European Parliament, constituted a milestone in regional policy in favor of European construction.
Global challenges and European responses present an excellent opportunity for a new strategy for the ASRUP.

These regions, such as the Azores, beyond the permanent constraints that everyone is accustomed to hearing about, present a set of potentialities that confer clear opportunities to achieve our progress and give a clear advantage to Europe in new domains essential to responding to global challenges.

And for this reason, the President of the Commission decisively ends the palace coup that the Commission’s paper indicates was being prepared while we, as Members of Parliament and European citizens, were promoting the ratification of the Treaty of Lisbon and its importance in safeguarding the cohesion of European territory.

I would like, first of all, to greet the rapporteurs, notably Mr. Martin and also Mr. Corbett, and to say that, as a member of the EPP, I fundamentally agree with the proposed amendments to the rules of procedure.
I would essentially like to highlight the point that appears important to me and which has not yet been brought up here this evening, namely the point concerning National Parliaments.

The democratic strengthening of the European Parliament undoubtedly results from its rules of procedure and the Treaty of Lisbon, but European democracy also results from the connection to National Parliaments.
And what this regulation, this proposal now seeks to do is precisely to create these two democratic legitimacies, to reinforce democracy.

On the one hand, democracy resulting from the instruments of the European Parliament, from its control mechanisms, from its legislative capacity, and on the other hand, the democratic collaboration of National Parliaments through various instruments.
And that is why I am here, let's say, fully aligned with the proposals put forth.
I disagree with my colleague Duff when he suggests that we should postpone the introduction of mechanisms for engaging with National Parliaments.
I assure you that we can do this immediately under the Lisbon Treaty, and that it is very important.
I would also like to say that I support the proposal by my colleagues Sayer and Brock regarding representation in the COSAC, and finally, that I am
entirely in agreement with the observations made here by colleague Broc and other colleagues regarding the primacy of Parliament and its members relative to the services of Parliament.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I congratulate the rapporteur colleague on the work developed in this report and on her intervention just now.
This new microfinance instrument will enable the granting of microcredit to small businesses and to individuals who have lost their employment and wish to create their own business and their own job.
This is very important at a time when the economic crisis is predicted to result in the loss of 3.5 million jobs alone in the European Union.

As a consequence of the economic slowdown, banks have ceased granting loans for job creation and business ventures, and access to credit has become more difficult at a time when it should be more accessible.
Now, this new form of microfinancing will counteract the current trend of restricted access to credit, facilitating the acquisition of funds necessary for the launch of new businesses and new jobs.
The European Commission’s proposal aims to reallocate €100 million from the Progress Programme budget to this financing instrument.
We cannot agree with this proposal.
The financial and economic crisis is also a social crisis.
Thus, reallocating resources from progress aimed at the most vulnerable groups is not altogether the most suitable solution.
For this reason, the creation of a separate budgetary heading to finance this instrument is supported, as well as an increase in the allocation to 150 million euros.

We also agree on the need to clarify within the legislation itself that the target group consists of vulnerable populations experiencing difficulty entering or re-entering the labor market and facing the threat of social exclusion.
Thus, the reference to specific groups should be suppressed.
Finally, we emphasize that it is essential that individuals receiving financial support also have appropriate training. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to begin by greeting the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, Prime Minister Reinfeldt, both on behalf of the EPP and on behalf of the Portuguese delegation of the EPP.
Our assessment of the Swedish presidency is of an almost complete success, essentially in four fundamental areas.
The first in the institutional sphere, the Swedish Presidency's contribution to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, and to the highly successful election of the President of the Commission.
For, namely, all matters of ratification, associated with ratification, were extremely professional and met the standard expected, the best practices of the European Union.
Naturally, for a country like Portugal, which played a decisive role in the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, this contribution from the Swedish presidency is invaluable.
A second point is the climate agenda, where naturally the Commission’s work was also extremely important.
We must say that, from my point of view and from the point of view of many EPP deputies, it is in the area of climate change that the European Union has had the greatest success.
It is there on the true front line at a global level, and this is due to the effort of both the Swedish presidency and, in particular, the European Commission presidency.
We consider this balance to be very positive as well.
A third point concerns financial regulation, which, particularly with this latest Council, took a step we consider decisive and that may have a significant impact on exiting the crisis.
And therefore, I also wanted to congratulate you on achieving an agreement in that area.
And finally, I wanted a word for an area that, personally, resonates deeply with me, which is that of the Stockholm Programme and, therefore, the area of security, justice, and freedom.

I believe that I, having followed both the Temper process and, in particular, the Daia process afterward, consider this Stockholm program absolutely essential and wished to congratulate the Swedish Presidency and Prime Minister Reinfeldt for it.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. As you know, the recognition of professional qualifications has been consolidated into a single legislative act, comprising 15 directives, which has given rise to various practical problems in their application across the different Member States.

The difficulties are well-known, and the Commission should inventory the critical points and conduct an analysis of the problematic areas that arise in the application of this important internal market instrument.
Protectionisms, manifesting at various levels, constitute an impediment, not only to the free movement of people, but also to the internal market.
We should attempt to identify the ambiguous points so that the effectiveness of the directive is not undermined by mistrust.
The Union is not asked to do what the Member States should do, but there is a facilitation effort to be undertaken that helps to dismantle professional corporatism.
An improvement in the application of this Directive should involve the dissemination of recognition of qualifications through the Solvit network and the EURES network by encouraging
common platforms, the implementation of effective contact points, and, no less importantly, it should provide for the articulation of this Directive with the Services Directive. Thank you.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen Members of Parliament. It is urgent that a debate be promoted regarding the Community Budget and how, in the future, we can contribute to its sustainability and transparency.

The post-2013 financial framework should be built on the foundations of solidarity and territorial cohesion, values crucial for regions such as Madeira, which face persistent difficulties and therefore require ongoing support.
I would like to share with you some ideas that I believe should always be present when considering and building cohesion policy.

The Commission has repeatedly highlighted certain aspects that appear to me to be essential, such as the need for greater flexibility, simplicity, efficiency, and a stronger focus on results in the definition and implementation of this policy.
But there are questions that cause me some concern, especially considering the needs of the outermost regions.
In this discussion, allow me three brief notes. Firstly, the current approach in terms of regions should prevail over alternative guidelines, such as value-added sectors.

Such a reorientation could jeopardize Objective 2, which currently benefits approximately two-thirds of European regions, and may also prove counterproductive in regions with distinct economic profiles and competitive advantages. Secondly, it seems to me that maintaining the proximity criterion in cohesion policy is vital.

It should continue to prioritize an allocation and management of structural funds from a regional perspective, rather than a national or even one centralized at the European level. Thirdly, and finally, but no less importantly, I would like to recall and underscore Article 349.
349 The Treaty of Lisbon provides for special treatment of the outermost regions with regard to access to structural funds, precisely due to their economic and social situation.
Exacerbated by conditions and unique characteristics of a lasting nature, which manifest in these constant difficulties and therefore require the claimed permanent assistance. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Given the urgency, what we witnessed in Copenhagen was several steps backward.

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more heads of state than others, but it also created more divisions. And as a result, what happened was that we ended up in a situation of each one for themselves, where each state can define its own goals and moreover, under a voluntary regime.
It should be noted that having a 2-degree Celsius target or funding targets without any clarification also cannot serve as consolation to us.
Therefore, what I think is that we must act in terms of the future. And acting in terms of the future means moving beyond rhetoric to action.
The European Union has always wanted to be a leader, it has always stated so.
But when we arrived in Copenhagen, he ended up hesitating, failing to define or defend the goals he had previously stated were his goals and from which he would not abandon.

And therefore, what I ask is whether we will not be more just in the future, whether we will continue to allow it—at the cost of this failure and the decisions of some over others—for the poorest to continue paying the heaviest bill.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I wished to denounce here what is happening in Portugal at this moment, where it is clear that the media
A plan by the Government to control newspapers, television stations, and radio stations has come to light, which calls into question freedom of expression.
This week, a well-known journalist, Mário Crespo, had an opinion piece censored, also at the suggestion, or apparent suggestion, of the Prime Minister.

In light of this, Prime Minister José Sócrates must provide substantial explanations to the country. He must explain that he is not dominating, restricting, or censoring freedom of expression in Portugal.

The way things are going, Portugal is no longer a state of law; it is a formal state of law, where the Prime Minister is limited to formalities, procedures, and formalisms, and does not wish to provide substantive explanations.
For Portugal, we desire a substantive rule of law.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. The green paper on the reform of the common fisheries policy, reported on by my colleague from the Azores, Maria do Céu Patrão Neves, represents a unique opportunity for debate concerning a sector that assumes considerable importance in the balance of local development within ultraperipheral regions.

Madara follows the ongoing discussion with particular interest and considers it imperative to propose a differentiation between artisanal and industrial fleets, which should benefit from different fishing regimes.
It is fundamental to defend a principle of positive discrimination with regard to limiting access to territorial waters within the exclusive economic zone to local artisanal fleets only.
In Madeira, supporting the modernization of vessels is a priority, as is a management approach that ensures the long-term conservation of a broad range of species.
Only in this way will we be able to avoid unsustainable situations for economic, environmental, and social equilibrium.
Finally, let us advocate for permanent, rather than time-bound, support for fisheries in the outermost regions.
This report concerning the European Regional Development Fund aims to broaden the eligibility of interventions in the housing sector to benefit marginalized communities in our Member States.
To date, this support has been applied solely to marginalized communities residing in the urban areas of the new Member States.
In other words, since the vast majority of these communities live in rural areas and in makeshift shelters, they could not benefit from support to replace substandard housing.
Fundamentally, it concerns how to cull a cow and grant Member States and their regions greater possibilities in the policy of mitigating the specific difficulties of these communities.
Health also, and equal treatment for all Member States, as marginalized communities with needs for support and integration deserve our concern, regardless of the Member State to which they belong.

Upon concluding the initial reading of this important report in the fight against poverty and for human dignity, its rapid implementation within the framework of the economic relations plan is also achieved, responding brilliantly to the crisis that affects us.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, allow me to begin by highlighting the rapporteur’s role, Mr. Vandestelroy, for his work in seeking consensus on this matter and also for the availability he always demonstrated in incorporating other contributions into his report.
Tomorrow, we will vote on amendments to the FEDER Regulations, which assume particular importance for the so-called former Member States and also for Portugal.

These changes will allow for the extension of the utilization of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) in the housing sector to benefit marginalized communities, as currently this fund can only be allocated to urban development operations.

The changes I proposed together with other colleagues and which were approved by a large majority in the Regional Development Committee will allow former member states and not only the new ones, as the original proposal envisioned, to also benefit from this funding possibility.

With this, I sought to prevent the establishment of a precedent which I consider dangerous and which would exclude all former Member States from this and, likely, from other additional uses of Community assistance.
What would make no sense, since housing issues, particularly within marginalized communities, exist in both new and old member states.

I wish to reiterate that the length of time a country has been a member of the European Union should not be a criterion for the allocation of structural funds, and that this criterion should be abandoned immediately.

The negotiation of the post-2013 cohesion policy should be based on solidarity, aiming at territorial cohesion, and should be oriented towards rewarding rather than penalizing regions that have demonstrated exemplary performance in the utilization of Community funds.

I would like, at this essential moment, to emphasize to the Commission and to the President of the Commission the manner in which they have worked with this Parliament over these months of investiture.
There is no body in the world with both executive and legislative powers that is subject to the presentation of a program by its President before Parliament, nor to hearings with all groups.

parliamentarians to a vote by a significant absolute majority, bringing here all the commissioners to be heard individually with their own program, with three to four hours of direct questions, of questions with answers.
to someone who agreed to negotiate with Parliament a framework agreement, in which they accepted, firstly, to justify and expand the powers of Parliament within the scope of legislative initiative.

that accepted the principle of total access to information, whether in legislative and political action, or in international negotiations, that accepted taking the Parliament's opinion into account regarding commissioners, regarding the restructuring of commissioners.
This means, once and for all and from my perspective, that the Commission has demonstrated, from July until now, a willingness to maintain a close relationship with the Parliament and that, in

He demonstrated it in a clear, evident, and unequivocal manner: that the strategic alliance of the Treaty of Lisbon for the community method referred to by my colleague Sario Zewoski is the alliance between the Parliament and the Commission.
And for that reason, the Commission and the Framework Agreement deserve the full support of the EPP.
Five years after the Orange Revolution, Ukrainians appear to view this period as a missed opportunity.
