And the blame isn't solely with its political elites.
It is true that these were consumed too much in power and influence struggles.
As many reforms remained unfulfilled, many did not progress beyond the paper stage.
It is inconceivable that in any democracy electoral laws should be altered between the two rounds of an election.
does not reflect the views of those who proposed them, those who voted for them, or those who promulgated them.
and translates the unpraiseworthy and undesirable intentions at its genesis.
There is much that needs to change regarding the lack of independence of the Judiciary, subject to excessive influence not only from the political power but also from economic agents.
Without a free and independent judiciary, there is no rule of law, human rights are not guaranteed, there is no foreign investment, and there is no progress.
But the blame for this disillusionment also rests with this Parliament and, essentially, with many Member States.
I would like us to, for a few moments, place ourselves in the shoes of a citizen of a European country that, due to historical circumstances, is not yet a member of the European Union.
what we would expect from the Union.
Solidarity.

But many chanceries, with the sole concern of not inconveniencing or displeasing Moscow, exploited and abused the permanent internal struggles in Kyiv to avoid unequivocally asserting that Ukraine is an independent and sovereign country.
As such, if this is the freely expressed will of its people and provided that the established criteria are met, Ukraine may aspire to become a member of the European Union in the future.

I would like to emphasize that in island regions, air transport is sometimes the only possibility of access and that operating conditions are contingent upon the size of their passenger and cargo flows.

If there are regions in Soares where the abundance of these flows is appealing to many operators, attracting competition and low transport prices, thus improving accessibility, others exist, such as the Azores, where these flows are still reduced and not attractive to operators' interest.

Consequently, airfares are higher, constituting an obstacle to the mobility of populations and a constraint on attracting tourists that would allow the vast potential for development and diversification of its economic base to flourish and consolidate.
This picture is particularly disheartening during times of crisis such as the one we are experiencing.

It is therefore fundamental to provide temporary support that fosters increased flows so that the market can function, also sharing these regions of high tourist potential with the objectives of the trans-European networks in bringing the periphery of Europe closer.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I take the floor today in this Chamber with a voice choked by the consternation of one who lived and personally witnessed the tragedy that struck Madeira last Saturday.

My words are, obviously, to associate myself with the feeling of pain and mourning that has struck the families of the deceased, which currently numbers 42, to whom I offer my tribute and respect for their losses.

The true magnitude of this catastrophe remains to be revealed, as search and rescue teams, working tirelessly since Saturday in a Herculean effort that I commend, are only now beginning to reach the most isolated populations.
and there is concern that the number of casualties may increase.

The scene is one of widespread destruction, with significant material damage to access roads, highways, and areas completely leveled, as well as to essential services such as water and electricity supply.
Approximately 600 people are displaced, having lost their homes and personal belongings.
The economic and social impact of this catastrophe prevents people from resuming a normal life course.
But it is now necessary to look forward.
I also need to deliver a message of solidarity, of hope, and of confidence to the people.
It is necessary to help. And it is in this chapter that the European Union and the Parliament in particular have a role to play. They are fundamental to the process of mobilizing the Solidarity Fund.
And when we are called to intervene, we must do so swiftly, because we cannot ask people to wait, especially when they need us most.

I appeal here to the Commission and its President, Dr. Barroso, and in particular to the Commissioner for Regional Development, Johan Assane, and I commend your initiative to visit Madeira in the shortest possible time.
I ask that he also be a bearer of this message of hope, of aid, and of support for the reconstruction. Because now is the time to rebuild what nature, unfortunately, has once again taken from us.
But I am certain that we will. Because, as the anthem of Madeira taught me, the Madeiran people are humble, stoic, and valiant.
It is the people who tilled the land between the hard rocks. It is the hero of labor in the mountainous scrubland.
Through wood, it will honor its history and along the path of work, it will fight and achieve its well-being and glory.
We begin today’s plenary session with a minute of silence.

It was a minute of silence with two meanings: one of solidarity for the victims of this catastrophe that struck Madeira and their families, and one of tribute to all the workers who have been providing assistance to these victims tirelessly.
But the minute of silence should make us reflect and should also lead to a reflection that extends beyond that which we are doing here.
What we witnessed in Madeira is a phenomenon that will tend to repeat itself increasingly.
Climate change is causing extreme weather events to repeat, and we must have responses to them.
We cannot avoid natural disasters, but we should also not be condemned to the fact that they must always have such dramatic effects on people's lives.
That is why we must advocate for planning and development policies that are oriented towards the public good.

But I want to establish, Mr. President, that what is most important and what brought us here—the European Commission, the European Parliament, the European institutions—must have the capacity to respond urgently to an emergency situation. And for that, the necessary financial resources are required, and the necessary speed is essential.
A tribute of solidarity to the families and friends of the victims of Saturday’s tragic events on the Island of Madeira.

As an Azorean, as a Portuguese person, and as a European, I cannot fail to appeal to the Parliament and to the Union for their demonstration of active solidarity in favor of the Autonomous Region of Madeira and its populations.
It is in the regions that the presence of the Union needs to be felt, and precisely in these moments when its solidarity is most needed that it is also most important for it to be felt.

I too wish to express my solidarity with the people of Madeira and to persistently request the European institutions, and in particular the Commission, to unlock all available means, all means within their reach, to provide that assistance.
I would also like to emphasize that, when a disaster of this kind occurs, it is much more difficult to address its consequences when it happens in poor countries and impoverished regions.

But in the case of wood, we must also consider that the economic basis of the wood industry is directly affected by the fact that, being dependent on tourism, it has a double consequence when its natural beauty, its access routes, and its quality of life are all destroyed.

Therefore, there is indeed a different situation when we have problems of this gravity in poor countries and in poor regions, and particularly in mountainous and tourist regions, as is the case with Madeira.
Therefore, it is absolutely essential that all adaptations that were foreseen and requested, and that have been recalled here concerning the Solidarity Fund, do not await any further delay.

that they immediately assume their functions, because due to climate change and these processes, unfortunately they will repeat, especially in the poorest regions of Europe, which experience torrential rainfall and extreme drought during the summer. Thank you again, Mr. President.
Commissioner and Council, we are here discussing the reinvention of the energy system on a European scale through investment in low-carbon technologies.
I believe it is one of the very important challenges, as is indeed mentioned in the communication that is being made.
and it is one of the challenges we must confront centrally. But there is no clarification here, and hence the importance of raising these questions and requesting clarification.
It appears that not only is clarification of the funding lacking, but political clarification is also absent.
Energy efficiency, carbon capture, nuclear power, biofuels, and solar energy are discussed—indeed, energy efficiency is even cited as the most cost-effective way to reduce emissions.
It surprises me that there are far cheaper ways to reduce carbon emissions that are not even mentioned in this communication, such as, for example, the reduction of greenhouse gas consumption itself.
microgeneration, distribution, and different forms of distribution and projects that do not necessarily have to pass through large structures and access to energy.
I believe that there, we would certainly be contributing to greater financial clarity to make the plan more affordable.

And therefore, within this political clarification and within this financial clarification, it remains to address what appears to me to be an absolutely important point: the persistent emphasis placed on public-private partnerships as if they were a solution for everything.
When asked where the money comes from, we are told by the Commission that it comes from where it is.
I confess that I am not made any clearer by being told that the money will come from where it is, without being told exactly where it is.

Therefore, this emphasis on public-private partnerships, consistently employed when discussing low-carbon technologies, leaves us with a certainty. Namely, lacking clarity regarding the source of funds and knowing that these are public or private partnerships, we inherently understand who will bear the cost.
Those who will pay are the taxpayers initially, and the consumers who are also taxpayers ultimately.

And we know that those who pay the least are the starting point; it is institutions and private organizations that make the investment, are remunerated for it, but ultimately end up monopolizing the profits.
And without this clarification, it appears to me that once again we are systematically passing the bill for Europe’s energy model transition on to future generations.

Thank you, Mr. President. The European Union recently celebrated, within the framework of the World Trade Organization, an agreement with the countries of Latin America, in which it committed to substantially and progressively reduce tariffs on banana imports from those countries.

I draw your attention to the fact that this agreement has directly negative effects on European banana producers, particularly on banana producers in Madeira, Portugal, but also, and in an even more intense manner, on the Canary Islands in Spain.

I reiterate that the situation of producers in these regions is already seriously complicated by the physical and orographic characteristics of the islands and the size of their holdings, which leads them to face permanent difficulties that penalize their development.

Therefore, it is urgently necessary to take measures in defense of banana, timber, and canary producers, considering the serious and immediate impact that the new Geneva Agreement will have on the European market for imports and, consequently, on the production and marketing of bananas originating from these outermost regions.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I would like to begin by
to commend the deputy whom he admires, even in his forced absence, and to highlight the manner in which he was able to craft this important report, thereby facilitating the primary objective.
I would also like to congratulate Deputy Creel on the presentation she gave us.

That primary objective is, without further delay, to simplify the procedures and accelerate the implementation of programs funded by the Cohesion Fund, the Structural Funds, and the Regional Development Fund.
Within the context of the current financial, economic, and social crisis, pressure on national financial resources has been increasing.
This pressure will diminish with better utilization of community funding, with these resources reaching affected beneficiaries more quickly.
Over 20 million Europeans are unemployed, that is, 4 million more than a year ago. And, regrettably, the trend is upward.

This situation demands ensuring the proper implementation of cohesion programs, as they represent the most potent and relevant lever for supporting the real economy, particularly within small and medium-sized enterprises and employment.
SMEs are the engine of the European economy and key players in sustainable growth, generating employment in both quantity and quality.
The ongoing simplification and clarification of the rules governing cohesion policy will undoubtedly have a positive impact on the pace of program implementation, particularly as it will

national, regional, and local authorities, the possibility of resorting to clearer and less bureaucratic rules that will allow greater flexibility in adapting programs to new challenges. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Of course, this crisis was an unforeseen crisis, and of course, the precautionary principle had to take priority.
but there are lessons to be drawn, and the first is that for five days, not a sufficiently strong and politically responsible European voice was heard.
And that voice was missed with regard to the defense of passenger interests, the clarification of their rights, the pursuit of transportation alternatives, and the coordination of solutions.

A second conclusion is that the exit from the crisis must not appear, to the average citizen, to be a game of forces between those who want to avoid losses and those who want to uphold the principle of precaution.
There must be a clear transparency and a clear objectivity regarding the conditions under which one exits a total space beam situation within the European space.
And therefore, the improvement of scientific tests and coordination also at the level...

Thank you, Mr. President. I also want to begin by congratulating my colleague Tikal on their work and persistence on this very important dossier, and for their efforts to improve the energy performance of buildings and towards a more sustainable Europe.
Energy expenditure in the European Union, as we know, is far above what is acceptable, and that is why moving forward with proposals of this nature is so important.
It is more than just time for us to have an ambitious policy in European terms and to add to this ambitious policy complementary measures, especially in the crisis situation in which we live.
The construction sector is considered one of the markets with the greatest potential in terms of energy economics, but that is not all.
And it's not just that, and therefore it is a sector par excellence for the assertion of public policies. And it is in this sense that I would like to conclude, Mr. President.
We must, therefore, capitalize on this opportunity for investments in improving the energy efficiency of buildings and its potential to create millions of jobs in the coming years.
and not only of new buildings, but also in the rehabilitation and recovery of existing buildings, degraded or inadequate.

Let us therefore leverage this legislation as a fundamental contribution to the revitalization of the European economy, and we cannot continue to squander the investment that can and should be strategic for recovery from the crisis. We hope for investment from the Commission and that Member States will know how to utilize this investment. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would like to begin by congratulating the colleague Mandas on the work developed in this report, as well as thanking the colleagues who collaborated with him on this dossier.

In truth, the very fact that this proposal simplifies and improves the existing regulatory framework, bringing together in a single regulation all existing legislation—the three basic directives concerning the designation and marking of textile products—is itself an important factor.

But beyond that, this proposal will have a positive impact on private agents and public authorities, and will also allow for the framework of newly developed fibers, thereby encouraging innovation in the textile and clothing sector.
This review will also enhance the transparency of the process for adding new fibers to the list of harmonized fiber denominations.
It does not appear that there is any doubt that the agents involved will benefit from this regulation.
Let us consider that the textile industry will benefit from reduced administrative costs and the possibility of marketing new fibers sooner.
For their part, the authorities of Member States will not need to transpose the amendments into national legislation, which will enable significant cost savings for those Member States.
And consumers will have the assurance that the fibers designated meet specific characteristics, also benefiting from the fact that the new fibers will reach the market sooner.
For the European industry, the introduction of these new fibers is important as a means of promoting innovation, while also increasing the level of information provided to consumers.
Within the current context of a globalized world, of emerging economies, with increasingly expansive markets in which millions of products circulate, produced by millions of companies,
The investment in innovation and the speed at which that innovation reaches consumers is absolutely crucial for companies, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises.
that the application of this regulation may enhance its competitiveness.
These small and medium-sized enterprises will certainly benefit from this new regulation, gaining market share and, through this means, contributing to increased employment in Europe.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Madam Minister, Mr. Commissioner. The scarcity of organs for transplantation is a greater problem.

It has been referred to here several times, and it is a larger problem that raises questions both of public health and associated issues such as the strengthening of the black market and organ trafficking, which do nothing to enhance either our healthcare systems or our citizens.

Therefore, we must combat this crime and combat it through legislation encompassing proposals such as those we are discussing here. It is, it seems to me, more than important and more than relevant, and for that reason, I want to focus on the most important dimensions and issues raised by these two proposals.
Because the system we have thus far, lacking these two proposals, is a system of enormous inequalities.
inequalities between Member States, inequalities between existing systems, inequalities of access to bodies, inequalities between citizens which it seems to me we cannot sustain and
Therefore, it is important to emphasize that these inequalities are diminishing. And these proposals aim to combat precisely that.
I believe that a European system which nevertheless retains certain specificities of some countries, so as not to oblige them to adopt more restrictive systems, is the answer to this problem.
The work developed by the rapporteurs, Mr. Nicolás Ic and Mr. Perello Rodrigues, is work of extreme importance and a contribution to this problem we face.
If we are discussing proposals based on and supported by issues such as altruism, volunteering, gratuitousness, confidentiality, and data protection,

Traceability, accountability, and here I believe it is important, on the part of Parliament, that extends to the patient's recovery and not just to the donation and cooperation between Member States, I think we are on the right track.
I must, however, state, with regard to donations between living individuals, that I am pleased by the inclusion and expansion, this expansion being accomplished with rights.

Obviously, ensuring all rights and all conditions, but it is very important to have gone beyond the restricted cycle of the conventional family, because otherwise it would be just another way of having other forms of equality.

Therefore, promoting DAD (Donation for Advancement of Donation) and the Main Transplant Fund, and protecting patient data and security, seems to me to be more than sufficient reasons for all of us to be together tomorrow and vote favorably on these two proposals of extreme importance to humanity.

President, Minister, and Commissioner, the ability to replace deteriorated human organs with organs from another person, preventing their rejection, is one of the great successes of contemporary medicine.

European benchmarking reveals that mid-sized countries like Portugal perform very well in such comparisons, and larger countries like Spain are now recognized as organizational leaders and exemplars of best practices.
certain principles and practices to safeguard.

Firstly, the reinforcement of scientific knowledge and information that increasingly leads donors to living donation and to the generalization of post-mortem donation. Secondly, the prohibition of the commercialization of the drug.

Not only within Member States but also outside them, preventing transplant tourism and combating organ trafficking. Thirdly, the proactive promotion of donation in hospitals, as a means of overcoming scarcity.

Finally, Madam President, ensuring equal access to transplantation for all those who need it and qualify for it according to harmonized clinical criteria, adhering to the principle of universal access to healthcare, a paradigm of Social Europe, which we are proud of.
I commend the rapporteurs for their work.
I would like to underscore that it is with great satisfaction that the European People’s Party and the Portuguese deputies of the Party
European Public, witness the commencement of this process of accession, of joining the European Union to the European Convention on Human Rights.

We, a country like Portugal, which has always been at the forefront of human rights, with the abolition of slavery in Portugal as early as 1761, and with pioneering work in the abolition of the death penalty, can only be, evidently, interested in and supportive of this accession process.

I would, however, like to draw attention to the very important consideration that the European Parliament should follow, step by step, the entire negotiation of the European Union’s accession to the European Convention on Human Rights.

We consider this aspect, from a technical, legal, and political perspective, to be fundamental because Parliament itself is a home of human rights and a place where human rights hold great relevance. And I would now simply like to emphasize a point that we consider very important.

For us, members of the European Parliament, who are in contact with many states outside the European Union, it is very important—it is a very good signal that we give to the members of the Council of Europe—the entry of the European Union, to the members of the Council of Europe who are not members of the European Union.
For these members of the Council of Europe, it represents a signal of strengthened commitment from the European Union to their situation and to levels of democracy and respect for fundamental rights.
Madam President and Commissioner, Social Housing is an economic service of general interest with an important role in the market, creating positive externalities to the benefit of all of society.
According to Protocol 26, annexed to the Treaty of Lisbon, the execution and organization of this type of service falls to national, regional, and local authorities.
Therefore, this restriction of the target audience to families with incomes below 33,000 euros is scarcely comprehensible.

This is a measure of poverty that is conducted in absolute and purely financial terms, failing to account for the diversity of the 27 Member States and reducing itself to a simple argument of solvency.
Now, social housing addresses cultural, social, proximity-to-workplace issues, the significant redefinition of women’s roles in the market, and the mobility of workers within the European space.
The struggle that the European Union is undertaking to overcome the current crisis involves economic growth, which entails an increase in immigration and ethnic minorities.
economically and culturally, and by the need for its integration, even with the risks of ghettoization associated with it, which we must combat with a just balance.
Is the Commission not encroaching upon the competence of the Member States?

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues,

Allow me, Madam President, to point out the fact that we are debating the first report from the Committee on Agriculture, subject to the new ordinary legislative procedure laid down by the Treaty of Lisbon.

This concerns a historic moment that, should this Chamber confirm the sense of the vote I propose, will initiate in the best possible way this new period of sharing responsibilities in agricultural matters within the European Union.
I speak directly with Algeizolano about its outermost regions in a practical demonstration of the will to build a Union strengthened by cohesion.
in the spirit of active solidarity, in respect for the specificities and differences of its parts, as the only viable path to the construction of our common European project.
I also introduce fundamental regulation to enable the already century-old sugar sector in the Azores, the region from which I originate, therefore I am particularly pleased, thus contributing to a
Healthy diversification of agriculture in a region where the dairy sector occupies, as we know, a unique dimension on a national scale, irreplaceable, which we must sustain and consolidate.
Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for Jealousy and the senior officials of the Commission with whom we have worked and negotiated, for the openness and flexibility demonstrated.
The Spanish Presidency of the Council also exerted every effort to ensure that our shared desire to reach an agreement at first reading became a reality.

This acknowledgement is, of course, extendable to the shadow rapporteurs of the other political groups, as well as to the excellent officials of the Secretariat of the Committee on Agriculture of this Parliament, whose collaboration allowed us to reach a result that I consider very positive.

I would also like to underscore the decisive contribution made by the Açores Farmers' Federation and by the Regional and Republic Governments in the manner in which they engaged and committed themselves to achieving a solution for Azorean sugar.

The presentation of the Council’s proposed regulation on October 2nd before the Agriculture Committee occurred at a time when there were no prospects for the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which continued to await ratification by all Member States.
In this context, the initial idea of the Commission and the Council was that the proposal should be approved in a simplified procedure, without any amendments, to take effect from 1 January 2010.

With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon and despite, at the time, the dominance of opinion among other political groups, as well as the Council and the Commission, for the proposal to remain in a streamlined process, because they understood that

the proposal did not require amendments and should enter into force rapidly. Despite upholding this view, I and the socialist and democratic group believed that Parliament should already issue its opinion within the scope of the Treaty of Lisbon, assuming its role as co-legislator.

Fortunately, we did so because from that point onward new possibilities opened up, first with the contribution of the Regional Development Commission and the opinion of my colleague Nuno Teixeira, whom I take this opportunity to

To congratulate and thank you for the constant cooperation provided throughout this process and subsequently for my report, introducing new possibilities for sugar in the Azores, as well as for the contribution and support of the colleagues from the Agriculture Commission.

I would like to say, finally, in this first intervention, that, regarding the amendments proposed by the Regional Commission and voted on in the Agri Commission, and which I supported, we were unable to secure their acceptance in the compromise reached in the triúgio.

It was essential to secure a first reading commitment, thereby safeguarding the improvements already achieved and the need for effective entry to avoid compromising its retroactivity from January of this year.
However, with the Commission already preparing a review document for the POSEI, we will certainly have the opportunity to debate them again soon.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. We are facing an acceleration of a global change that has devastating consequences for our economic, political, and social systems and, consequently, for all our citizens.
We are witnessing today an unprecedented weakening of the capacity of states to respond.
Consequently, the European Union must identify common causes and allies and act clearly and unitedly on the world stage.
Extraordinary situations demand clarity in collective action.

If we fail to implement the necessary collective measures of rigor and accountability, Europe will be consigned to marginalization and impoverishment. Only a strong Europe, respectful of its common rules, can provide an adequate response to the new times.
Fragile and indebted states lack the capacity to protect their citizens.

Because, achieving [this], we need to be able to regain the trust of citizens, win the battles of stability, budgetary rigor, job creation, stability of the Monetary Union, globalization, and strategic choices.
Otherwise, our future will be compromised.
And the future is won by investing in social cohesion, ensuring peace, and building a new model based on values of freedom, social justice, and responsibility.
Thus, the Europe 2020 strategy and the integrated Europe 2020 guidelines constitute essential instruments for a new cycle of growth and employment in Europe.
For correct implementation and achievement, it is necessary to define quantifiable and clear objectives in employment, education, and poverty reduction.

It is also decisive for the success of the strategy that everything be done to facilitate the transposition by Member States of their national objectives and to ensure the correct implementation of this strategy. Thank you very much.
When the Economic and Monetary Union celebrated its 10th anniversary, the Commission regarded the Euro as the Union's most successful project.
Today, we would have difficulty affirming it without limitations, because the crisis demonstrated beyond doubt that the Economic and Monetary Union is an unfinished project.
Minimal salvage measures were taken amidst a climate of emergency, but let us not be deceived. The conditions of pressure, the direct interests of the major…
member states. The painful nature of decisions, their slowness, have weakened the image of the euro and the European Union in the eyes of citizens and the world.
We must face the facts.
The European Union and the Euro are a process of integration, not merely inter-state cooperation.
They are an unfinished process that, at this moment, either strengthens itself or runs serious risks of disappearing.
There are three themes that must be addressed. First, it is important to consolidate the instruments that were launched in this climate of emergency. It is necessary to create a monetary fund.

European, it is necessary to move forward with eurobonds, it is necessary to move forward with the European supervisory and regulatory architecture, and it is necessary to move forward with a European dimension in the management of banking crises.
Second dimension, it is important to understand that there is no strong currency if the economy is weak. The projected 1% growth for the European Union is unsustainable in terms of...
Whether concerning its demographic composition or in terms of combating unemployment, the 2020 Strategy is nothing more than a collection of good ideas if it lacks the means for implementation.

Third dimension, Mr. Commissioner Ollirane, fiscal consolidation is important, but it cannot coexist with growing divergences among the Member States that comprise the Union. The convergence policy must be urgently revisited. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Several colleagues here at the PPF have already provided a very comprehensive picture of the situation.
I judge that it will now be necessary to demand and to make a reference to the role of Nation States.
De facto, national governments also have a role here in imposing, within their States, the requirements.
and the conditions for the single currency to be strengthened and for this project of monetary and economic integration to be advanced.
And here I wanted to say that our party, the party linked to the PPE, which is PSD, in Portugal, is supporting the Government in the austerity measures, because we consider

that the errors the Socialist Government has committed over these 15 years in Portugal, and which today unfortunately are evident to everyone, need to be rectified and will have the support of the PSD to be rectified.

But if we are supporting austerity measures, we are also criticizing the Portuguese government. And it’s a good example for other analogous cases, because it isn't reducing expenditure. And what is fundamental is not merely…

Increase taxes to reduce the deficit, but it is reducing expenditure. It is demanding that the Government have the courage to take measures that reduce expenditure, that alleviate the deficit, that alleviate public debt.

This applies to Portugal and applies to other States that are today in a difficult situation. And we, as Members of the European Parliament, have the responsibility of also doing it in our own countries.
An advocacy of the measures necessary for the euro to emerge strengthened and for this space of integration and this dream, which is a dream of the PPE and a dream of us all, to be realized.
Therefore, we criticize those governments that lack the courage to take the necessary measures within their own states.

Dear colleagues, I would like to begin by stating that the report on the assessment of the results of the 2006-2010 roadmap for gender equality, and which aims to influence strategies on this matter for the future, could, in our opinion, have been more assertive and less contentious.

In truth, the manner of addressing various ethically sensitive issues, notably the issue of women’s sexual and reproductive health, should have been distinct if the objective were genuinely to achieve the broadest possible consensus.

Having said that, I would like to emphasize that in times of so-called normal economic growth, concern regarding women's rights, particularly the disparity between the situation of men and women in the workplace, in society, and in the family, is significant. But these problems are profoundly exacerbated by economic and social crises such as the one we are experiencing.
Hence the need for a strengthened strategic commitment from the Member States, at the level of local and regional entities and Community institutions, with regard to protection.

to say, in line with what the President Dou stated and what the colleague Werner Langen stated, it is fundamental that there be an Economic Government of the Union, but that this Economic Government be centered on the Commission.
This is the first point I wanted to emphasize. And having said that, I want to say that we should not, as we have done all morning here, limit our debate to immediate issues,
also in those that are included in the Strategy 2020. And I would particularly emphasize the issue of education and training of young people, the issue of innovation, research, and development.

Because those are the niches that will allow Europe to be competitive in the global space. And today I must say that, regrettably, the European education model has failed. And it has failed because, when compared with the model of emerging countries,

Like India, like China, like Brazil, it is today a less demanding and less rigorous model. And for this reason, I also request that in the boldness of this idea of innovation, development, research, and education, there be rigor and demand within the context of European educational systems.
Only with this rigor and demandingness do we prepare our young people to compete in the global market.

We cannot think only of this year’s crisis or that of the next two or three years; we must think of the strategy for Europe over the next 10 to 20 years, and it depends on an educational system of rigor and demanding standards.
Mr. Commissioner, never until today has the European project, built with so much effort over the last 50 years, been so threatened.
European citizens’ frustration is immense. The financial system that should have served them destroyed their savings, their pensions, their investment plans, their jobs—in short, their future.
Regarding the necessary strengthening of the entire financial services market – banks, insurance, securities – the path forward is clear and lies in the architecture we are discussing today.
We indeed require a robust European supervisory architecture, covering all products and actors, equipped with methodologies and instruments of
effective interventions that are capable of responding to market realities, which, particularly in the European context, do not recognize national borders.

Risk cannot and should not be eliminated from the financial market, but we need regulation that makes this risk more transparent and prevents the accumulation of bubbles whose explosion affects the entire system and spreads to the real economy.

But if, despite these safeguards, new crises occur in the future, it is crucial to have mechanisms that limit contagion, particularly with regard to the banking system, because it is vital for the functioning of the economy and the repository of citizens’ savings.

Here, precisely in the powers and competencies of banking supervisory authority, lies the capacity to execute a new strategy on the management of cross-border banking crises, a subject to which my report refers.
It is not within our power to prevent the bankruptcy of banks, but rather to ensure that their reorganization or eventual liquidation are carried out in
in an orderly fashion, limiting collateral effects on the rest of the system and, above all, preventing the taxpayer from bearing the costs of the crises they generate.

For this, a set of new instruments is necessary. It is necessary to adopt rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments, and terminology common to all stakeholders in restructuring, reorganization, or liquidation operations.
It is necessary to harmonize the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, notably bankruptcy and liquidation laws.
It is necessary to grant supervisors enhanced intervention powers.
It is necessary to establish clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, that allow for the initiation of interventions in a struggling institution.
Contingency plans must be prepared.
This entire process, involving 27 Member States, requires time.
Meanwhile, approximately 50 banks of the 12,000 operating in Europe represent 70% of the assets.
Now, this signifies a significant concentration of risk, but also an opportunity to intervene with priority regarding them.

Therefore, conditions exist to propose a special and urgent process for the resolution of banks, which, being cross-border institutions, due to their size, relationships with other banks, have a potential systemic impact on the financial system.
Now, for these banks, special supervision by the new European Banking Authority can be anticipated, although operating within the Council of National Supervisors.
It is possible and urgent that they, in view of the risk they generate, begin to make contributions to a fund that finances any potential interventions.
that are necessary, and it is important that the banking authority create a specialized unit that coordinates interventions in the event of difficulties at these banks.
Overall, the proposed elements ensure that interventions in transnational systematically important banks are consistent and coherent among
different countries and, above all, that a principle so dear in Europe be upheld: that the costs of pollution caused by these banks be borne by the polluter themselves.
This proposal fits perfectly within what we are discussing, particularly regarding the competencies of the banking authority. I would even say that it is the most evident test of its effectiveness.
In the case of the vote in the Economic and Monetary Committee, there was an overwhelming majority of support for this proposal, 87% of the votes.
We also count on the massive vote of this institution here in plenary, in order to, by overwhelmingly supporting this proposal, which is visionary, which is realistic, but which is pragmatic, we…
Let us undertake an action that is urgent and necessary to rekindle the hope of Europeans in Europe, in its financial system, and, in particular, in the banking system. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much.

Deforestation, as we know, is one of the principal environmental and social problems of the planet, and we lose 13 million hectares of forest each year, thereby contributing to 20% of the globe's carbon emissions and constituting a significant threat to biodiversity.

The contribution of deforestation to climate change is undeniable, and therefore it is largely responsible for the occurrence of extreme weather events, floods, or even the desertification of vast areas of the planet.
Forest loss places all of humanity at risk, but this risk and impact are not shared equally among us.
Communities with fewer resources and those most dependent on the forest and nature for survival are the most affected.
Deforestation pertains to our collective existence, to the scarcity of natural resources, their distribution, the rights of local and Indigenous communities, and to social justice.
The primary cause of deforestation is the illegal logging of timber, which accounts for 20 to 40% of global industrial wood production.
Therefore, we are also discussing the transfer of wealth from producing countries to consumer countries of that same wood.
This illegal practice puts at risk the sustainable exploitation of timber and the companies that engage in it.
Fine words are not enough.
This Parliament should adopt strong and consequential measures in this fight.
This report takes a very significant step in this direction by defining the prohibition of timber trade.
Good intentions are not enough, either.
Effective measures are required, notably sanctions that in this case may be of three types.

First, fines that effectively remove the economic benefit from the illegal practice, increased with recidivism. Second, confiscation of the wood of the products in question. And third, immediate suspension of the authorization to engage in a commercial activity.

And so it is because whoever exploits or commercializes a natural resource must be socially responsible. And so it is also that whoever places timber or timber products for the first time in the European Union must be subject to due diligence to ensure that it is timber exploited legally.
That is why all subsequent operators should provide basic information about this wood, specifically its origin and destination.
The population must also have the right, and I conclude here, Mr. President, the right of access to information regarding who complies and who does not. Thank you very much.

We clearly need architects.
Finally, I would like to know the external dimension of the European Union's action, particularly to learn more about what the Belgian presidency proposes for Cancún and for Doha.

Agricultural policies are increasingly market-oriented, and farmers in Europe are facing very low levels of income, while millions of consumers, as a result of the crisis affecting everyone, find themselves in constant need of maintaining affordable food prices.

That is why, if farmers’ income is going to depend increasingly on the values generated in markets and the price of food on its proper functioning, then improving the functioning of the food supply chain is essential.

It becomes absolutely necessary for a more equitable sharing of value generated from agricultural producers to final consumers, ensuring fair incomes for the former and appropriate prices for the latter.

To achieve this, it is necessary to rebalance the relationships established throughout the food supply chain, ensuring transparency and guaranteeing the existence of a framework of fair and competitive best practices.
In this regard, we support the Commission in considering the widely supported proposals within the Agriculture Committee.
A few days ago, in Arouca, Portugal, all the workers at a footwear company were dismissed via a simple mobile phone message. Without further explanation.
I bring this case here because it is, unfortunately, a blatant example of collective dismissal abuses in Europe.
It contravenes all European norms and wounds any semblance of common sense, respect, and dignity.
Europe has gained 8 million new unemployed since the crisis began, bringing the total to 25 million. How many have been dismissed in such a shameful manner as this?
I would say it more and more, unfortunately.
The European Union claims a long tradition of safeguarding workers’ rights.
However, current legislation has not been effective.
So, what additional measures will the Commission take?
It is for this reason that this question is so pertinent.
There is no justification for layoffs such as the one in Iorocaba.
It will be an innovation to fire via SMS, but it is not a good innovation; it is certainly a very bad one.
The environmental catastrophe currently under debate, although occurring outside the geographical space of the Union, concerns us all, European citizens.

The notion of sustainable development we embrace is a concept that transcends administrative boundaries, religious beliefs, and views the planet as a whole, rather than the sum of its constituent parts.
The River Jordan is, therefore, a problem for all of humanity and not solely for the populations or communities directly affected by water scarcity or its poor quality.
Common sense tells us.
That is what we are here today to do, think globally.
As the European Union, we must assist in acting locally as a means of minimizing and reversing this persistent degradation of the flow and quality of the waters of the Jordan River.
And to act or assist in acting, the Union already has a legislative, institutional framework, and instruments at its disposal.
I am referring to the Union for the Mediterranean, its secretariat, and the FEMIP, managed by the European Investment Bank.
This is, obviously, a topic that the delegation of this Parliament, which I preside over, regarding relations with the MASHREC countries, will follow closely.

It is evident that action leading to the resolution of this environmental tragedy should, first and foremost, be undertaken by the States and local authorities whose populations directly benefit from it.
Within this framework, I would like to emphasize two ideas present in the resolution.
Firstly, the creation of a commission for the management of the entire Jordan River basin, comprised of representatives of the States or authorities that utilize those waters.
And here, Europe can help by sharing, for example, the experience of the International Commission for the Protection of the Rhine.
Secondly, the support and dissemination of good practices regarding joint community projects, involving Jordanian, Israeli, and Palestinian citizens,
namely, those promoted by Friends of Terra-Middle East, which the colleague from Roça invoked just now, regarding the efficient and correct management of water resources in the Jordan Valley Basin.
Finally, Mr. President, and within an even broader scope, to highlight the example of cooperation and peaceful coexistence that this design embodies.

At the moment when, although regretting the absence of the European Union in the process, we welcome and encourage the resumption of the new process of direct dialogue between Israel and the Palestinian Authority, we wish to acknowledge this direct engagement of the two parties.

Thank you, Madam President. We are discussing here today yet another human rights violation, that of the imprisonment of the Syrian activist Aytan Almaleh, an 80-year-old lawyer, accused of allegedly spreading false and exaggerated news that undermines the national sentiments of his country.

Beyond the violation of numerous treaties and international conventions, the imprisonment of this human rights defender is also contrary to the country’s own legislation, which stipulates that military courts should not have jurisdiction to try civilians.

The decision that was made regarding this man and regarding other Syrian prisoners detained for similar reasons, the various detentions, the restrictions on freedom of movement, and the arbitrary measures taken.

by Syrian authorities are practices that contradict the important role of Syria throughout the region and do not reflect the efforts that have been made in this country to improve the social situation.

I highlight two. The first, the rejection of the sentence of death by stoning imposed on Sakineh Ashtiani.
Many voices have joined together, and there have already been some results.

It is not yet time to declare victory, but far less is it time for us to remain silent. Today, we approved a significant resolution against the abuses imposed by the Sarkozy Government on Roman and Bulgarian citizens.
The defense of human rights knows no borders and is not a struggle to be fought only elsewhere.
Today, we provided a good example of how to address it behind closed doors as well.
The unjust imprisonment of Aitan Almaleh unites us all here today.
He is a human rights advocate.
Human rights defenders must be free people, and that is what we demand of Syrian authorities.
We, also human rights defenders, will not leave him alone. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, the fact that the safety profile of new medications is increasingly only fully known after their entry into the market imposes the need for a pharmacovigilance system more effective than has been in place thus far.
We are facing a typical risk management problem, but at a macro and supranational level. Let's bring it closer to the citizens. Now.
New medications have played a fundamental role in public health and advancements in healthcare over the past decades.
Adverse drug reactions continue to be the fifth leading cause of hospital mortality.
The proposals presented reinforce the contribution of medicines to modern public health through a community-based pharmacovigilance system, improving coordination and transparency.
It aims to monitor, detect early, communicate, and evaluate adverse reactions.
The new medications will have a graphic symbol indicating that they are still under scrutiny.

User participation in control is encouraged. Studies of effectiveness at the national level are stimulated, a new sensitivity to environmental consequences is fostered, and community control institutions are improved. The Praco.

Mr. President, I should like to begin, first of all, by thanking and congratulating the rapporteur, as well as all colleagues who were involved in this process.
We know that adverse drug effects are the fifth leading cause of hospital mortality—it is never superfluous to repeat this—and a robust and transparent drug monitoring system is essential.
We now have the opportunity to strengthen the safety of medications already available, going beyond laboratory tests that do not always anticipate problems.

If concrete examples were needed to justify the importance of a new system, consider what happened with the H1N1 flu vaccine. Speed in placing the vaccine on the market and negligence in investigating the side effects that were detected, which further delay a complete investigation.
It is therefore necessary that we continue to deepen this path.
This Directive ensures the more active involvement of healthcare professionals and patients in identifying difficulties.

A Europe without economic, social, and territorial cohesion is not a Union.
Mountainous regions, islands, and areas with low population density present their own, considerably difficult challenges, which must be overcome in the name of a Europe of the people.
But we must go beyond statements of intent, otherwise, we have the opposite effect, that is, we reinforce inequalities.
These regions are vast reservoirs of important resources.
Biodiversity, forests, wetlands, and green areas provide an essential service for all and, nonetheless, suffer from the resulting limitations on their economic viability.
There is a need to reciprocate.
The populations of these regions must be collectively supported by all.
I offer two proposals.
First, the potential contribution to science and development.
Many of these regions are authentic open-air laboratories, given their richness, but lack equal access to research resources.
Why not then equip them with centers of excellence in research, generating quality jobs and invigorating their economies?
A second proposal concerns energy.
These regions can and should serve as the foundation for projects demonstrating the potential of self-sufficiency and energy sustainability, notably through microgeneration from nearby sources.
Dependence was reduced, equality and job creation were increased.
Finally, I want to state that using GDP as the sole or primary indicator for the allocation of funds in aid can only result in further injustice.
It is therefore very important to use complementary data, particularly that which portrays the social and economic reality of these regions.
I cannot fail to make a special reference here to the peoples of the Azores, Madeira, the mountainous regions, and the depopulated interior areas of Portugal.
With your efforts, you contribute significantly to development and the quality of life for all Europeans.
These and all regions have their own context.
Social, economic, and territorial cohesion should not be viewed as an act of charity.
This is where it is determined whether or not we want a genuine European redistribution policy.
I consider, for all these reasons, this resolution to be an important, but initial step.

For the celebration, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the objective of territorial cohesion, now enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, embodies the value of European solidarity and the commitment of the Member States and the Union to reduce the disparities existing between the various regions.
It is not enough, however, to express in the texts of treaties the objectives to be achieved.
There are regions within the Union that face persistent constraints severely conditioning their economic and social development.

It is therefore necessary to implement specific programs that allow for the effective and genuine overcoming of the lag in these regions, by promoting an adaptation of their development model to their potential and resources and contributing to the achievement of the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy.

This incentive for these regions should result not only from the means of regional policy, through its structural adjustment instruments, such as the Cohesion Fund and the four Structural Funds, but also
also stems from a different utilization of various sector policies, which have a significant territorial impact in each region and can therefore have a stimulating effect on their economies.
For the determination of European assistance to these regions, it is certainly necessary to maintain GDP as the primary indicator of eligibility.

Nevertheless, and considering its inherent disadvantages, it becomes pertinent to resort to other measurable criteria capable of providing a more realistic picture of its level of development, such as the unemployment rate, population density, or the level of education.
Only in this way will it be possible to have a more complete picture of the complex reality of the most disadvantaged regions.

Let me illustrate the case of the outermost regions, for whom recognition was established by the new treaty, and which constitute a group of regions within the European Union possessing specific characteristics and deserving of special treatment.
The regions of the ultraperiphery, united by their particular characteristics, also diverge in their levels of development.

Similarly, with respect to these [entities/regions], complementary indicators to GDP should be utilized, capable of providing a more complete description of their specific reality and thus contributing to a more accurate determination of their level of development. Thank you very much.

derive from the Treaty of Lisbon in opportunities for the populations of territories experiencing various permanent natural constraints to participate in the European project.

because we must first define the content of policies before allocating the necessary means for their implementation, as has indeed been happening with Community policies now under review.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, Commissioners, dear colleagues, after four consecutive years of declining unemployment rates from 2004 to 2008, the current economic crisis has undone much of the progress achieved.
Unemployment rates within the European Union have experienced a significant increase. For example, in Portugal, we reached the unfortunate record level of an unemployment rate of 11%.
Another negative phenomenon is youth unemployment in the European Union.
Europe is currently traversing a period of transformation and faces enormous challenges.
The crisis nullified years of economic and social progress and exposed the vulnerabilities of its member states' economies and, consequently, of the European Union itself.
The 2020 strategy outlines the path forward.
The European Union must intensify all its efforts to promote employment and social inclusion, as an integral part of its strategy to combat the economic and social crisis.
Thus, the proposal for a resolution on the future of the Social Fund, currently under debate, is welcomed, as this fund plays a crucial role in achieving the objectives of the 2020 Strategy.

In fact, this fund is the principal financial instrument that enables the European Union to realize the strategic objectives of its employment policy, improving the levels of education and qualification of its citizens.
The ESF should be strengthened as the primary driver of the 2020 Strategy and should be used by Member States to invest in skills for employment, training, and professional retraining.

Finally, I would like to emphasize that the reform of the European Social Fund, to be carried out in conjunction with that of the other structural funds, should facilitate and simplify its management and
to reinforce transparency, as well as concentrate funds on achieving results and realizing objectives that are effectively felt by citizens in their daily lives. Thank you very much.
The European Social Fund is arguably the most structuring instrument of cohesion.
It should therefore have a strong connection with the Regional Development Fund.
It is fundamental to adopt a local approach to the issues to be resolved, that is, a global perspective for a local action.

Local and regional authorities are the entities with the greatest knowledge of their realities, their investment needs for job creation, and which measures are most suitable for promoting employment in their regions.
We must take into account the positive experiences of the regions.
In the Azores, an ultraperipheral region where unemployment typically reaches record levels, the unemployment rate is 6.5%, the lowest in Portugal.

This is largely due to the prospective planning strategy employed for employment, defining factors to act upon, how to achieve the desired flow, and also the utilization of the European Social Fund as an operational instrument of this strategy, acting on education, training, and employment promotion.
The horizontality of cohesion policy is the only way to ensure the success of the Strategy.
Cohesion policy is the cornerstone of European solidarity.
It is through cohesion that the objective of reducing disparities between regions is achieved and the harmonious development of the entire European Union is encouraged.
In the next period, from 2014 to 2020, we must define a framework capable of reinforcing the effectiveness of regional policy.

Governance, at various levels, should be encouraged with greater involvement and participation of regional and local entities in respect of the principle of subsidiarity and as foreseen in the new Treaty of Lisbon.
The special situation of the outermost regions must not be forgotten.
This set of regions faces very significant challenges and should continue to benefit in the future from specific provisions in the application of European policies.
GDP should continue to be the primary eligibility criterion, but we must consider other indicators that can provide a more complete picture of regional realities.
...aged and with very low birth rates.
These factors represent enormous challenges for the European Union to which we must provide concrete responses.
This finding has been universally accepted throughout our discussion, despite the differing perspectives that this debate has highlighted.
In Portugal, for example, the birth rate does not ensure the renewal of generations and reveals a reality that compromises the future.
This situation occurs in my country as it does in most of the Union’s Member States.
I am confident that more flexible policies regarding maternity leave could help to reverse these trends.
We must send families a consistent message of support for motherhood, with concrete measures for a better balance between professional, private, and family life.
Women should be protected so they can choose to have children without having to leave the workforce.
Achieving this challenge is essential if we are to reach the economic and social objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and combat demographic aging.
In Portugal, for example, maternity leave is already fully remunerated for 120 days, in an attempt to counteract the declining birth rate we are experiencing.
I therefore contend that women’s salaries should be guaranteed during maternity leave, in accordance with the model presented in the report under discussion.
Allowing each Member State, by 2020, to establish conditions that guarantee the objective of full salary payment during maternity leave appears to be a sensible procedure.

Finally, I commend the rapporteur Edith Estrela for her persistence in advocating for measures aimed at protecting families, while simultaneously contributing to counteracting the population's investment.
First, regarding these two reports, I would like to commend and offer here public testimony, as I already did before the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, for the remarkable work done by
colleagues Lena, Suoboda, Ror Berendt, Diana Wallis, and Rebeca Harms, who formed part of the Parliament's delegation that negotiated this framework agreement with the Commission.

I would also like to register the great openness and highly constructive spirit of collaboration of the President of the Commission and, following the inauguration of the new Commission, of Commissioner Shevchovitch and his teams.
I believe that a remarkable work has been achieved, leading to a historic agreement, an agreement that represents the first framework agreement following the signature of the Treaty of
and it is the first framework agreement that has a direct basis, a basis expressly stated in the treaties, more precisely in Article 295 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
I would like to say that this agreement, in fact, creates a relationship of great transparency and great dynamism, even of a certain intimacy in the relationship between the
Parliament and the Commission and essentially represents a compromise, a balance between the two institutions' vision of the new role that each of them will have after the Treaty of Lisbon.

I believe that our negotiating team's work was, in fact, very positive, because it managed to give translation, within this framework agreement, to those which are the new competencies and to that which is the strengthening of powers resulting from the Treaty of Lisbon.
This applies to the legislative procedure and to programming or planning, notably, for example, just to give two examples, in the involvement of Parliament in
work program of the Commission or, for example, in issues related to the use of soft law in those which are legislative competencies of the Parliament by the Commission.

On a second line, a very important aspect is the strengthening of the Parliament’s powers of control and scrutiny. Whether detailing and specifying the rules for the election of the President and the Board of Commissioners, or, for example,

Regarding the Parliament’s involvement in matters such as restructuring or the potential departure of a commissioner, or, for example, the hearing of directors from regulatory agencies, or indeed, the monitoring of international negotiations.
In all these dimensions, there was indeed a consecration of powers, powers that result from the layout of Lisbon.
It is also very important to have access to information, and in particular, to classified information or to information that is classified.
And, furthermore, the exchange of information and the exchange of viewpoints between Parliament officials and Commission officials.

For example, we know that today it is already possible for the Commissioner responsible for institutional affairs and the President of the Commission to participate in the relevant parts of the Conference of Presidents.

Or, for example, that there are several platforms for dialogue between the Conference of Presidents, the Conference of Committee Chairs, the President of Parliament, the President of the Commission, and the College of Commissioners, all of them duly expressed.

Even the presence of the Commission in Parliament was reinforced in Parliament, notably through the application of Question Hour not only to the President of the Commission, but also to the Commissioners.
I would therefore say that, with a deep respect for the Treaty of Lisbon and its new balance of powers, and with a deep respect for the idea of the separation of powers,
We have here a clarifying agreement that serves to make the Treaty of Lisbon current, to make it alive, to make it applicable.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I begin by commending the rapporteur colleague for her work, as well as greeting all those who collaborated with her on this report, which enabled us to reach this agreement at first reading.

The negative effects of this practice on the economic life are enormous, both at the level of small and medium-sized enterprises and at the level of the domestic market. This legislative amendment serves to provide coherence and meaning to the European economic recovery plan and the application of measures for small businesses.
business act. It is certain that this directive will improve the liquidity of companies.

Thank you, Mr. Deputy Alves. There is currently a significant disparity in many Member States regarding payment terms to businesses, particularly when the State, SMEs, and large companies are involved.

We who have come from the business world know that in this situation of economic crisis and increased financing difficulties, companies are increasingly struggling with liquidity problems, and are even in many Member States exposed to an increased risk of insolvency.

It appears clear that the current Directive, which attempted to regulate this matter, had limited effects, and therefore the proposal we are now analyzing represents an important step toward compliance.
Payment terms, not only in relationships between companies and public entities, but also, and this is essential, in the relationships that companies establish with each other.

We now have legislation that brings us greater added value, with a clear system of sanctions for payment delays and that equally brings about an effective improvement in the balance of abuse of the dominant position established by the State and large companies.
Thank you very much, Madam President. Commissioner, allow me to speak about what remains unsaid.

I listened very attentively to the commissioner, and from what I heard, it seems to me—I'd like to say—that, to date, the most effective action, whether by national authorities or European authorities, has been the management of silence.
Industrial accidents can and should be avoided. This is also why European legislation exists, and it seems obvious that the law has been violated.
There was ineffectiveness, delayed response, and abandonment of those affected, particularly the most vulnerable.
People have died, and many continue today under the threat of what may happen to their health.
It is impossible to calculate the total costs and it is immoral not to care for the victims.
How is it possible, I ask you, Madam Commissioner, that we learn of news through reports reaching us from Hungarian citizens and the authorities see or tell us nothing?
That is why I would like to raise some questions.
How is it permissible for the Bank to pressure citizens with mortgaged homes in the affected area, demanding that they pay what they owe, when their homes have lost value?
How is it permissible for telephone operators to cut off the sole means of contact for those in a disaster zone?
How is it that the company responsible for this catastrophe has already resumed operations?
And finally, Madam Commissioner, you spoke of mitigating the effects of blade runoff.
I ask you what the reasons are for continuing to mitigate the true dimension of this human tragedy.
It's that it seems like we’re always starting from scratch.

Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating Mr. Commissioner Barnier on the presentation of this important document.

As you diagnosed, the impact of the crisis we are experiencing is being felt in all sectors of society and of our economy, causing our citizens discouragement and distrust regarding the single market.
But it is precisely this unique market that is one of the assets Europe possesses to combat the current crisis.
Therefore, we warmly welcome this communication, which represents a new ambition for the policies of the single market, enabling us to restore confidence in our social market economy model.
In the current situation, the European Union must give particular attention to its 20 million small and medium-sized enterprises.
In this regard, one of the Union's priorities should be the creation of mechanisms that resolve the issue of access to credit for these companies.

We also highlight the Commission’s proposal to evaluate the Small Business Act by the end of 2010, with the aim of facilitating the lives of these businesses, particularly through bureaucratic and tax simplification, as well as the promotion of social responsibility.
We hope that these 50 measures now presented will contribute to deepening the internal market, fully leveraging its potential, which could represent supplementary growth for the European economy.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. We are here today to discuss what has been presented as one of the European Commission’s highest priorities, namely the innovation policy.
takes shape finally, notably through European partnerships for innovation and with this pilot project that we are discussing today regarding active and healthy aging.
However, there are many aspects that still need to be defined, particularly regarding clarification, the definition of future projects, and the establishment of priorities.
Who, ultimately, will define the priorities and on the basis of what criteria?
I believe these answers are due to us.
But I would like to leave some concrete and particular notes in relation to this first project on active and healthy aging that was presented to us.

And these notes are, from the outset, a positive note because it seems to me positive that the focus is on a sector of the population that is particularly vulnerable, in a Europe that is increasingly aged and increasingly disadvantaged.
However, I would like to add even more questions to these, because it seems contradictory to present a project in this area when, at the same time, we have nowhere to sustain this innovation.
How are we going to sustain it?
What is the foundation?

Is there any viable innovation within a context such as the one we are witnessing, where there is a persistent and systematic attack on the Welfare State, the reduction of access to healthcare, systematic cuts in services provided, and continued disinvestment in this area?
The title of the communication that was presented—a union of innovation, more employment, improved lives, a better society—is ambitious.

I would even go so far as to say that I would have no problem personally endorsing it, but let’s agree that it is contradictory to what has been the practice in Member States, with the cuts and austerity measures.

I believe that sustainable innovation only occurs if there are rigorous, sustainable, and demanding public policies. If it's merely a fleeting spark, little remains and we have few answers to give these populations. Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, we welcome the Commission's efforts to place research and innovation at the top of the political agenda.
We are presented with an integrated strategy to make the European innovation ecosystem more effective and productive in service of a sustainable economy.
European innovation partnerships emerge as an instrument, and the major challenges they address are sufficiently broad as to avoid controversy.
However, it is not yet clear how the sub-thematic priorities will be defined, nor how the preponderance of each discipline will be established within them.
What level of transparency will be expected for stakeholders to participate? How to arbitrate conflicting interests
What is the relative role of the Commission of the Member States of the Regions?
How to ensure accountability within a complex structure,
What financial dimension will these partnerships have?
The Commission and the Council, Mr. President, must ensure excellence in implementation, which is not guaranteed by the scant months of pilot testing foreseen for the first partnership.

which are demanded of them to access the market, a matter of elementary justice, and, furthermore, that they be compensated to the exact measure of the harm caused to them.

Or, if that is not the case, then at the very least, there should be the decency to tell them plainly that they will have to change their lives and seek another occupation, because it is certain that under the conditions that are anticipated for the future, they will not be able to survive and will have to abandon their activity.

This report provides a very positive indication when it highlights the manner in which we respond to this level in the plan and local sphere, responding concretely to local needs.
We are in a period in which we debate and will continue to debate a range of legislative proposals in the field of energy, and we often tend to
to focus excessively on large projects, on large networks, and to forget other scales of intervention where it is absolutely fundamental to intervene.

And that is why I believe this report can help us invest not only in energy efficiency and renewable energies, which is very important, but also in bringing tangible benefits to local populations, which naturally translates into tangible benefits for the European population as a whole.

And that is why I want to conclude, Mr. President, with two final points. It is important not to forget that energy efficiency is rarely achieved significantly through energy reduction within microeconomic projects.

Dear President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner Dali, the patient must have the right to know as much as possible about their illness and what medications are available to treat it.
But how to distinguish information from advertising?
Where and how to gather objective and unbiased information?
There exist different interpretations of the current texts. It is necessary to harmonize them, striving to reinforce the citizen's sovereignty.
The information must be reliable, validated by authorities, independent, accessible, and geared towards a general, non-specialist audience.
The aim is to foster a more informed and responsible citizenship on the part of the end-user.
The deadline given to the European Agency for tacit approval should be extended from 60 to 120 days.
The requirement for justification of intervention reinforces the adversarial process and balances the final outcome.
The EMEA has an essential role as a privileged source of objective information.

And I would like to conclude by greeting Rapporteur Fielner for the work he has done and congratulating myself on the fact that he accepted almost the entirety of the proposals I presented in the Internal Market Committee as rapporteur. Thank you.

The life of a worker bee is very short, approximately six weeks, and highly susceptible to external changes.

Therefore, honey production has also been affected, not only by the increasingly uncertain duration and stability of the seasons, but also by the increase in external aggressions that may result from the use of pesticides, mites, or other stressors.
