President, let us be clear, the solidarity mechanism for sovereign debt did not work, nor does it work. The price of Greek debt has not decreased, and Ireland is

The economic turmoil and contagion were not contained. The process that was created, belatedly created, is intergovernmental and should have existed in a different format from the very beginning of the euro’s creation.
The President of the Commission now proposes a consolidation of this system.
But in the third of the instruments proposed for use, he suggests involving private entities.
We had already heard that proposal to Chancellor Merkel, and it was as a consequence of that premature and inopportune announcement that the markets surged.
Parliament will fully utilize its powers and with the utmost responsibility and spirit of cooperation in the co-decision process accompanying the legislative package.
legislative action on economic governance, but not by sacrificing haste, speed, or placing quality second.

Therefore, let us be clear: Parliament will participate actively, but a matter as serious as the resolution of sovereign debt cannot be decided at the margins and without the consent of European citizens and their representatives. The two elements are intrinsically linked.
Finally, we Europeans need a clear European vision at this moment of crisis.

A European mechanism for sovereign debt consolidation is needed. The issuance of eurobonds is needed, and the euro area must be sustainably protected through European, rather than intergovernmental, systems.

It is necessary to reinforce the European budget. We cannot continue with 1% of the European budget level, and it is necessary to place real growth and convergence at the center of European political priorities.
It is this agenda that the Commission and the new President must defend.
And the President of the Commission cannot be an emanation of the Ecofin Council.
This is what we need to present to European citizens.
Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, I naturally wish to state that the EPP’s position is clear. It is a position in the sense that
that the resolution of this crisis, this grave crisis facing Europe and the European Union, can only be achieved through a deepening of economic governance and the Community method.

For us, there is no doubt whatsoever that only with greater community method, only with an economic government, only with the specific instruments of a true, single currency within the euro zone, is it possible to confront and address this crisis.
But this means that each of the institutions—the Council, the Commission, and the Parliament—accept responsibility before European citizens.
It needs to be stated that it is clear, at the very least, that the largest groups in the European Parliament are willing to cooperate manifestly in order to increase
the community method of introducing economic governance, of giving the single currency the necessary conditions to triumph within the European crisis context.

It is also evident today that the same holds true for the Commission and the President of the Commission, who, contrary to what socialists and Deputy Elisa Ferreira claim, have demonstrated that they are neither an emanation of the Council nor an emanation of Parliament, but an emanation of European interest.
It remains for the Council, now in December, to assume its responsibilities.
It is with this that we count, and with your evident adherence to the European ideal, President Wanderlund.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to begin by congratulating colleagues Luan and Manescu on the remarkable work they have developed in their respective reports.
Both constitute an important contribution to the ongoing discussion concerning the new cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period.
Today, more than ever, the achievement of economic, social, and territorial cohesion is essential for affirming the competitiveness of the European Union on a global scale.
This goal will only be achieved if we are aware that only by reinforcing and developing the regional dimension can we have a cohesive Europe internally and a competitive one externally.

In this regard, I would highlight three points that I consider crucial. Firstly, decentralization, ensuring that local and regional authorities, particularly those with legislative powers, participate more and contribute to a better implementation of the cohesion policy.

Member States should invite regional and local authorities to participate in negotiations on the future of structural funds, on an equal footing with national authorities and representatives. And finally, the strengthening of the role of regional authorities in the preparation, management, and implementation of programmes.
Only in this way, with the greatest involvement of these authorities throughout the process, will the principle of subsidiarity be fulfilled.

Another aspect that I consider crucial is the request for a simpler architecture for the post-2013 funds, not as a consequence of the economic crisis, but rather as a general principle of the future cohesion policy, in order to facilitate the absorption of the funds.
The central concern underlying the Treaty of Lisbon was to bring Europe closer to its citizens.
Let us then not only do that, but also make your life easier, avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens that discourage your participation.
Only in this way will we be able to realize the objective of genuine territorial cohesion.
Only in this way will we see disparities within the European Union reduced, disparities that are currently markedly contrasting and with a significant gap between rich and poor regions.

Greater participation also means greater responsibility. And it is this responsibility that should be assumed and shared by all, doing more and better so as to have a stronger and more competitive Europe.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, I would begin by congratulating colleagues Edith Bauer and Anne Edd on the excellent work developed in this report.
Human trafficking dishonors our society and demands a strong and coordinated response from all.
Organized crime underpinning sexual exploitation, forced labor, the trafficking of human organs, and other deplorable practices must be effectively combatted, but primarily prevented.
What is at stake is the defense of human rights and the protection of the most vulnerable people, particularly women and children.
The experience demonstrated that the current legal framework was not sufficiently effective and that the European Union must exert greater effort.
It is essential to have greater cross-border cooperation, including effective sharing of information and best practices.
It is noteworthy in this proposal, and rightly so, an approach centered on the victim.
Policies in this area should encompass aspects related to social issues and social inclusion, such as the social rehabilitation of the victim. Thank you very much.
The NATO Summit took place in Lisbon, and therefore, allow me to say a few words about what happened in my country in connection with this summit.

At that time, Portuguese authorities prohibited the entry into the country of European citizens for a single reason. It was because these citizens were carrying with them critical texts concerning the Alliance.
In those days, the least we can say is that an arbitrary regime prevailed in Portugal, a veritable police of thought.
A regime so unique that it led the Portuguese government to purchase riot control equipment valued at 5 million euros, which did not even arrive in time for the summit.
And these are the priorities, after all, of a Government facing a significant social crisis.
In the Europe we dream of, freedom of expression is a fundamental value.
The Europe we dream of does not bow before military organizations that write their history with blood.
The NATO summit resulted in the legitimization of its military intervention throughout the world.
There has also been a subordination of the European Union to the military strategy and interests of the United States.
Thirdly, the militarization of access to energy sources became established.
Lastly, the military defense of a development model that generates environmental imbalances and disrupts the social crisis was established.
Therefore, Madam President, I want to say that, in my opinion, with this summit, we have lost ground in democracy, we have lost freedoms, and we have lost out so that some may profit from war.

I now yield the floor to Mr. Rangel, you have a minute and a half. Thank you, Mr. President. The first point I wished to make clear here, and which it is important to reinforce in this Parliament, is that…
that, contrary to what is sometimes read in the press and in statements by some European leaders, the euro, as a currency, has been fundamental in responding to the current crisis.

Without the euro, we would be in a very difficult situation, with the currencies of the most vulnerable countries experiencing an enormous devaluation and with a potential German mark appreciating to an impossible level, unable to sustain the German economy and the European economy.

And for this reason, the euro has been a factor of stability, especially not only for the countries that are in the euro zone, but also for the currencies of the countries that did not wish to join the euro zone.

And precisely because we must defend this community that has managed to respond to the crisis better than any other and as, indeed, we will see in the future, for example, what will happen to the dollar and the United States of America, we will see how the euro has, in fact, advantages…

We now have the responsibility within this Council to do everything to defend the Euro. To establish, specifically, a stabilization fund that follows the Community method and is capable of introducing responsibility in countries.

countries that are in the most vulnerable situation and solidarity with those that have fulfilled their obligations and which have not always shown, at least in their external declarations, willingness to be supportive in the context of Zone E.

I wish to offer my sincere congratulations to my colleague Sorbu on the excellence of the report produced, strongly advising that the Commission take it into account, especially in those aspects where the complex dimension of agricultural issues significantly exceeds the strictly delimited scope of the

agriculture require the involvement of other areas, such as competition, the internal market, and financial regulation, as well as others, also requiring their treatment on other extra-community stages, such as the G20 or the WTO.

The issues absolutely determining the fate of agriculture, farmers, and the provision of sufficient food in quantity and quality to the populations of Europe and the world can only truly be addressed if they are faced within all their dimensions.

And the ambitious objectives of the CAP reform can only be achieved if the reform transcends the strict borders of agriculture and its objectives are also taken into account in the necessary interventions of other policy areas and in other global-reaching organizations.
This report made things very clear, and I commend it for that.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, and dear colleagues. I want to begin by thanking you all for the words spoken here regarding the report that Parliament is presenting on Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias.
We are all aware that the situation we are experiencing is substantially dramatic and remains significantly underdiagnosed, as was stated here.
And I simply want to refer to a question that was transversal to all the interventions, but likely not so emphasized, which is the question of the dignity of patients, of their rights.
And not only of the patients, but also of their families and those who care for them, whether formal or informal caregivers, and the professionals associated with this type of illness.

I am pleased, frankly pleased, with the Commissioner's words when he states that he shares the same concerns as the European Parliament and that the European Commission views all the recommendations of the report presented by Parliament very positively and will do everything within its power to implement them.
We know that each day that passes is later than the last in this matter of the urgency of what we have in hand.
Therefore, we also know that tomorrow Parliament will pronounce itself on this matter.
We will await the result of the vote, but we know, Mr. Commissioner, that European citizens expect much more from us than solidarity and moral comfort.

They expect concrete and appropriate actions from us. I sincerely hope, Mr. Commissioner, that you will implement them, and that the Commission, which has initiative—an initiative this Parliament unfortunately lacks—will put them into practice.

all this priority that you give to this domain and that transforms it into legislative initiative, so that citizens and their families see their rights respected and are treated with equality and the dignity they deserve. Thank you very much.

Firstly, I would like to say that this Parliament, on a day when we are discussing the Hungarian presidency, without prejudice to being able to address all the topics it wishes, should focus on the problems of the European Union, something that it is not doing here.

And to focus on the problems of the European Union, one should read carefully and discuss here whether or not one agrees with the priorities of the Hungarian presidency, rather than discussing points.
or aspects that are aspects of Hungary's internal life and that, at most, could be regulated in a healthy and normal relationship between the European Commission and the Hungarian Parliament.

I wanted, therefore, to say here that, beyond the priority that, naturally, the Hungarian Presidency will give to the economic and financial issues on the agenda, I see with great satisfaction that it is...
The Hungarian agenda for this semester is remarkably clear and ambitious, focusing and prioritizing three subjects that will be essential for the future of Europe.

Food, which is entering a serious global crisis, energy, which is essential for our security and our economic sustainability, and water, which has been little discussed but will be the next challenge for Europeans, following food.
I hope you achieve your goals.

Thank you, Madam President. I believe that these two countries, like others in this region, show us how, in recent years, European leaders have often sided with business interests rather than democracy, with dictators rather than the poor.
I am frankly concerned about the situation currently unfolding in Egypt and today's developments. It is therefore my understanding that we should not be calm, but rather demonstrate solidarity.
solidarity with the millions of Egyptian citizens who are in Cairo and throughout the country, fed up with hunger, fed up with oppression, fed up with unemployment.

And that is why, after today’s Mubarak speech, after the regime’s hounds have been released, after a clear and unobstructed path to violence has been created, we must say that we need to stand with these people.
We cannot allow a strategy of fear to be created so that they return home.
Thirty-six years ago in Portugal, we would have returned home had we heeded that advice.
It is well that we returned, for thereby we had a democratic revolution.

either a deception or a false promise, as you wish to call it, because we have been operating, particularly regarding the collection of terminal cells from umbilical cords, based on misleading information.
And we know, as has been mentioned, that in Europe, the collection of stem cells from umbilical cord blood does not reach 1%.

Yet, we also know that its possibilities for the treatment of diseases may be inexhaustible. Diseases such as those already mentioned, cancer, Alzheimer's disease, and rare diseases, present immense possibilities.

But what we allowed to happen was the establishment of a set of private cell preservation banks, telling parents that they could store their children’s cells and, at the time of birth, cure them in the future, if necessary.
I believe we should be more responsible than that because the probability of ensuring that happens is very low, as we know.
And this false promise that is sold to parents costs money.
In Portugal, for example, this false premise costs three and a half minimum wages.
The solution clearly involves creating public stem cell banks. Because only with public banks can we guarantee equitable utilization and equal access.

and effective medical treatment, alongside further research that is equitable for all, and not solely utilizing metaplasmic cells as commodities or a burgeoning business—a business that benefits only a select few.
Therefore, I believe solidarity, common sense, and impartial information are, in the end, not things that can be classified as excessive requirements.
We do not have the power to impose, we have the power to promote.
This falls within our competencies. I believe we should do this in the name of equality. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. The price of food has reached a historic high and this is the 7th consecutive time it has increased.
And there are several factors that can explain this increase, the first being a short-term factor,
has to do with the coincidence of adverse weather conditions in some countries, such as Russia and Argentina.
But there are two factors that are foundational, that are of a structuring order, and that is why I bring these two factors here.
The first relates to the fact that some food producers and consumers who were exporters have become importers, as is the case with China.
And the second concerns the fact that the weight of some large multinationals can manipulate prices to their advantage.
And the example of cereals is this very clear level. It is dominated by six large multinationals.
This situation thus places farmers in immense uncertainty regarding food prices.
Europe must, therefore, return to doing what it ceased to do some time ago, namely, protecting its producers and consumers.
In a world where everyone resorts to forms of protection and where multinationals manipulate expressions, we cannot continue to be naive. Thank you very much.
I congratulate my colleague, rapporteur Marisa Matias, and extend my greetings to all those who collaborated with her.
Regrettably, over the past several years, we have witnessed an increase in the counterfeiting of pharmaceuticals in Europe.
According to data from the European Union, one and a half million boxes of counterfeit medicines are sold annually through the legal supply chain.
This is a criminal activity that represents a serious threat to European patients and to the European industry.
The objective of this Directive is to prevent the introduction of falsified medicinal products into the supply chain and, thereby, to protect public health.

I would like to highlight, in the opinion I prepared, the following key points. The introduction of the definition of counterfeit medicine, clearly emphasizing consumer protection, the application of secondary devices,

to the security of prescription medicines, the accountability of all stakeholders in the distribution chain, and finally, the application by Member States of effective sanctions to deter this criminal activity.
Mr. President, I obviously want to thank all the comments that were made by all colleagues.
I will not comment on them individually; that is not the intention.
I believe that if there were any doubts about what the word commitment means, it has become very clear here what it means.

We do not all have the perfect proposal, but far more important than knowing whether it is the perfect proposal is knowing that we have an instrument in our hands that will allow us to no longer delay the protection of patients’ health.
And we have the obligation not to delay its adaptation either, we have the obligation not to delay real action, and we can only do this together.
I must also say personally, and the Commissioner mentioned the issue of inspections, that in my initial proposal I presented an amendment for mandatory inspections in third countries.
The commitment is precisely that, and yet, one gains in some things, loses in others.
We were informed by the Commission that obtaining that would be impossible.
I would also like to add another note regarding this commitment.
I believe we all see ourselves in the commitment, but I also think and am aware that we will all be demanding that it be fulfilled, because otherwise it will not be effective.

This commitment ensures safeguards so that we can monitor the process, assess it, and systematically obtain information that allows us to verify whether it is being implemented or not, properly or improperly, and if adjustments are necessary.

I would therefore like to conclude by thanking the European Commission for its collaboration, and in particular, the Spanish and Belgian Presidencies, with whom we have worked together over the past six months.
There are no perfect proposals, no perfect interventions; there are failures, but I believe we have a strong and robust commitment to allow us to combat and defend the health of patients.
And as my intervention is also full of shortcomings, I failed to thank colleagues Regina Bastos and Amália Sartori, from the partners of the other commissions,
Thank you very much for your support as well.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, it is hardly necessary to reiterate that the current moment represents the most serious test of the euro's survival, and therefore, of Europe's.
The Polimata report opens constructive solutions, and for that reason, I also want to congratulate our colleague Pelas Ideias Clansa.

The gravity of the moment does not stem from the euro zone as a whole having an excessive deficit or external debt. Rather, it results from the persistent and serious divergence of the economies that comprise it under the impact of the common policy.
We lack instruments that allow for the convergence between these economies, that allow Europe to regain balance, that allow Europe to grow.
Let us be clear, the euro zone and the European Union cannot survive with the current level of integration and the diversity of the economies they comprise, with a budget of 1% of collective wealth.
In practice, after the crisis, the only solution we were able to construct was the recipe of austerity. And it is the workers and the companies who pay today.
the deficits generated by the speculative crisis in the financial sector, in whose rescue 26% of the wealth of the European Union was committed.
The financial transaction tax, levied at a very low rate—for example, 0.05% on transactions of high-risk, highly speculative products—is indeed to be paid by its consumers.
But why should they not pay, if common citizens pay VAT on bread, on milk, and on the most basic products?
The tax burden must be redistributed to affect workers and businesses less and to be shared more equitably by the financial sectors, particularly those engaged in speculative activities.
And, Mr. Commissioner, I believe it is not incumbent upon the Commission at this moment to reject or shy away from the clear message that this Parliament is politically delivering to it.
The public consultation cannot exclude the analysis of the financial transactions tax; on the contrary, it should be analyzed with the highest priority.
We are well aware of what happened with the A influenza pandemic, and that should serve as a lesson for us all.
And I don't know if you all remember well how all of this began, but the truth is that it began in one way and then the response was completely disproportionate to the scale of the problem.
That is why the report voted on here today is so important, because we must learn from what was done so that what was done is not repeated.
We have the right to know who made the decisions, how the whole story unfolded, and who decided for it to have happened that way.
We have the right to know which countries responded in a certain way, why they responded without transparency, and without allowing us to stay.
With minimal doubt, because we have maintained all doubts as to whether or not a deal occurred. We must ensure that no residue remains whether or not a deal related to this influenza occurred.
That is why I understand, Madam President, that all threats to public health must be confronted, but it is not irrelevant how they are confronted, nor who pays for them.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. We are here discussing proposals concerning salaries and proposals concerning the retirement age, and the least we can say in relation to these proposals is that they are frankly unfair.
they are unfair and insist on recipes that have already been proven failed more than once—recipes that have already proven unsuccessful on multiple occasions.

What is happening in Ireland, Greece, Portugal, Spain, Italy, and God knows how many more countries, because this is an endless pattern, are different situations in each of these countries, but there are some commonalities.
One of the things we have in common is a previously unprecedented transfer of value from labor to financial capital.
We cannot accept this.
The other thing we have in common is that those paying for this crisis are workers and retirees and pensioners, and also an entire generation of precarious individuals who

There is no guarantee in the society in which we live. And it is for this reason that I would like to conclude by saying, Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner, that we cannot continue to condemn people to poverty.
I sincerely hope...
Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by saying that I fully support what my colleague has said.

The prevention of natural and human-induced disasters is of enormous and growing importance, and the European Commission systematically presents us with a number of procedural intentions and timelines.
But there is a very complex problem, as has already been mentioned.
The Solidarity Fund is an instrument that typically responds to these situations, but responds in a very, very protracted timeframe, nine months to a year, and this after the catastrophe.
As has already been mentioned, and I repeat, and we will repeat as often as necessary, there is the case of Madeira. It suffered a massive catastrophe a year ago and has yet to receive any support.
And I ask this, and I reiterate this question, wouldn't it be appropriate for the Commission to undertake a review of the fund’s procedure and the financing model itself at this time?
How can we maintain an exceptional fund to deal with situations that are increasingly chronic?
We do not know where it will happen, but we know that it will happen, and climate change is there to prove it.
Therefore, an exception can never respond to a situation of regularity. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, the concerns raised here regarding disaster prevention and response are a matter of great sensitivity and of the utmost importance to our populations, and should not nor can it be postponed.

We are discussing very sensitive situations, those that affect the safety of individuals and their possessions, which often move us all emotionally due to the loss of lives, the devastation of families, and the ruin of entire working lives.

But all our expressions are of little value when faced with the dramas that, through media, impress and sensitize everyone, if afterward we fall asleep on the work we must do to ensure those situations can be avoided, minimized, or, better still, assisted.
Mr. Commissioner, the matter here, very well focused by my colleagues,

It is an area where the European Union can best demonstrate its presence alongside its citizens, assisting them in disaster prevention, particularly when these events occur, and standing by them during the moments they need it most and are most vulnerable.
I will gladly respond, although I did not wish to transform a debate in the European Parliament into a debate about Portuguese politics.

Incidentally, if Deputy Edith Estrela wishes to debate Portuguese policy, she has a simple solution. We should hold elections, have candidates for the Portuguese Parliament, and have the opportunity, in the opposition, to debate with the PSD government the policies it intends for Portugal.
I say only this: we can no longer endure a government that has failed four times over two years.
It is impossible, it is unsustainable, it is not credible to the markets, there are no further solutions with the socialist government.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr. Schwab on the negotiating persistence that led to this important agreement, and I also commend all those who collaborated with him on this report.

We seek not only to ensure a high level of protection for European consumers, but also that European companies, whatever their size, can supply goods and services to consumers in the 27 Member States, without unnecessary legal obstacles.

This new directive will end the legislative fragmentation that has been harming the participation of our companies in the cross-border market and will provide a significant boost to the internal market.
I highlight the new provisions regarding information to be provided to the consumer, requiring that this information be clear, intelligible, and furnished in a timely manner.
It is also important that the burden of proof, regarding the compliance with information requirements, now falls on the merchant.

Regarding contracts concluded at a distance, particularly contracts finalized by telephone or over the internet, their rules should be defined and the consumer protected by simple and effective mechanisms.

We are certain that at the end of the institutional negotiations, the new directive will contribute to making the European Union more competitive and dynamic, as is required in a global economy. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. Council President, and Mr. Commission President. Firstly, I would naturally like to congratulate you on the results of the Council of 24 and 25 March, notably the consolidation of the semester.

European, but, more than that, whether through the institutionalization of the European Stability Mechanism, or through the focus, let's say, of the Euro Plus Pact, which already stemmed from the Eurozone Summit of March 11th.
I believe these are very positive results for Europe, and it’s regrettable that this process wasn’t fully concluded on March 24th and 25th.
I believe that if we had given that signal, if the States had given that signal in the Council, completely closing this package of reforms to the fund, we would be in a position today

stronger to face the three, four months. And, in part, we would have attenuated the effects of the crisis that my country, Portugal, is currently experiencing, and on which I also do not want to fail to offer a word.
to say that, in the case of the PSD, fully integrated into the PPE, there is absolute and total willingness to fulfill the requirements and obligations of integration within the European space.
That is what we have been doing, even now, at this moment, when there are difficulties regarding short-term financing.
Unlike what the Socialist Government has done, the Social Democratic Party has demonstrated a complete willingness to give Europe the assurances needed within the context of this crisis.

And with this, I want to give this signal, without bringing domestic politics into the European Parliament, of commitment, of the total guarantee of the Social Democratic Party to the rigorous agenda that the country will have to have after its elections on June 5th.
Thank you very much, Madam President, esteemed colleagues, Mr. Commissioner Stefan Fuller. The historic moment we are living through demands firm and determined action.
As many of you, we observe the unfolding events in the Mediterranean Basin with a mixture of hope, concern, and anticipation.

I am, however, satisfied with the proactive position that the Parliament is preparing to adopt with regard to the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy South, which I hope will lead to a greater presence of the Union in this zone, not only as a payer, but equally as a committed partner.
From the outset by affirming the absolute necessity of defending our founding values in relations with neighboring countries.
We can no longer compromise on the defense of democracy, nor on the defense of human rights, and even less so, on the defense of social justice.

We can no longer prioritize short-term stability at the expense of the superior interests of citizens and their uncompromising defense, their individual and collective freedom, with particular attention to the rights of women.
In the future, the Union must prioritize a bottom-up approach in its neighbourhood policy.
It is essential that this occur.
Only the greatest involvement of local communities and civil society will guarantee maximum effectiveness in its implementation.

But I cannot help but express a frustration. I regret that this Parliament and the Commission do not wish to seize this opportunity to definitively differentiate the Eastern Neighborhood policy from the policy concerning countries that potentially may become, in the future, our partners within the Union, and the Southern Neighborhood policy.
I also challenge the Commission to demonstrate, in its review process of April 20th, the ambition that the current moment demands—a neighborhood policy.
tailor-made to each State, with clearer assets and a careful evaluation that will allow progress towards a future Mediterranean economic space with the Southern democracies.

To conclude, Mr. Commissioner, we trust that the positive atmosphere and cooperation which have characterised the work on this topic will lead to the permanent involvement of the European Parliament in the planning and evaluation of this policy. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. The reports we have discussed and which the rapporteurs—whom I congratulate—reinforce a set of initiatives that aim to revitalize the internal market.
I would like to highlight the commitment of the European Commission, in particular that of Mr. Commissioner Barnier, whom I welcome, and the positive reception of this Parliament through the
Committee on the Protection of Consumers and the Internal Market, to prioritise competitiveness and market dynamism, a fundamental pillar of the 2020 Strategy.
Citizens and businesses expect effective stimulus measures for Europe to regain economic growth, anticipate increased employment, and aspire to the creation of greater prosperity.

As the Commissioner highlighted, opening markets to our companies, eliminating obstacles and difficulties, will provide a very special boost and an unparalleled opportunity that will allow them to continue their mission as a driving force of our economy.

The measures aimed at reducing the administrative and bureaucratic burden on SMEs and their access to credit and the services market, the European patent, and the recognition of qualifications are essential.
The relevance of developing e-commerce to strengthen consumer and business confidence in this type of commerce, the investment in innovation.
important for strong and sustainable growth. Social entrepreneurship is indispensable for creating innovative business projects for social inclusion.
These are some measures that will ensure this ambitious project of completing, deepening, and fully harnessing the single market for the benefit of European citizens.
Finally, the important recommendation is for Member States to redouble their efforts to improve the transposition and implementation of the internal market rules. Thank you very much.
I also wish to add my voice to those who have expressed concerns here regarding the low incomes of fishermen, exacerbated by historically high fuel prices, particularly in recent months.
As has been very well stated here, fuel costs have a very high impact on the survival of our small and medium-sized shipowners, particularly exacerbating the already precarious incomes of fishing.
This momentous rise in prices is also bringing us profound negative effects. Reduced outings to sea, meager incomes for fishermen, exacerbated by the low prices paid at the initial sale,

increases in imports of aquaculture and fisheries products from third countries to the European market and a consequent abandonment of the activity due to financial difficulties, such as the loss of jobs.
In this context, to prevent the continuation of the crisis's worsening, it is necessary to act, and to act with solidarity and with depth regarding the problems of fishing.

The Commission must, therefore, provide positive responses with measures of both short and long term to address the adversities facing the sector and the severe income losses being experienced by our fishermen.
First, I would like to congratulate, in particular, the work of our PPE colleague, Mário David, whom I represent here today as he is absolutely informed.
unable to attend this plenary session and wished to state that we have always considered support for the victims of the floods in Pakistan to be an ethical and moral imperative.
And for this reason, we strongly support all measures that have been taken toward traditional humanitarian assistance.
We even consider that work should continue in order to help stabilize the situation of so many millions of affected people.
What we cannot accept is that the European Union’s trade policy is now considered a suitable instrument for humanitarian aid.

The truth is that this brings two nefarious consequences. One consequence within the European Union, especially for the Southern countries and for their textile-clothing industry, today highly weakened by an economic, social, and financial crisis without precedent since the

And secondly, at a global level, in the WTO negotiations, where this opening of the world’s largest trading bloc, which is the European Union, to potential Pakistani exports, could completely disrupt the WTO negotiations.
It is no accident that they find themselves in the impasse in which they find themselves.

It is, therefore, natural that, faced with a situation like this, we have to say, concerning the history of this Regulation and the difficulty it experienced during these eight months of intense negotiations for the

which we collaborate on the most constructive proposals, we will now, unfortunately, have to take a position—a position in the sense of supporting the amendment that, essentially, foresees the end of this proposed regulation as we know it.
We will have to do this now, not for any lesser solidarity with Pakistan, but because we believe that humanitarian aid should be given in the appropriate place and in the appropriate manner.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to begin by saying that, naturally, I believe that the agreement reached for Portugal is a balanced agreement.
It is a very tough agreement for the populations, but one that places its fundamental point on structural reforms to increase growth and competitiveness.
And I believe that is very positive.

I do not adopt the stance of those who believe that countries like Greece, Ireland, and Portugal did everything correctly, made no errors, overextended themselves in no way, and acted appropriately, with the international crisis being solely responsible for the problems.

No. Our governments erred and had flawed policies. But that does not mean there isn't now an opportunity within the context of the Union to have the possibility of returning to the right path and the correct course.

And for this reason, it is important to remember here that, in fact, it is necessary to tell public opinions opposed to supporting countries in difficulty that they are not giving money to those countries, they are merely lending money to those countries.
but they are lending them at very high interest rates and, therefore, are making a deal that is positive for their budgets and for their populations.

But I also say here that perhaps it is time to have a global European response with the admission of eurobonds, with the admission of the possibility of selling in the primary market to respond to international markets.

It would perhaps be the opportune moment for the European Commission, the Fund, and the IMF to review interest rates, in order to provide the possibility of, by lowering those rates, achieving sustained growth for these countries currently facing difficulties.

Thank you. I yield the floor for a minute to Mr. Correia de Campos. Many thanks, Mr. President, Commissioner, and Rapporteur. This strategy is important for all European countries, especially those whose economy lacks greater competitiveness.
It is essential for the creation of small and medium-sized enterprises.
Today, the creation of new jobs is more active.
It is essential for universities and laboratories whose relationship with productive sectors depends on part of their survival.
It is essential for the financial system, which will find in innovation a new market, as the classic manufacturing model runs its course.

Innovation is at the top of the European agenda and, being a pillar of the EU 2020 strategy, must be supported by new financial instruments to prevent it from succumbing to budgetary constraints arising from the current situation.
I would finally like to commend Judite Merckes for her significant contribution to a more innovative Europe with a knowledge-based economy. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the colleague, Mr. Odi, on his excellent report.

The interim assessment, although belated, allowed for the highlighting of critical aspects of the seventh program. Its excessive bureaucracy, the industry's disinterest, the number and complexity of the new instruments, the slow pace of disbursements,
There remains a greater risk of diverted allocations of funds from the current program framework to large-scale programs of questionable added value.

but also allowed for highlighting positive aspects, greater articulation and international cooperation among scientific groups in common projects, some success stories, including the European Research Council, and a greater gender balance.
There are priorities that must be developed. First, simplification. Second, promoting scientific excellence, not in some countries, but across Europe. A stronger link of

framework program with innovation, with instruments directed at small and medium-sized enterprises and entrepreneurship, the most successful of which is the Eurostars program, which should be expanded. Thank you, sir.

Madam President, Commissioner, I address the proposal you presented here today to Parliament directly, and I tell you with utmost candor that I believe some of us—men and women—have the right to be disappointed with this proposal, because the proposal presented is not only weak but also contains countless shortcomings.
I believe this is a European issue; it is not a question of the States that have nuclear industry and those that do not, but of the entirety of Europe, and Europe desperately needs good news.
And I must sincerely tell you that one of the good news items is assuring citizens that we are taking care of their safety.
Now, when these tests are conducted as the Commissioner presents, that is, a first phase is carried out by the parties involved, and a second phase is carried out by the Member States that

These interests are defended by those involved, and a third phase is carried out by peers who are genuinely interested. I wonder if the outcome won’t be to say, in the end, that all nuclear power plants are in very good health and are recommended.

We know that is not the case, and for that reason, I sincerely hope there will be serious consequences and that we can tell our citizens that we are taking care of their safety, and not merely pretending to do so. Thank you very much.
I expect this European Council, especially given the climate experienced in recent weeks, to make a decision of great responsibility.
It is of greater responsibility than that which existed in the last Council, in which an attempt was made to postpone a problem for three months solely due to electoral calendars.

I hope that this decision, fundamentally, will demonstrate that economic and financial matters are crucial and decisive for Europe, but that economic and financial matters are instrumental to Europe’s principal purpose, which is to maintain peace.
If an approach is taken to the problems that merely and solely leads to States beginning to distrust one another, to instilling distrust among the different States,
To create and inflame differences and rivalries between Southern and Northern states, between central and peripheral states. What we will be led to is the decline of the European Union.

I believe that what is at stake in this European Council, regardless of technical solutions, regardless of political disagreements, is to determine whether we do or do not want the European project to continue as a valid framework for peace in Europe.
I assure you that this is what is at stake.
What I observe in many discourses of leaders, both those from countries in difficulty and those from countries that are economic contributors,
contributors, it is an irresponsible discourse, which often even appeals to certain characteristics of nationalities that are extremely negative.
I appeal for this and nothing more, based on the responsibility of European government leaders to find solutions that lead Europe to an exit and a resolution.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner. My first words are to commend the work done by the rapporteur, my colleague Jorge Sravacakis, who has done an extraordinary job in identifying future synergies for enhanced effectiveness between the various structural funds.

Your report also fits within this joint debate on cohesion policy, a debate that assumes the greatest importance, not only due to the substance of the topic but also, and above all, due to the timeliness of its discussion.
Indeed, we are currently poised to learn the Commission’s proposal, not only regarding new financial perspectives, but also concerning the future cohesion policy post-2013.
Cohesion policy is a fundamental policy for the European Union.

It is a horizontal policy that, through its quintessential instruments, the structural funds, finances projects and programs in Member States, seeking to reduce disparities between the levels of development of the various regions.
However, experience has shown us the difficulties in terms of efficiency and results stemming from the fragmentation and complexity of this policy.

Establishing a single strategic framework for the various funds, with an integrated and results-oriented approach, is the starting point for greater and improved synergies among the different instruments and for strengthening their effectiveness.
It is also essential for improved coordination between various sectorial policies and for greater efficiency in the allocation of resources.
We must leverage the danger of crisis to seek new alternatives.

It is true that all these reports, which are being discussed today, will pose enormous challenges for us. And that we know that to respond to these challenges, we also need a sound budget. But we must make a clear distinction between budgetary aspects and political objectives.
The political objectives are well known. And, indeed, it is only by asserting those political objectives that we can offer a future to the regions.

And if that is the case, then we must place the budget at the service of the future of the regions and the citizens, and not the citizens and the regions at the service of the budget. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Cohesion policy is the key policy for the future of the European project.
The construction of a common space, with an internal market and a single currency, requires a certain degree of convergence among its member states and regions in order to function.
Current disparities in competitiveness and development asymmetries have inevitably led to the weakening of the European space and the crisis affecting the Eurozone.
That is why this vital need for convergence absolutely requires a robust cohesion budget that cannot be weakened to finance other policies.
The European Union, to do more, must be more. And that is achieved by growing its budget and not reducing, even skillfully, the cohesion budget.

I ask the Commissioner this question regarding the creation of the Fund for Infrastructure and New Innovation Policies, which will be coordinated with cohesion and regional development—something I support—but which, without an increase in the Community budget, could not become the Trojan horse that is introduced into the cohesion budget.
The modernization and renewal of energy infrastructure are essential factors for the sustainable and intelligent growth objectives we seek with the 2020 Strategy and for our energy security needs.
It is essential to involve all regions in this challenge.

To this end, the incentives stipulated in regulatory frameworks should be improved, particularly those applicable to higher-risk projects and more innovative projects, such as those being developed on the islands of the Azores, in renewable energies.

Regions should be associated with the conceptualization and implementation phases of projects, in the definition of priorities, in their elaboration and execution, because this ensures better results and consequently, a stronger defense of European interests.

The current economic climate further emphasizes the need to adopt an innovative and integrated approach to energy issues, ensuring that all economic, environmental, and social aspects are taken into consideration.
It is essential not to lose sight of its medium- and long-term effects, seeking to ensure all European citizens have secure, sustainable, and reasonably priced energy.

The report we debated is of particular importance considering the influence that general interest social services have on the daily lives of European citizens, as well as on social cohesion, job creation, and economic growth.

Collaboration with the Rapporteur Próncias de Roça proved very fruitful and clarifying, as the Rapporteur himself just stated, enabling the adoption of several commitments within the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.
Based on the result we have here today and that we have debated, I commend and congratulate the rapporteur.
In truth, from our side, the principal concern was to make it clear that the competencies in this matter belong to the Member States.
National authorities are the holders of the competencies to define, organize, and finance general interest social services.
Thus, the creation of harmonizing legislation at the European level is unnecessary, given the highly diverse realities of these general interest social services in the 27 Member States.

It suffices to consider health services, social security, employment, and social housing—these are examples where proximity and knowledge of the contexts are the cornerstone of adequate and more equitable service delivery. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, as rapporteur for the REGI opinion on the future of social and international services, I wish to congratulate the colleague from Roça, highlighting the fact that we are dealing with an essential pillar of the social market economy model that we defend for Europe and in which the SIG plays a fundamental role in its cohesion.

Social cohesion at the European Union level advises against neglecting the existence of minimum levels of protection in all Member States, without prejudice to the respect for the competencies of their national, regional, and local authorities.

European regions have a very important role in delivering these services to the populations, and their opinion should be taken into account, given the specific nature of their constraints, to ensure their provision to the populations.

At a time of crisis such as the one we are currently experiencing, Social and Intensive General Services constitute a social protection network for the most disadvantaged or for those whose income does not allow them access to private services.

It is, therefore, important to ensure that Member States decentralizing powers do so with the corresponding financial resources so that regional and local authorities can effectively deliver services to the population.
Ms. Ashton, I begin by saying that it is obvious that we must continue to support the democratic revolutions that are occurring in these countries.
I don't have much time, and therefore I only want to leave a few notes.
First, we must not forget that the conditions for negotiation, bearing in mind a democratic transition and not civil war, must be defined by the peoples of these countries.
The situation in Syria is serious. This applies to Syria, but also to Yemen and Bahrain.

If we want to avoid civil war, the last thing these countries need is for Europe to interfere in their internal affairs, and especially, and very particularly, through the presentation of military or paramilitary solutions.
And if I say this, I say it because we must wholly repudiate what is happening in Libya.
NATO and the United Nations have superseded all resolutions, even those voted for by the United Nations Security Council.
It is this silence regarding Libya, this repudiation that we must make, and it is because it does not appear in this resolution that I cannot subscribe to it. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. Prime Minister. Firstly, I would naturally like to congratulate the Polish presidency on the ambitious program it has brought here and, in particular, congratulate them on…

neighborhood policy, not only to the east, but also on the southern border, where I believe a challenge is currently unfolding that is perhaps more demanding than the one we have to the east, which is more of a long-term and less of a short-term issue.

But, having said that, I would like to ask the Prime Minister and the Polish Presidency to pay special attention to economic integration policies, economic governance, and the supervision of financial markets.

I believe that at this moment, however ambitious our goals may be in the, let's say, area of energy defense, food security, the environment, agriculture, and multi-annual financial frameworks, if we do not

To resolve, in a clear and solid manner before global markets, the problem of the debt crisis within the European context, we will not have a Europe strong enough to address the challenges that the Polish presidency has set out.

And that is why I was emphasizing that it is fundamental to convince the remaining heads of state and heads of government that it is necessary to provide greater economic integration, more economic governance to the European Union.

Without it, what will happen is that we, instead of being the drivers or, at the very least, the representatives of our peoples, whether in the Council, in Parliament, or in the European Interest Committee, instead of being that, we will be merely…
Mr. President, as President of the MASHREC Delegation, I would like to offer a sentence about each of my, obviously, four countries.
Beginning with Syria and reiterating what some colleagues have already said, it is regrettable that, in the eyes of the public, the international community appears to apply double standards.

It is necessary to denounce, if required, the countries that, in the Security Council – and I am obviously referring to Russia and China, ultimately, beyond Brazil, but with veto power – have prevented the international community from adopting a more cohesive stance regarding the values that we share.
Regarding Egypt, there is an urgent need to raise awareness among Egyptian authorities concerning the postponement of elections, as was already done in Tunisia.
Regarding Lebanon, I believe it is essential that a very clear message emerges from this debate for the new Lebanese government.
so that they are aware that they will be judged based on their conduct in relation to the charges brought by the Special Tribunal for Lebanon.

Regarding Jordan, it serves as an example of how a peaceful transition is possible, and there may perhaps only be a need, at this stage, to raise awareness and encourage the authorities to accelerate the process of reforms.
We cannot forget, obviously, in a debate of this kind, the peace process in the Middle East. And to reiterate our hope that the meeting of the Quartet next Monday can
Indeed, to be productive, and to reaffirm that this House would certainly like to see a much greater involvement of the European Union throughout this process.

I have no doubts that there will be a new round of negotiations before the United Nations General Assembly in September. But I hope that this round of negotiations will be productive and conducted in good faith.
Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating the rapporteur and all those who contributed to achieving this work.
There is no doubt that this report constitutes and will constitute a reference point with regard to recommendations and robust, coordinated responses to the challenges of the crisis.
The conclusion that can be drawn is that the crisis we are experiencing will only be overcome with a deepening of European integration.

In a time of serious financial, economic, and social difficulties, and of painful austerity measures in some Member States, as in my country, Portugal, there is a temptation to seek refuge in a protectionist and nationalist attitude.
But that is an error.

The European response to the crisis requires a genuine European economic governance that pursues sustainable growth, promotes job creation, and develops the social market economy, providing long-term answers with defined objectives to which Member States can identify.
The strategy for exiting the crisis needs to be financed with a sufficiently ambitious community budget.
To avoid a new sovereign debt and euro crisis, closer coordination in budgetary policies is needed, as well as the creation of a system for issuing public debt securities and euro-bonds.
I conclude by emphasizing that during this difficult period, it is also necessary to maintain levels of social protection, especially for the most vulnerable citizens. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Presiding Authority, it is customary to say that crises help strengthen Europe.
Historically, that was the case, but today I am not so certain that this continues to be true.

The slow, improvised, reactive manner in which the Union is responding to the Greek crisis exacerbates the situation daily and spreads contagion and a disturbing lack of confidence in the Union and its currency.
This is despite the problems of the Eurozone resulting from obvious flaws in the construction of the single currency, which today are concentrated in its most fragile links.

For the current crisis to result in the strengthening of the Union, a strategic vision is needed, as was the case in the past, and which, unfortunately, neither the Commission nor the Council have been able to impart to the European program and project.
This report from Parliament, however, gives us this perspective. More Europe, not less, is the solution.
The Parliament recalls that the market and the single currency generate intolerable divergences between economies and that these must be counteracted by specific policies.

It recognizes that the functioning of the euro requires a reinforced European budget financed by own resources, requires a European agency for the joint issuance of debt capable of protecting Member States from market speculation.

and to provide them with credit at reasonable prices and terms. It also recognizes that diplomas and the transferability of workers between countries require mutual recognition of social rights and pensions.
Parliament has united to send clear messages. Let us hope the Commission and the Council heed them.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear rapporteur, firstly, I would naturally like to greet and congratulate the rapporteur for considering this report extremely useful and, indeed, enabling us to take new steps in the area of mediation.
The report presents an overview, a range of solutions adopted by the various Member States in the implementation, the application of
Directive 2008/52/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 May 2008, relating to mediation in civil and commercial matters.
Now, we all know the advantages of mediation.
On the one hand, this judicial resolution of conflicts contributes to the decongestion of courts, to the rationalization of the justice system, and simultaneously provides
providing the parties simultaneously with the possibility of obtaining a friendly, faster, and less costly solution, less burdensome than the dispute in which they were embroiled.

It is therefore essential to reaffirm the objective of Article 1 of the Directive when calling for the adoption of measures to encourage the use of, recourse to, alternative dispute resolution methods and, in particular, mediation.
Promoting access to and utilization of extrajudicial means of conflict resolution contributes to improving, simplifying, and making our justice system more accessible.

It is therefore a very important challenge for the European Union and for the establishment of the area of freedom, security and justice, I would say, for the idea of the rule of law within the European Union.
And it is for this reason that, within this context of crisis as well, I consider it very important that, as stated in the report, public opinion and industry professionals can be made aware.
judicial precedents on this matter and appeal to the Commission and to the Commissioner to swiftly present a legislative proposal on alternative dispute resolution.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I also want to highlight the fundamental importance of this report regarding the transparency of the European energy market.
And I simply want to say that this constitutes the central domain of cooperation in European terms if we safeguard some of the dimensions that are fundamental, among them avoiding that the
that liberalization transforms into increased energy prices for citizens, ensure equal access, and exercise caution regarding sanctions, as numerous colleagues have already mentioned.
And precisely because this is a central domain of European cooperation, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I cannot fail to mention and to question you and ask you directly, Mr. Commissioner,
I would like to give you the opportunity to explain regarding the recent statements you made concerning Greece, Ireland, and Portugal, as these are also matters of European cooperation.
Symbolic measures such as lowering flags to half-staff, Mr. Commissioner, serve only to reinforce the shame of citizens who are dignified and who fight for a Europe

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Chief Commissioner of Covites, Representatives of the Council, Polish Presidency. Firstly, I would like to clarify that I will be intervening here in a dual capacity. On the one hand, substituting the author of the Commission’s opinion on Matters of

constitutional my colleague Messer Schmidt, a Dane who is absent due to the ongoing election process in Denmark at this moment, and therefore I am representing him as a member of Africa, but also as a member of the Jury, as rapporteur shadow in the Jury of this report.

The first point I wanted to make is that, in the crisis we are facing—the economic and financial crisis—the question of intelligent regulation, of smart regulation, of better legislation, is a central one.

There is no doubt that, in the so-called structural reforms that can trigger economic and financial recovery within the European space, improvements in legislation and regulation are absolutely essential.

It is evident that a Europe which aspires, on one hand, to be dynamic and competitive, must have regulation that is simple and accessible to businesses and, obviously, to citizens. And therefore, it must be oriented towards their needs.
The truth is that, in this sense, it is essential today that, firstly, the program of reducing administrative burdens be achieved, and that all efforts be made in the direction of
to conduct consultations with market agents, representative citizens' and businesses' associations, and to assess the impact of the legislation itself, that is also extremely important, so that the

the decision-making process could essentially be based, let's say, precisely on the opinion of those who are the recipients of the legislation and could be carried out without administrative burdens and with fewer economic and financial costs.

It is important to note that, for the Commission on Constitutional Affairs in particular, the idea of the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity is relevant, this idea that European intervention should be an appropriate intervention and not one that promotes the complexity of the legal system.

And for that reason, we have given special attention, in our opinion, to the reinforced role that National Parliaments have in this dynamic, precisely due to the principle of proportionality and the principle of subsidiarity.

It is therefore essential that, at the level of Smart Regulation and at the level of legislative improvement, we now involve the National Parliaments. So that, whether at the European level or the national level, both legislation and regulation

Let us be more agile, more intelligent, more efficient. And therefore, this is a good moment to put into practice what we announce every day: a more competitive Europe and a more agile Europe through more intelligent regulation.
Mr. President, the number of homeless people, as well as those living below the poverty line, has continued to increase in recent years in several Member States.
The economic, financial, and social crisis, along with the rise in unemployment, has exacerbated this problem, as everyone has already diagnosed.
We all also agree that this phenomenon is a negation of important values of the European Union, respect for human dignity and respect for fundamental rights.

In my country, for example, which is subject to a significant austerity measure, the concept of homelessness, according to the National Plan, encompasses individuals who seek assistance to obtain a meal.
And the number of people seeking help with eating has increased by more than 20% since 2008.
A significant increase is observed in families and individuals in vulnerable situations whose livelihoods have been impacted by unemployment and also by bank debt.
This is merely an example that demonstrates the seriousness of this situation.
Last year, the European Parliament approved a written declaration on a European Union strategy for homelessness.

With this declaration, this Parliament cautioned for the need for the European Union to equip itself with a strategy sustained by national and regional strategies, with the long-term objective of eliminating situations of people sleeping rough and long-term homelessness.

National strategies should focus on preventative measures, but also on concrete actions to improve the quality of services provided to people experiencing homelessness and the provision of affordable housing.
It is also evident that this European strategy must be compatible with the social housing policy of the Member States.
We have taken good note of the Commissioner's words and recorded the state of affairs that was presented to us.
I conclude by urging the European Commission to provide a strong impetus to coordinate the action of Member States and regional authorities in combating this social injustice.
We debated the peace process in the Middle East. But is there any process underway that has escaped me?
Unfortunately, no.

The European Union repeatedly declares, as does the majority of the international community, in favor of the existence of two peoples and two states, sharing the space between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean, which have the right to aspire to live in peace and security.
But without dialogue between the parties, in a burgeoning swell of hatreds and misunderstandings that has persisted for 63 years, only extremism and frustrations are fueled.

It is fundamental that Europe and the Arab League engage much more actively in the pursuit of a negotiated solution for the borders, based on those existing in 1967, with exchanges that allow most of the Jewish settlements to remain in Israel.

May the question of Jerusalem, a holy city, future capital of two states, be clarified and mutually accepted as a symbol of peaceful coexistence between two peoples who have the obligation to fulfill Isaiah’s prophecy that it is the land of milk and honey.

May all countries of the Union participate in the resolution of the Palestinian refugee issue and may the international community, and in particular the Arab nation, participate in the necessary financial compensation.

It is also absolutely essential that a military force under the auspices of the UN and the participation, among others, of American and Islamic forces be deployed on the ground as a guarantor of peace maintenance.
May there be courage and political will.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, tourism requires a European approach that is clear and coordinated, with careful consideration of the potential and challenges that different tourism modalities offer us.
The touristic diversity presented by the European Union is so rich that it allows for exponential growth of this sector and of the Union’s competitiveness itself.

An investment in this key sector, which accounts for 10% of GDP and approximately 12% of employment in the European Union, will enable not only the creation of European added value, but also address the economic crisis in which we find ourselves.
It originates from an ultraperipheral region of Madeira, where tourism is the primary economic activity.

Therefore, the creation of a specific sector subheading within the financial framework 2014-2020 is indispensable for the cohesive and sustainable growth of tourism, which is predominantly comprised of small and medium-sized enterprises.

The realization of a genuine, sustainable, and diversified European tourism policy requires a concrete strategic plan, with a clearly defined timeline, actions, and funding, capable of strengthening the visibility and quality of the tourism sector within the European Union.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. The absence of an ongoing peace process is jeopardizing fundamental rights and has led to the assumption of unilateral measures on each side, which lack conditions.

contributed in any way to easing tensions in the region and, even less so, to the genuine pursuit of a life for the two peoples who have the right to live harmoniously in peace, security, and with dignity.

The time has come for the international community to say enough. The time has come for Europe and the Arab League to drive the search for a lasting solution, with sound judgment, presenting viable solutions, without delay and with deadlines.
It is evident that the United States and Russia are no longer part of the solution.
Let us begin with Jerusalem. Why not recover the initial idea of a separatum corpus administered by the UN and that functions, obviously, as the capital of the two states?
Borders. Let us begin with those of 1967.
Exchange land parcels where feasible and coherent.

Take care of the defense of Israel, a matter obviously unavoidable for the Jewish people. For example, through the deployment of blue helmets with Americans, Europeans, and Islamic forces alongside the Jordan River.
Refugees number approximately 4.8 million and are entitled to their dignity. To a future linked to a homeland, preferably their own.

But they are not exclusively an Israeli problem, nor a Palestinian one. It is also ours. It is of the neighboring Arab countries, of the Arab community in general, but also of Europe and the rest of the international community.
Colonization must end its expansion, and this is non-negotiable.
The announcement made today is shameful and betrays hypocrisy and bad faith in an offer of immediate negotiations.

Above all, we desire negotiations in good faith, committed to a deadline for their completion, beyond which the international community, to maintain its credibility, will have to adopt a different stance.

Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, the shameful situation in the refugee camps in Tunisia has already been referred to here. We all share, and I particularly share, what my colleagues who have just spoken have said.
I will not refer to that specifically; I am referring to another situation that is more overlooked, namely that of the citizens who were received into families' homes in Tunisia.

And that is one of the situations that should leave us even more ashamed, because we see Tunisia in a crisis situation, yet expecting solidarity. Europe has failed to be supportive and is not undergoing a transition to democracy, and it has not known how to be supportive, nor how to receive.
I believe it is indeed shameful that we can count the number of refugees received in Europe as only a few hundred.
Many of these people, contrary to what has been said, cannot, simply cannot, return to their homes.
And there were children who were enrolled in public schools, which has implications at the infrastructural level, and implications regarding the welcoming of these children in these countries.
That is why, Madam Commissioner, I am very much moved by the appeal you are making, and I do not say this ironically, but seriously. But, please, what about the Commission?
And in Europe,
What can be done?
How does Europe live so well with this double standard?
We are so quick to repatriate and so slow to assist, Madam Commissioner.
It cannot continue like this.

Mr. President, I naturally wanted to congratulate you on this supplement of hope you have given to all European deputies and, in particular, to the citizens of the European Union that we represent here.

And having said that, I would like to say that we now expect a very, very determined action from the Commission, vis-à-vis the Council, so that this sovereign debt crisis can be resolved in the short term.
We know it’s a marathon, but immediate signals are needed.

And therefore, without prejudice to us all beginning now to consider an amendment to the treaties that would give political translation to the entire project we have brought here today, without prejudice to that, something needs to be done immediately.

This set of measures, perhaps an agreement, an agreement between States, what I have termed a sort of parasocial agreement that goes beyond treaties, and which can, from this moment forward, set in motion all these ideas.
Many congratulations on your courage and your determination.
I believe we are on the right track and leaving here today with a renewed resolve.
The crisis that the European Union is experiencing has had serious consequences in all Member States, and thousands of workers have been affected by layoffs caused by globalization and the crisis.
We cannot fail to affirm our solidarity with these workers who have lost their jobs and to assert that Europe must assist Member States in maintaining an employment rate and combating unemployment.
A rapid reintegration of workers into the labor market is a priority objective.

An example of the utility of this fund is my country, Portugal, which has accessed it four times, although we are aware that access to this fund could be improved, particularly in the countries most affected by the crisis.

Thanks to the existence of this Globalisation Adjustment Fund, it has been possible to assist thousands of workers through professional training measures, support for business creation, and incentives for recruitment.
This proposal is positive because it will allow Member States to request the intervention of this Fund to support workers dismissed as a direct consequence of the economic and financial crisis.
We support the extension of the deadline and understand that the Member States most affected by the crisis should have greater access and easier access to this globalisation and crisis support fund.
Thank you, President. I greet the Polish Presidency and also Mr. Commissioner Ali Ren, simply to say that I believe...
Today, following and developing what was presented in the State of the Union address, a very, very significant step was taken to resolve the problems of the Eurozone crisis.
Because the Commission has here reaffirmed its commitment to using its power of initiative and to working with the Council to resolve this crisis.
I believe this is an extremely important step and is the only way we currently have of resolving the Eurozone crisis.
There is no possibility of resolving this in the short term solely with an intergovernmental approach. And therefore, it is necessary that the States, the governments of the States,
the commission the instruments and the mandate to lead this resolution process, to implement, execute, and develop this roadmap that it presented here.
But I didn’t want to fail to say that this is not incompatible with what we do at the same time, with what we develop at the same time our capacity to amend treaties.

I am also convinced that in the medium term, it is necessary to amend the treaties, but also there we will have to do so in a way that strengthens, in a way that gives more power and greater standing to the Commission.

It is through the strengthening of the community method, initially in the short term and subsequently with a revision of the treaties in the long term, that we will achieve greater integration and a solution for the 17 countries of the Eurozone and for the 27 countries of the European Union.

Thank you, Mr. President. Dr. Durão Barroso came here today to announce that, as one of the measures, banks lacking capital requirements must submit plans to obtain them, and if they fail to do so, they must then suspend dividends and bonuses.
I could not help but agree with this presentation given by the President.

This week we witnessed what happened with Banco Zéxia, and just a few months ago, an administrator of this bank received a prize of 600,000 euros for his remarkably splendid administration, as we know.
But to be serious, Mr. President, the Commission has to let go of the governments and present the complete package. And the complete package is what contains the essentials.
The essential point is that taxpayers’ money must be matched by a credit policy for growth.
The essential thing is that banks begin to pay taxes on their profits, which does not happen in many countries, notably in my country, Portugal.
In two years, or rather, in three years, it's the second time we're asked to bail out the banks with taxpayers’ money, with the money of the unemployed.
