Banks that save the economy should also assist in job creation. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mr. High Representative, there are moments when I believe little is needed beyond reflection, and this appears to be one of those moments.
It seems to me to be because we are always in the rhythm of events and responding to event with event, and we lose a little of what is the perspective of the whole.

It is certainly true that each case is a case and each country we are discussing here is a specific case, but, if you will pardon me, Madam High Representative, it seems to me that it is difficult to scrutinize the criteria the European Union has been using to act in relation to each of these cases.
We are often, regrettably, held hostage by the interests of the countries of the European Union, by a portion of those countries, and not by all of them.
And it is for this reason that we frequently use the expression "two weights and two measures" in this House, and we continue to do so.

Sometimes it is sanctions yes, sometimes it is sanctions no. Sometimes the interference goes as far as the bomb, as was the case with Libya. Other times it is total silence, as was the case with the invasion of Bahrain by the forces of the

Saudi Arabia and, Baroness, allow me to say, I have studied all the dossiers attentively and have not yet seen a single statement from European institutions condemning the invasion of Bahrain by the military forces of Saudi Arabia.

Death sentences are endless violence. Doctors and nurses are sentenced to up to 30 years in prison by a military court because they were allegedly opposing the regime and not assisting the injured who needed them.
Regarding the dictatorial monarchy of Bahrain, regarding the dictatorial regime of Yemen, of the Sale regime, we have had far more silences than actions.

I am not in favor of interference, never have been. But I fear we are placing ourselves in an uncomfortable position, the position viewed from the outside, Mrs. Berenesa, which is, instead of assisting development, aspirations

democratic and revolutionary movements of the peoples in Arab countries. Instead of aiding this first Arab era, we are preventing its extension, whether through excess or deficiency, and I do not believe we should bear that guilt.
I hope the awarding of the Nobel Prize to a Zapatista activist can serve as a sign that our side is on the side of the peoples who are in revolution. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, this is a good report from the honourable member.
Firstly, there is a need to ask why VAT should be revised in the European Union.
First, there is a need to reconcile it with the single market.
The greater the number of VAT regimes and variations, the less fluid the market will be.
A VAT reform favors e-commerce, centers competition on the base value and price of goods and services, and not on tax differences.
Combats fraud and ensures the necessary trust, especially in cross-border transactions. Improves the economy of SMEs and reduces administrative burdens.
What other complementary measures are already underway in the single market that could be associated with the IVEI?
First, a simple, clear, and transparent digital support mechanism, Measure 7 of the single market.
Measure 5, concerning services, the need to review legislation on standardization and the implementation of the Safety Directive.
Measure 9 is intended to remove fiscal obstacles and explicitly review the VAT system and VAT equalization in online and face-to-face commerce that we all experience when ordering books.
The pressures for VAT reform stem from two fundamental orders of reasons.
First, the economic crisis.
More recipes are needed, including, probably, in some countries, the reduction of contributions on labor to promote economic development, shifting that burden to VAT.

Secondly, a second major source of pressures is population aging, demographic aging, and the trend of shifting from indirect taxes to direct taxes, which is due to the reduction in the taxable population base.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, we must, in these reforms, reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to restrict the variation range in the standard VAT rate, so that we can all understand it better.
Greater transparency is needed in the definition of the reduced VAT rate and its scope of application, a clear and widely publicized list of the reduced rates.
It is necessary to study exemption thresholds for SMEs, fully aware that each exemption is accompanied by a procession of small or large frauds.
Finally, to welcome the Commission's recent proposal to create a European VAT.
Thank you, Madam President. I thank my colleague Rula for the excellent report she prepared.

The advantages of public procurement are certainly well known, but so too are the obstacles. Conflicts of interest between European legislation and the objectives of Member States hamper competitiveness.
The dichotomy, the quality of prices, and the complexity of the laws and procedures are evident.
It is fundamental to examine existing best practices, particularly in Portugal, where electronic procurement has functioned effectively and facilitated public contracting.
An effective European public procurement represents a privileged means of controlling public deficits and fostering further growth.
To that end, it must have a stable and predictable legal framework, less bureaucratic procedures to attract SMEs, and defend social and environmental values.

It is therefore that I express satisfaction with the intentions presented to us here by Mr. Commissioner Barnier for the review of public procurement, as also this year, with one of the 12 priorities of the Single Market Act. Thank you.
I will congratulate my colleague Rula and all those who collaborated with her.
Important in the realm of public contracts is the matter of public procurement and
that unfortunately the objectives proposed by the European Union, 50% of allocations via electronic procedure in 2010, failed, with average values barely reaching 5%.
Only a few countries, such as my own, Portugal, have been successful in this domain.

The advantages of electronic public procurement are overwhelmingly evident and have been outlined here. It allows for replacing costly access procedures with the simple consultation of the electronic platform, that is, it significantly reduces costs for businesses, especially for smaller

small and medium-sized enterprises, the dissemination via the internet and the ease of receiving procedural documents broaden the number of suppliers, increasing competition and allowing for better procurement, making the contract award process for public contracts

Easier and more flexible, it simplifies access to European Union public contracts, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, thereby facilitating their participation in the market for these public contracts—vital drivers of the economy.

In this regard, we welcome and encourage the European Commission for strengthening mechanisms aimed at transforming public and electronic procurement into an increasingly comprehensive reality. Thank you very much.

We are living decisive hours for the destiny of Europe. And if the situation rapidly evolved, before the eyes of all, from a problem of the Greeks or the Portuguese to a problem of vast European scale, the truth is that the inadequacy of the proposed solutions and their delay have not produced any effectiveness in the swift deterioration of the situation.
The pursuit of solutions targeted at individual States rather than truly European solutions allowed markets to continue speculating on sovereign debt and imposed timelines and rhythms.
absolutely impossible that some States are seeking to achieve with measures of a brutality previously unimaginable, applied to individuals, companies, and the public sector.

A common solution, already found for the risk of excessive European debt, is absolutely indispensable – one that removes pressure from the markets and speculation and affords the time necessary to undertake the essential adjustments.
Without that, what we will have in the end are countries that will continue without the means to pay their creditors, devastated economies, and immense suffering.

To my fellow shadow rapporteurs, with whom I had a fruitful collaboration, and I also thank the rapporteurs of the partners from the four committees involved. These partners are a valuable contribution to this report.
We received 400 amendments and drafted 47 commitments, all of which were approved.
This demonstrates the importance and the interest aroused by this topic of new skills and jobs.
It is, ultimately, about preparing Europe’s human resources, anticipating the needs of the labor market in the coming decade.
The key strategy for preparing the report was to reformulate common ideas in order to avoid repetitions and ensure the report's coherence.
I believe that objective was achieved.
We all know that the crisis currently affecting us has highlighted the vulnerabilities of the European economic and social model, as well as nullified many of the advances achieved in the past.
Since the initial effects of the crisis began to be felt in labor markets in 2008, Europe has already lost over 5 million jobs.
Today, nearly 23 million people are unemployed.
Youth unemployment is even more alarming. The youth unemployment rate is nearing 21% and represents more than double the general unemployment rate.
On the other hand, in all Member States, unemployment rates vary with qualification levels.
This means that people with higher qualifications find employment more readily.
We also know that in the near future, the needs regarding skills, competencies, and qualifications will increase across all types and levels of profession.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges. First, job creation. Second, the need to remain competitive.
Subsequently, the sustainability of social security systems. And, finally, the difficulty in finding people with the appropriate skills to fill job openings.

This report, therefore, has a dual objective. Firstly, to underscore the need for swift action to address skills gaps in Europe. Secondly, to better anticipate the labor market’s needs regarding skills.

To this end, several measures are highlighted. First, to ensure the availability of skilled labor, it is necessary to improve basic competencies, as well as competencies in science, innovation, information and communication technologies, and foreign languages.
As I have already mentioned, skills needs should be identified early, within a timeframe of at least 10 years.
It is now known the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy, and the necessity of investment in ecological qualifications.
Subsequently, there should be an increase in participation in lifelong learning and professional reskilling, as well as a reduction in school dropout rates.
Another important matter is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications and the urgency of advancing this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the connection that should exist between educational institutions and the needs of the labor market.
Internships should be of high quality and supervised by tutors in a manner that enables them to lead to employment and eliminate any potential abuse of the intern's position.
Particular emphasis is also given to the role of social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote demand and job creation.
We have a future ahead of us and we must create jobs.
And small and medium-sized enterprises play a decisive role in achieving that objective.

It is also necessary to strengthen the single market to facilitate the free movement of workers, and therefore the need for coordination of social security systems so that workers can have their acquired rights guaranteed, particularly the portability of pensions.
Finally, the issue of labor market flexibility. To improve the functioning of the labor market, flexi-security rules should be adapted to the socioeconomic contexts of each Member State. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. I begin by thanking all colleagues who participated in this lively debate.
All colleagues made very useful interventions and contributed to a highly constructive discussion on an agenda that is ambitious given the severity of the current crisis.

Incidentally, this discussion is taking place precisely on the eve of an European Council meeting that will show whether or not there is political will to overcome the difficulties we are experiencing and whether there is willingness
a policy for deepening our coordination in economic terms and whether there is truly a harmonized and unitary will to carry forward the ambition that is in this agenda. That is to say, to have

new jobs in the next decade, new jobs that will lead to young people who are currently unemployed and those who are training having hope in the labor market, having hope in an inclusive labor market, that will respond to their

ambition for self-improvement through work and who also have the opportunity to be in a constant state of dynamism, keeping pace with the challenges of a globalized economy and a dynamic unlike any seen in recent generations.

Therefore, our ambition is truly that there be job creation, that there be economic growth, not only to respond to those who are unemployed as a result of the crisis, but also to those who will enter the labor market.

a response to the major challenges that lie ahead, concerning the green economy, services in the healthcare sector, services in the transport and housing sectors, all of which require from each of us a different vision, an intelligent vision, and an inclusive vision of the labor market.
Thank you very much to everyone.

Marisa Matias. Thank you very much, Madam President. What we were told here today in the Council’s declaration is that, for technical reasons, democracy would have to be sacrificed regarding the European semester. But what we are discussing is a political matter. And the question I pose is whether political coordination can exist without democracy.
Where, then, does the European Parliament’s scrutiny take place?
Where does the scrutiny of national Parliaments over their major budgetary choices take place?

But, if the issue were technical, as it has been stated here, then we are discussing a variable technique. Because we know how the Council substantially eased the conditions for the four countries on the waiting list, France, Italy, Hungary, and Spain. It did not do the same with respect to the countries under bailout.
Therefore, what model of intergovernmentalism is this that allows Germany to express opinions about Portugal, but does not allow Portugal to express opinions about Germany?
And, Mr. Statement, I simply ask that you pay attention to this. No problem of democratic legitimacy is resolved by asking deputies to consult information on the internet.
This is an issue of information scarcity, not a problem of democratic exclusion; it is this very issue that we are addressing here. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. A first word to congratulate the rapporteur for Ardenne on the quality and timeliness of this report and also Commissioner Andor for the initiatives announced.
Poverty is indeed a very serious problem that demands effective and rapid action to halt the increase of a phenomenon currently affecting over 80 million Europeans.
The serious crisis we are already experiencing has exacerbated this situation and made the times we are living through dramatic, as Commissioner Andor stated.
The number of people unemployed continues to rise, and we all know that a lack of employment is a pathway to poverty and social exclusion.
This panorama demands resources, will, and significant commitment from the European Commission and the Member States.
If this does not occur, the objective of lifting 20 million European citizens out of poverty during this decade will not be achieved.
Therefore, I warmly commend the initiative of the Platform Against Poverty, which is a very important instrument for ensuring social justice.
But no one doubts that the best antidotes to poverty and social exclusion are job creation and the promotion of economic growth.
Mr. President, internet access should today be considered a new fundamental right of citizens and not merely a commercial object, because of this right
depend on essential things such as freedom of expression, access to and sharing of information, access to and sharing of culture and knowledge, as well as democratic and media pluralism.

And that is why this access cannot be subject to speculative tariffs nor to contracts that block free choice and the possibility of easily changing suppliers, particularly in the world of mobile telecommunications, as we know.
Active citizenship therefore requires that comprehensive and transparent information be provided.
The blocking of internet usage is not exclusive to political regimes that fear their people.
It can also happen that options, as a result of economic considerations, are offered as privileges to police clients, representing a less egalitarian treatment of clients who are not as profitable.
That is why I support the Parliament by clearly aligning itself with the neutrality of the internet and the defense of its universal character.
Let us speak the truth.
We have been taking the medication for three years to overcome the crisis, and the situation worsens day by day.
Instead of healing, we created two fatal vicious cycles.
The first, between banks and states.
In Europe, the failure of a state is more easily discussed today than that of a large bank, but it is still expected that banks will finance states and that states will save their banks.
This spiral must be broken.
The Commission must proceed with the European legislation that protects taxpayers from bank crises.
But it is also vital to protect the debt from speculators’ attacks.

To that end, it is urgent and preparations for coordinated sovereign debt issuances, whether termed Eurobonds or Stability Bonds, should begin this afternoon, ensuring their guarantee through robust instruments of a community and non-intergovernmental nature.
In sum, we must also review the involvement of the European Central Bank.
But the second vicious cycle results from the argument that some states are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they have sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically flawed.

She ignores the essential fact that a single market and a single currency, constructed by political option among unequal partners, necessarily exacerbates competitiveness imbalances between the center and the periphery.
And this is what must be anchored in economic governance.
No, Mr. Rompói, through sanctions that promote the suppression of salaries and income by exerting control over one country by another.
before, through engagement, Mr. Commissioner, both of countries that have surpluses and countries that have deficits, so as to converge productivity through investment, education and science.
The sanctions have only generated unemployment, disillusionment, and a wave of queues from which we cannot escape.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Commissioner, the integrated maritime policy advocates a coordinated approach to the management and governance of the oceans, seas, and coasts, from a global perspective and in coherence with all European policies related to the sea.

Having a global perspective and an integrated approach implies the interaction of European maritime policies and calls for improved governance through greater engagement in the European decision-making process.
The success and relevance of this policy have been demonstrated over the past years through various funded initiatives regarding preparatory actions and pyrotechnology projects.
Integrated maritime policy should, therefore, continue to benefit from adequate funding during the coming years of the current financial programming period.

In this regard, I advocate for adequate funding until 2013, not only to consolidate previous projects, but also to support the definition of a stable framework concerning the objectives of this program.

Issues of policy, governance, sustainability, and maritime surveillance are, for obvious reasons, topics that particularly interest certain regions of the European Union, such as the outermost regions.

Eruption regions, with the exception of French Guiana, are few and of small scale, and depend on a limited number of economic activities, in which those related to the sea and fishing are particularly important.
Furthermore, ultraperipheral regions contribute to the European Union possessing the world’s most extensive exclusive economic zone.

Exclusive economic zones (EEZs) account for more than half of the European Union’s exclusive economic zone, approximately 15 million square kilometers out of 25 million, and, together with coastal regions, are fundamental to the economic growth of the European Union and its Member States.
A program such as that of Integrated Maritime Policy should benefit these regions, prioritizing transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
It is thus necessary to guarantee continuous and sufficient funding, not only for the next two years, but also and above all for the next financial framework starting in 2014.
To fail to seize the opportunity when discussing integrated maritime policy to underscore the immense potential held within the Atlantic and insular dimension for the European Union.

The Atlantic, being the western maritime border of Europe, also establishes its connection to North and South America and to Africa, conferring a strategic dimension for Europe indispensable in the architecture of a maritime policy designed with an eye to the future.

And it is with an eye toward the future that integrated maritime policy, beyond promoting the coordination of maritime activities, should place the potential of the Atlantic, in its three-dimensional dimension, at the forefront of its priorities, based on science and technology.

The investigation of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, the deep sea, and the seabed constitutes a new frontier whose potential exists in biotechnology and mineral resources and is of incalculable value to the knowledge economy.
The Union should therefore take advantage of the Azores’ privileged position and the excellence of its oceanographic department to install a deep-sea observatory there. Thank you.
Enough of this path.
When the diagnosis is incorrect, the medications are ineffective.
And in the case of the Eurozone, excessive remedies have brought it to the brink of death.
The successive miraculous solutions that were proposed were also discredited by the markets.
the Financial Stability Fund, the successive corsets of reinforcement of the Stability and Growth Pact, the revenues from the Troika in low-programme countries.
The blind discipline lacking growth generated a recessive wave among fully interconnected economies, which were thereby contaminated by bankruptcies and unemployment.
And at the hands of the markets—that is, the rating agencies and the speculators—governments are falling one after another, and solvent countries are transforming into insolvent ones.

Altering treaties is now another step on this disastrous trajectory, with an aggravating factor. We risk destroying what remains of national sovereignty, placing countries in the hands of the European Court of Justice.
No, it is not necessary to alter the treaties.
It is necessary, in this emergency in which we find ourselves, to make two decisions.
First, it is necessary to define a genuine agenda for sustained growth and cohesion.
Where is the 2020 Agenda?
Where is the relaunch budget?
Where are the so-called project bonds for Europe's structural investments?
And secondly, it is necessary to protect sovereign debt.
Naturally, aerobonds are necessary, but in this emergency situation we face, it is urgent that the European Central Bank, directly or indirectly, defend sovereign debt against speculators.
Not in a hesitant way, but with a definitive, resolute stance, as befits any central bank defending its currency and the economy it supports.
For this, it is not necessary to amend the treaties; what is required is political will and European conviction.
Let us revise the treaty when we have drawn all the lessons from the present crisis. And there are no few lessons to be learned, but this is certainly not the time. Thank you very much.
Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner Dali, the first Single Market Forum, an idea stemming from the Greco report, took place in Kraków.
it was rich in content and fruitful in the debate conducted by the Polish presidency with European, national, regional, and local authorities and civil society.
We have a roadmap outlined in the Commission’s communication of April 12th, incorporating the 12 levers.
The law, as well as the strategy for the other 38 priorities identified in the Act for the Single Market, needs to be implemented.
For a market to exist, trust is necessary.
Now, the trust of citizens and consumers cannot be taken for granted; it requires stimulation, nurturing.

The single market is not merely a buying and selling operation. It involves horizontal policies, such as health, social and consumer protection, labour law, the environment, and sustainable development.
The Single Market Forum should, therefore, become an emblematic event of the European Union with an annual staging and a diversified and increasingly participatory audience.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I believe we are at a point of reassessment concerning these crisis policies, austerity measures that have affected so many countries, and also the so-called structural reforms.
And it is within this context that I believe we cannot fail to see how they have generated so much social emotion.
And it has generated social unrest not only in the countries facing the greatest difficulties, in the southern countries, not only during the so-called peaks but also in other contexts across Europe.
Last week, we were in Portugal during the largest general strike ever, both in the public and private sectors. A strike that took to the streets.

But if we look at what happened today in the United Kingdom, we see that we witnessed the largest strike ever, especially if we take into account that people also took to the streets as they did in Portugal.
We anticipate a large demonstration in Brussels on Friday.

What this demonstrates, Mr. President, and what strikes demonstrate when people take to the streets, is that the causes and problems we have faced are common, and it is for this reason that the reaction is also common.
The crisis of the European Union is affecting all member states, reaching unbelievable proportions.

We are witnessing chaos in the financial markets and a growing inability to secure essential financing for our small and medium-sized enterprises, even those that are healthy, leading to despair, bankruptcy, and unemployment.
It is a spiral that fuels the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the need for rigorous budgetary discipline, profound restructurings, and greater economic governance. But these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer sufficient to counter the ongoing deterioration within the Union.

And if the truth lies in targeted policies to stimulate employment and growth, without which we will never manage to control sovereign debt, the central issue today is to ensure the financing of our companies and our economies, without which the Union will falter.
Therefore, more than ever, more than the revision of treaties, we need today a strong and secure intervention from the European Central Bank.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner. We are all here today united around a resolution with a very important set of requests regarding intervention.
We are speaking on World AIDS Day, and this assessment of the 2009 resolution and communication is essential.
It is fundamental, precisely, things that have already been mentioned.
We repeat ourselves because, unfortunately, there is still room for repetition, which means there is much to do.
There are many new cases diagnosed every year in Europe and the European economic area. A 2010 report speaks of more than 25,000 new cases.
If we consider neighboring countries, we are talking about over 100,000 new cases.
And if we think there are things that cannot get worse, they can always get worse.

One of the issues I want to make very clear here concerns the disinvestment that has been occurring in the healthcare sector as a result of the economic and financial crisis we are currently experiencing.
And this disinvestment has seriously affected domains that are fundamental to combating HIV/AIDS.
That is why, Mr. Commissioner, I believe that here the Commission has a fundamental role to play in asking Member States to fulfill their obligations in these areas.

A second issue also concerns the increase in discrimination, evidenced by the economic and social crisis. Discrimination against workers who have lost their jobs because they are carriers of this virus.
And that is why prevention, treatment, and care should be equal for all, regardless of sex, age, regardless of the region where they live.
I hope we can implement these measures with the support of the Commissioner.
Welcome to this Parliament, Mr. Draghi.
We are living through special and dramatic circumstances, and they require determined and urgent measures.

The spiral between state debt and bank debt must be broken, but at this moment the priority is to defend the states, to ensure that the countries of the eurozone and the euro itself are not destroyed by rating agencies and speculators.
In the report we will approve, Tremosa and Bacel, we have proposals to rethink the architecture of the euro zone, create eurobonds, and a European treasury. But all of this takes time.
At this moment, we are discussing an emergency, and in that context, the only solution rests with the European Central Bank.
Technically, the European Central Bank knows what needs to be done.
Do not be constrained today in your intervention or action by limited interpretations of your mandate.
Your mandate is to safeguard the euro, not to deal with inflation.
At a moment like this, there is no room for doubt. Saving the euro and doing what is necessary is what this Parliament and citizens expect from the European Central Bank.
Good luck and courage, Mr. Tragui.
The European Neighbourhood Policy already explicitly included the positions that the European Parliament has been adopting.

It was with immense satisfaction that we observed a significant portion of the principles and proposals we have been defending in this House incorporated into subsequent communications from the Commission and the Council.

I am, incidentally, grateful for the excellent and ongoing collaboration and coordination that we maintained throughout this time with Vice-President Cathy Ashton and Commissioner Stefan Fule and their respective cabinets.
From the outset by the upgrade achieved in our relationship with neighboring peoples.

By prioritizing relations with the general population and, in particular, with civil society organizations, we will be giving greater objectivity and greater effectiveness to our neighborhood policy, which is intended to be exclusively founded on the universal values that we defend and share.
I emphasize, however, that the European Union does not intend to impose a model or a pre-defined formula for political reforms in third countries.
But when the matter at hand concerns the money of our taxpayers, we should give more to those who are doing more in aligning with the values we believe in.
This principle signifies that the faster a country progresses with its internal reforms, the greater the support it will receive from the European Union.
The principle of more for more is therefore correct, fair, and coherent.
What this obviously means is that we also anticipate the possibility of cases or countries where we will have less for less.
The neighborhood policy now rests on the defense of pursuing common values and a commitment to democracy, human rights, the rule of law, and good governance.
But this pursuit implies greater accountability.

Our partners are called upon to assume greater responsibility within the process. Therefore, we advocate for the principles of maximum differentiation, maximum conditionality, and the well-known “more for more.”

By adopting an approach of engagement with our partners, from the ground up, and implementing bespoke policies – what we term the bottom-up approach and tailor-made policies – we enhance both development effectiveness and institutional capacity.

The Institutional framework that we so wish to defend and that forms the basis of the rule of law and the democratic process, which we want to see implemented as quickly as possible in the societies, economies, and communities of our neighboring countries.

The idea is to give the floor to citizens, as well as to all civil society movements that identify with our values, providing support to organized movements striving for positive and democratic changes in their countries.
countries, improving the rights of women and children, building and deepening the principles of freedom, whether of expression, of association, of religious belief, of the press, of choice, etc.
etc. With fair elections, with the fight against corruption, a rule of law, greater social justice, respect for minorities, environmental protection, and efficient resource management.
The serious economic and social problems facing our neighbors must also be the target of immediate action.
It is evident that without our concrete assistance, the democratic processes underway may fail.
These were the ideas that we have always defended for the future European Neighbourhood Policy.
These are the proposals included in the report that we bring to your vote.
Now is the time to act.
On our part, we will continue to be attentive and to exercise the new monitoring and supervisory powers now enshrined in the European Parliament.

Finally, I would like to thank my colleague, co-rapporteur, and friend Marek Sivic, to whom I extend a very special word of recognition for his remarkable work on the eastern dimension of the neighborhood policy.

I also extend my thanks to the Shadow Rapporteurs and the Opinion Rapporteurs, and to all of you, for the immense suggestions proposed in the amendments you presented, which I believe have enriched our work.
A final word to the Secretariat of the Commission and to the Political Advisors for the excellent support I benefited from.
In European neighborhood policy, excluding ultra-peripheral regions, while active borders of Europe in different parts of the world.
As external frontiers, ultra-peripheral regions transmit our values of democracy, peace, and respect for human rights and fundamental rights to third countries in those regions.
Regions such as the French ultra-peripheries have an absolute need for greater integration within their geographical zones.

Distant from the internal market of the Union, this integration is fundamental for its development and constitutes a significant potential for deepening the neighborhood policy with neighboring countries.

The neighborhood policy requires renewed impetus. An impetus that also leverages the privileged historical-cultural relationships that the outermost regions of the Azores, Madeira, and the Canary Islands maintain with North America and South America.
A more active role in favor of the European Union can and should be played by these regions within the framework of a new European cohesion policy.

Thank you, Mr. President. It was last September that one year passed since, after a thorough debate—in which I also participated, as the person responsible for this subject within the Socialist Group, promoting meetings and discussions with European, national, and regional organizations linked to the

To retailers, industrialists, and farmers, the Parliament approved the Bouvê report, containing an exhaustive set of recommendations to the European Commission with the aim of a fair income for farmers and improved functioning of the food supply chain.

Since 2008, in fact, the Commission and Parliament have been producing communications, reports, and recommendations, and establishing high-level forums and groups to address this serious problem, without anything having changed in practice beyond increased awareness.

Let us return to the matter, and it is necessary to state this without hesitation. A significant portion of the problems that farmers face stem from highly detrimental behaviors, imposed primarily by operators of modern distribution.
The problems have been more than identified.
What has been lacking for the Commission and the Member States is a genuine political will to implement the solutions.
Until then, farmers and consumers will continue to bear the losses.

Unfortunately, he is particularly dangerous.
Firstly, because it reinforces with further penalties and rigid rules a formula that does not work.
The recessive spiral is cast.
Who can trust a doctor who cannot distinguish between weight loss and anorexia?
A physician who, the more the patient weakens, the more insists on the remedy, while openly discussing the probability of their death.
How many more countries must enter a recession before the Commission and the Council realize that the diagnosis is flawed?
But it is also dangerous, because we here represent the citizens of Europe.
23 million and 700 thousand are unemployed.

Will the Council and the Commission fail to realize that ignoring this fact and failing to provide an adequate response reveals an autism and an insensitivity that are politically explosive?
Let us be clear.
The Great Recession is not a fatality; it is an ideological obsession.
There is an alternative agenda. It must be, however, not of words, but of action.
Where are the project bonds for financing European investment?

where is the barrier that should protect countries from the ruinous interest rates imposed upon them by the markets, leading them to ruin?

Citizens demand options, not words, but competent options.

Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Madam President. The Commission and the Governments now pledge to reprogram structural funds to support SMEs and create employment.

However, it is worthwhile to recall that at the end of last year, the Commission also decided on the suspension of the allocation of structural funds to countries that did not, or had not, meet the deficit or debt targets.
It does not require great genius to perceive that either the promise will succeed or the punishment will succeed. But the two cannot occur simultaneously.
And that is why, Mr. Commissioner, I want to ask you a very direct question. Does the decision to suspend the allocation of structural funds still stand? Has it been frozen, or has it been annulled?
In other words, could Greece, Portugal, Ireland, or other countries still draw on funds to which they are entitled if they fail to meet the objectives being imposed by the Commission and yourselves?
Answer, Commissioner, please. It’s just that in Portugal we are very tired of promises, you see?
Thank you, Mr. President. Commissioner, the proposal made by President Barroso to redirect available structural funds to support our SMEs
and to stimulate employment, especially youth employment, could not be more welcome, particularly for economies subject to stringent austerity measures, such as the Portuguese economy.

With the external intervention agreement and the significant difficulties in financing the economy, and particularly our small and medium-sized enterprises through the banking system, this proposal takes on special importance for regions like the Azores, which, despite high absorption and good utilization of funds, are situated within a recessionary context.

Here, you can achieve a real possibility of stimulating your economy through small and medium-sized enterprises and the indispensable contribution of our generation of young people—the best prepared ever—in providing the optimal response for growth and employment with these funds.
we could obtain.
What we need to know, Mr. Commissioner, is how, in practice, we will access these funds and how our regions will participate in their reprogramming.

Mr. President, Commissioner, the milk package presented here as an instrument for sector organization contains both positive and important elements, such as the reinforcement of the role of producer organizations and interprofessional organizations, and contractual aspects that in some states themselves may, with workers, cease to be.

Yet, significantly short of the instruments that the sector needs to thrive in the coming years, within a framework of an agriculture that we want to see, in Europe, have fair distribution of value along the food chain, and that does not transform into an agriculture of large-scale intensive holdings, concentrated in a few Member States.

If improving the self-regulation condition in the relationship between sector actors is desirable, already thinking that this alone is sufficient is to commit a serious error that could distance thousands of dairy producers, dozens of regions, and even entire countries from dairy activity.
The debate regarding the regulation of the dairy sector from the perspective of an economically, socially, environmentally, and territorially sustainable sector continues, still yet to be resolved.
And we cannot abandon the milk quota system without having ensured genuine instruments for managing supply.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner. Since May 2010 until today, we have seen how a problem that seemed manageable has escalated in an uncontrolled manner.
It is true that the fight against the crisis triggered by financial markets has exacerbated the indebtedness of Eurozone countries and that the most vulnerable have become particularly susceptible.

However, could it be possible that countries sharing the same currency are left to the mercy of attacks from financial operators and those who profit by betting on the probability of euro countries going bankrupt?
The terrible consequences of the Council's and Commission's failure to respond have generated problems that are now undeniable.
Speculative interest rates charged on individual countries rendered any strategy for exiting the crisis unfeasible.
The resulting worsening of the country's economic problem justifies renewed interest rate hikes, until the complete curtailment of credit kills a country's economy and contagion does the rest.
This Parliament has long been a form of common management of sovereign debt, subject to demanding but clear rules.
We welcome the Commission’s production of a green paper on the subject, what has been termed Brazil.

Today it is clear that without some type of obligation of this kind, properly articulated with the European stabilization mechanism, the so-called protective barriers, those firewalls, for sovereign debt do not exist. And until they exist, the euro is in peril, and so is Europe.

In the resolution overwhelmingly approved by this Parliament concerning the new treaty, it became absolutely clear that it is not admissible to continue imposing further rules on fiscal stability, budgetary discipline, and sanctions on euro area countries without taking concrete and urgent steps in the area of solidarity-based sovereign debt management.
The two processes will need to evolve in parallel.
That is what we expect from the Commission and it is now too late.

I would like to believe that this House of European Democracy will unanimously repudiate the behavior of President Assad and the Syrian authorities in the massacre of their own people, to which we, powerless, witness daily.
Because it is important that Europe can speak with a single voice regarding the meaning of values of respect for human life, carry out an indiscriminate and nobly orchestrated massacre.
The entire international community must maintain pressure on the Syrian regime through the implementation of new restrictive measures.
The killings must stop, and this is non-negotiable.
Insisting on dialogue, without a doubt.

A democratic Syria needs a period of transition and guarantees for all its minorities. However, the implementation of more restrictive measures against the Syrian regime does not consider whether all countries are rowing in the same direction. And this has not, clearly and unfortunately, been happening.
In addition to thousands of deaths and the two shamefully rejected revolutions at the United Nations Security Council,
We continue to condemn the position of China and Russia, increasingly isolated in their unbelievable support for the Syrian regime.
Everything else remains. A rotten, desperate, and cornered regime continues to govern a country. And we, the international community, remain powerless to halt the genocide of a people.
We are already lagging behind in the tightening of action by the European Union and the International Community.
We must provide more concrete support to the Arab League in its interventions and in its intentions to send a peacekeeping force to Syria.
We must wholeheartedly support the work of the Red Crescent in its efforts to minimize the suffering of populations.
The International Criminal Court must immediately initiate proceedings aimed at the punishment of those responsible for the crimes being committed against humanity.

and as a means of pressure on countries that have maintained support for Assad, also prohibit trade exchanges between the European Union and all Russian or Chinese companies that have commercial relations.

Thank you, Mr. President. Welcome, Commissioner, to discuss this topic of such importance.
In fact, we are discussing central issues relating to data protection, and above all, in a context where there may be conflict between two different jurisdictions.

And data protection is, in fact, one of the sensitive areas that has generated so much controversy and, in my opinion, should continue to generate. Because we are talking about what could be the clash between the

rights and guarantees, the safeguarding of European citizens who are protected by European legislation and then find themselves superseded when legislation from other countries overrides European legislation.
It is sensitive for several reasons.
It is sensitive because there is a rupture and a doubt concerning what, for all intents and purposes, is a contract existing between European citizens and European institutions.

These individuals, when providing their personal data, do so under the understanding that it will be protected by European entities and institutions and that it will not be distributed for other purposes.

Therefore, there is a breach of trust here, and this is a complex factor to manage. On the other hand, it is also a serious and precarious situation because the European Union ultimately transfers personal data to third countries, thereby breaking this bond of trust that is generated.

between European citizens and European institutions. And therefore, if citizens accept that European institutions can be guardians of their personal data in so many different areas, from health matters to other issues, as were mentioned, relating to companies,

which require data, and I am speaking specifically, for example, in the case of the United States, which systematically requests data from the European Union, what we are doing when citizens operate under the assumption that they are consenting, and as I said, for the European Union to be the guardian of their data, is a breach of trust.

Therefore, I also want to say to you, Madam Commissioner, that these issues have often been problematic for different reasons, but I will always stand alongside the demonstrations of citizens and citizenesses who

We wish to safeguard the protection of your personal data. And if there are demonstrations that you understand are happening because European institutions do not comply with it, I believe we should stand alongside citizens and not on the opposite side.

It's almost a form of betrayal that is taking place. And that is why this question we pose to you, these queries we put to you, Madam Commissioner, is so that you may clarify once and for all, because no community is built upon or founded on destruction or

a weakening of the bonds of trust that exist between its citizens and its institutions. And in this sense, Madam Commissioner, please answer us, to what extent can we guarantee that European legislation overrides that of third countries?
Because it is certain that European legislation supersedes the legislation of the 27 Member States of the European Union, and this is what citizens relinquish.
Within that space of sovereignty, at many moments, why should we accept that other countries, such as the United States, subsequently overlay European legislation that overrides national legislation?
It is necessary that this be clarified because it is, in fact, very sensitive, it is serious, and it is a matter that we should take into consideration.

And finally, Madam Commissioner, I would like to ask you, please, to tell us what the Commission is doing to ensure this does not happen again, to prevent recurrence, and to protect the personal data of all citizens and

from companies and various sectors that are referenced in these issues, are in fact data in which people can trust, sheltered from what we protect. And by this, I mean that I do not even share the view that all information that is stored should be stored, but that is another debate.

Regarding this matter, as it is a serious and precarious issue concerning the rights of citizens, I would appreciate it if you could provide those clarifications so that we may all feel more reassured. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, I would essentially like to say that from the next Council we expect a significant decision at the economic level for the countries that are under assistance, closely linked to the issue of structural funds.
It is necessary to flexibilize structural funds.
Many remain unused, a significant portion of which has been used only and solely for large-scale infrastructure projects.
must be focused on competitiveness, on small and medium-sized enterprises, and on the revitalization of the economy.
