When discussing these topics, it is necessary to respect, to exercise great care with regard to national identities and Member States. And not everyone needs
There are, at times, many of them with good intentions, but not all have risen to the challenge of strict respect for the national identity of each Member State.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I acknowledge the rapporteurs, but I would like to say that enough is enough of pious speeches about employment and growth.

Today, with the initial results regarding macroeconomic imbalances in Europe, the veil begins to lift on why, within the European Union, and particularly within the Eurozone, some countries prosper while others inevitably unravel.
Europe is losing competitiveness in external markets, and this agenda must be revised because much of the insufficient internal growth depends on it. But, focused on the internal market,
Four countries, among which Germany, accumulate surpluses successively, year after year, while 20 other countries, I repeat, 20, accumulate deficits year after year.
As deficits accumulate, the external debt of these countries increases unsustainably.
Of course, this process must be controlled.
Of course, discipline is necessary.
But it is important to ask today, within this framework, whether the solution of crushing the most vulnerable with recessive policies is the only possible solution?
Is fiscal competition from certain winners within the domestic market still being tolerated?

Could Europe’s largest economy continue to develop common policies that favor it and internal economic policies that, while certain for its economy, capture the majority of the gains from the domestic market for its own benefit?
Could the Commission and the Council continue to impose recessionary policies that tighten the economy for the most vulnerable, discussing
openly suggesting the possibility of sovereign states within the Eurozone going bankrupt, when they know that these firebreaks have never left the realm of intentions?
Should the Commission and the Council be fully aware of the explosive politico-economic risk that this discourse poses to Europe?
Yes, it is necessary to revise the formulas radically.
But for that to happen, political will is required.
While that will does not exist, out of respect for the citizens, let us cease saying that we defend growth and employment, because it is not true.
And citizens cannot continue to be deceived.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I begin by greeting the rapporteurs.
To say that we are living through the most serious financial, economic, and social crisis since the creation of our modern international financial model is now commonplace.
It bears emphasizing that unemployment rates in the European Union have reached unprecedented historical highs, and it can never be overstated that combating unemployment must be the top priority.
Youth unemployment is dramatic. In my country, Portugal, more than one in three young people are seeking employment and have no prospect of finding it.
our citizens so disillusioned
It is imperative to restore their trust.
After years of imprudent management of public finances, it is time to adopt budgetary reconciliation reforms and to bring the accounts into order.
But we did not move. Austerity without economic growth is merely a partial solution.
The creation of more jobs and better jobs is the great European objective.
Measures to ensure that young people do not go more than four months without receiving a job or training offer, as well as to reduce the risk of poverty and social exclusion, must become a reality.
A year ago, we witnessed the tragic combination of an earthquake, a tsunami, and a nuclear industrial accident, all in sequence.
Today, we pay a heartfelt tribute to the many thousands of victims of Fukushima.
To honor the victims is to tell them that we have learned the lesson. We must learn to deal with natural disasters. With nuclear ones, we have an obligation to avoid them.
But unfortunately, that does not appear to be the truth.
A year after Fukushima, new nuclear power plants continue to be built.
A year after Fukushima, new nuclear power plants continue to be planned.
Japan unfortunately bears the memory of enduring tragedies, Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and we Europeans also have the memory of an enduring tragedy, Chernobyl.
Fukushima obliges us, in light of all this, to reopen a debate that should never have been closed—the debate about nuclear energy.
A year ago, nuclear energy was unquestionable for Japanese people. Today, two-thirds of Japanese people do not want it.
They know it costs lives, they know that this cost is beyond measure. On the contrary, it is a cost that increases from generation to generation.
The stubborn policy in favor of nuclear power is a policy of arrogance.
Here in Europe as well, there is a majority of public opinion against nuclear power, and despite this, nothing seems to change.
There are currently 320,000 refugees in Japan. Of these, 100,000 will never be able to return home.

What was once familiar is now perilous.
What was once comfort is now ruin.

It is the ruin of a building or a house with radioactive vegetation.
It is the ruin of a contaminated soil or water.

And Fukushima cannot be visited as other ruins are, for example, a Mayan ruin or a Roman ruin. But, like these, Fukushima also portrays a civilization. And the ruin of Fukushima portrays our civilization.
that which chose to include in its development model a lethal technology.
An earthquake and a tsunami have no culprits, but a nuclear disaster has those responsible.
In Japan, as in Europe, many citizens decided to create farewell-to-nuclear movements.
They know better than anyone that safe nuclear energy is a thing that does not exist. They know better than anyone that there are no stress tests.
we can simulate what happened in Fukushima. And that’s why we know that energy policies are national, but in the sky, they
As previously mentioned, diabetes affects more than 30 million people in Europe.
These are, in fact, figures from an epidemic.
And it is for this reason that I believe it is also justifiable to enact a specific resolution regarding diabetes, particularly since it is the first time this Parliament is addressing this topic.
It is the result of a collective effort and a work that does not invalidate the work done to date on chronic diseases; on the contrary, it reinforces this capacity we have to intervene together.

We have approximately 325,000 annual deaths associated with diabetes, because we know that diabetes is the leading cause of, for example, heart attacks, blindness, amputations, and vital organ failures.
And faced with this data, we have two options, in my view.
The first is to say that it isn’t so serious, that we can live well with this, and that each government should handle its own affairs.
The second is to say that the absence of a European strategy in this area is part of the problem.
I understand that from this side, we have much to do.
and we have much to do in early diagnosis, in coordination, in investment in research.
And that is why this resolution holds the value of a beginning and of collaborative work in this regard. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. What I wanted to bring to your attention, essentially, was to congratulate you on the Council’s results.
Not because the measures are ideal, but because they are the possible measures.
There is no doubt that today we have come much further and can be more optimistic than we were three months ago and six months ago.
Many States have been making a considerable effort to stabilize and consolidate their public finances, and this effort has been undertaken in only some States at the inducement of the European Union.
It is fundamental for them to regain their credibility in international markets and is fundamental for them to grow in the long term.
With these guarantees that States have provided, among which the Portuguese State stands out, in the sense of consolidating fiscal matters and the budget, I am
convinced, also with the new treaty signed between the 25, that we will be in a position to seriously relaunch growth in the next steps of the European Council.
But it is only with this confidence that is being generated little by little that such growth must be achieved.
And that is why I say, solidarity of the wealthiest with the poorest is important, but solidarity of the poorest with the wealthiest is also important, providing these guarantees.
Mr. President, I would basically like to say that we are delighted to see steps being taken to integrate Serbia into the European Union.

This is very important because the experience of countries like Portugal, like Spain, or like Greece—countries that lived under dictatorships and experienced a set of very serious problems—is the experience that European integration was the way to consolidate democracy.
And for that reason, Serbia also deserves this opportunity.
I would, in any case, like to offer here a note somewhat different from the one that has been given by my colleagues.

I am aware of and welcome much concern for minorities, but it is necessary not to forget the majority Serbian population. It is fundamental that Serbians themselves have a place in the European Union and a place of full standing.
This cannot be forgotten.

There will be no peace in the Balkans without Serbia. And therefore, however much we emphasize the rights of minorities—and they must be respected—we cannot forget the Serbian majority, its identity, and its full right to be European citizens, equal to all others, with their own state and national pride.
Thank you, Mr. President. Portugal voted on the budgetary ultimatum last week, which, incidentally, is not a European treaty; it is good to point that out.

The favorable vote of the government parties reflects the accumulation of decades and decades of stupidity and a typical attitude of the good student, a grade-chaser, who does not think and obeys bad teachers.
The PS's and its leader's position was to shift from a perilous, forceful abstention to a servile vote in favor.

This alliance makes the Portuguese Assembly of the Republic the first Parliament to accept the humiliation of severing itself from one of its most important functions: to decide annually on the country’s budget.
This is yet another blow from the European Union, another one. It is a maneuver in which the power of money becomes increasingly beyond the reach of the citizens’ vote.
And I ask you, Mr. President, is it democratic for someone to vote so that they can no longer vote? Thank you.
Fiscal consolidation is imposing virtually unbearable demands on some European citizens.
However, fewer and fewer are those who have to bear a greater burden.
The tax burden falls upon workers, small and medium-sized enterprises, and consumers, while simultaneously witnessing an entirely disproportionate flight and evasion of taxes.
The group of European socialists wanted to know how much this tax flight and avoidance was worth in the 27 countries. And it is worth one million million euros, in English, one trillion euros.
This is more than the countries of the European Union spend on healthcare.

This signifies a volume so substantial that were we to allocate merely one-fifth of this amount to investment, investment would increase in Europe from 2.7% of GDP to 3.5%. We are therefore referring to an exceptionally high value.

The purpose of the resolution we are about to approve, initiated by this Parliament, is precisely a very clear demand to the Commission and the Council to expedite concrete action to combat tax evasion and fraud.

This means, in particular, concrete initiatives for fiscal cooperation within the European Union, fiscal cooperation with our neighboring countries, particularly Switzerland, but negotiated by the Commission and not country by country bilaterally.
This means reforming and harmonizing accounting rules, increasing transparency and reporting.
This clearly signifies reactivating the fundamental issue of combating fraud and tax evasion through tax havens.
Europe is not a minor partner.
Europe is a significant partner in the international context.
Europe has an obligation, within the framework of the G20, to clearly advocate for a common fight against fraud and tax evasion.

Without this, we lose credibility with our citizens, and therefore, my concluding remarks in this debate are to urge the Commission and the Council to initiate a robust fight against fraud and tax evasion. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating my colleague, Ms. Nibler, on the excellent work she has done, and by noting the coincidence that we are debating, on this, Europe Day which we celebrate today, measures that align with the legitimate aspirations of our citizens.
This regulation aims to impose limits on mobile tariffs charged to European consumers when roaming, with its primary objective being to terminate roaming within the European space from 2016.
Our citizens will now benefit from a significant reduction in prices concerning calls, SMS messages, and data.
If operators currently charge 3 euros per megabyte, from July the maximum price they may charge will be 70 cents per megabyte, decreasing to 20 cents in 2014.
Regarding incoming calls, the maximum price that can be charged will be 8 cents this year and 5 cents in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile phone users will save, as the Commissioner stated, 200 euros on their bill.
Second benefit: higher quality information for consumers.
From as early as the summer, operators will be obliged to inform consumers of the rates applied when they also travel outside the European Union.
Until now, the obligation was limited solely to the European space.
A third advantage is the possibility of more operators entering the market, which signifies increased competition that will stimulate improved services and better prices.

Finally, in the near future, the consumer may, should they so desire, have two contracts: one for services within the national territory and another for services abroad, maintaining the same mobile phone number and receiving only one invoice.
The consumer, our citizen, will also be granted the possibility of contracting with any European operator that offers them the best price.
This report is the perfect example of Europe of the citizens, Europe of free movement and free establishment. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, in February 2009, this Parliament approved a report supporting the European Commission's proposal to revitalize the European economy.

There were projects in clean energy, transportation, new technologies, and innovation, and at that time, the role of the European Investment Bank and the structural funds was already being considered.
More than three years later, we were able to produce the Six-Pack, the Europlus-Pack, the Fiscal Pact, and the Two-Pack, all of them replete with reinforced discipline and sanctions.
However, while unemployment, particularly among young people, reaches alarming levels, the European economy enters a recession and more than 7 of its member states are experiencing negative growth.
And meanwhile, while Greece is nothing more than a first stone threatening to topple the castle, the relaunch agenda seems to have been forgotten.
At this moment, that agenda is clear.
What matters at this moment is no longer assigning it a character of urgency, but a character of emergency in a situation that threatens to erupt.
It is necessary to intervene urgently in a set of pillars.
First, it is necessary that the European Marshall Plan be established with investment promoting growth, employment, and convergence.
Project bonds are one possible source.
Secondly, it is necessary to stabilize the interest rates at which countries finance themselves.
Let us, at the very least, prepare to coordinate sovereign debt issuance and manage the accumulated debt in common.
Thirdly, the European Stability Mechanism and the European Central Bank must prepare to function effectively as genuine firebreaks in the defense of European sovereign debt.
Fourthly, the credit that was absurdly transferred by the European Central Bank to commercial banks must reach businesses.
It is a billion euros held within the banking system while thousands of viable businesses die every day due to lack of funding.
Fifth point, investment makes no sense without demand.
The most fragile economies are crushed by austerity plans.
It is the strongest economies that must release domestic demand.

It is the case that almost 80% of exchanges now occur within Europe. And it falls to the Commission, Mr. Commissioner Ollila, to make recommendations directed not only at the most fragile economies, but also at the most dynamic ones.
Finally, and I shall conclude now, Mr. President, it is necessary to place a limit on the prescriptions imposed by the troika.

It is necessary to say enough to the punitive, dialogueless, and unaccountable style with which senior officials determine the fate of millions of European citizens and the democratic institutions of member states. Thank you very much, Mr. President.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Commissioners. What I wanted to say is very clear. Naturally, the Portuguese MEPs of the EPP fully support all measures that may contribute to growth. There is absolutely no possibility of

If we exit this crisis without promoting growth, especially in those states most affected by the financial crisis. But sometimes, when I hear some colleagues here, I get the impression that they think growth can continue with excessive deficits and poor public finances.

Now, we must continue to insist on reducing expenditure and implementing structural reforms. We can do everything from the perspective of growth, but we cannot abandon the path of restraint and reduction of public expenditure and…

of structural reforms. More growth cannot be more leisure, more rest. More growth and more growth policies must go hand in hand with strictness in public accounts and strictness in structural reforms.
If we only start talking about growth and thinking that there are magic growth solutions, we will end up again with unsustainable public debt and we will continue without structural reforms.

Having said that, I would like to draw attention to the fact that, at the morning summit, not only will the long-term or medium-term issue of growth be at stake, but also the urgent issue of Greece. And there, I believe it is fundamental that European States, in some way, stand alongside Greece.
We are responsible for finding a solution to the Greek problem. And I wanted to repudiate here the statement by the British Member of Parliament who spoke of the Portugalization of Europe.
Portugalization of Europe, at least in terms of values, wouldn't necessarily be a negative thing. And therefore, it rejects this idea of, ultimately, humiliating or attempting to diminish any people.
We are all Europe, and we all have a place within it.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, you came here to tell us that every additional euro spent on debt is one euro less for job creation. So, please explain to us why we continue with this obsession.

He also came here to tell us that one of the priorities of the Summit is to keep Greece in the euro zone. And I ask you, Mr. Commissioner, do we believe you, or do we believe Dr. Durão Barroso or Mr. Trichet, who just days ago were saying exactly the opposite?
He spoke about maintaining the Eurozone, I ask, which Euro?

in the euro we currently live in, in this zone we currently live in, or in the euro announced yesterday by Deutsche Bank in a study referring to a G-euro, a second-tier euro, should the left wing win the June elections in Greece.
This is a trap, Commissioner, it is the trap of a Europe held hostage by governments and it is the trap of a Europe held hostage by financial interests.
Let us not allow people to live under the shadow of fear, because that is not a way to live. Europe can be something else. You know, there is no lack of money, there is a lack of shame.

Mr. President, Mr. Minister Vaman, the first thing I would like to state is that it is regrettable that, in a debate of this importance, the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative, Ms. Ashton, are not present.
In any case, we are pleased to work once again with Mr. Minister Vaman, who here made a statement with which I fully concur.

I would, first and foremost, like to offer a word of comfort and solidarity to the people of Guinea-Bissau, who have essentially been, the people of Guinea-Bissau, systematically decimated by democratic instability, political instability, and profound insecurity.
It was no longer enough that he was surrounded by poverty; he has been systematically afflicted by these evils.

I wanted to say, on the other hand, that the EPP, during its presidency, has followed this issue from the beginning. And it is regrettable that the European Parliament only manages to have a debate on this matter after a month.
This relates to the invisibility of the Guinean people and the Guinean question.

And this invisibility is due to the fact that, unlike other matters also very serious, there are no large-scale economic interests at stake here that would motivate European, American, and global powers to debate the situation of the Guinean people.
But I must say, if an external reason is needed, if poverty and political instability are not enough for us to have a global humanitarian and political action, there is a reason.
less than the situation of drug trafficking that plagues Guinea and directly affects both European and American peoples would be reason enough for us to commit ourselves to this.
And for this reason, I ask the European Union here to be stronger.

There is no doubt that Resolution 2048, there is no doubt that the decisions of the European Union, of the Community of Portuguese-Speaking Countries, of the African Union, but perhaps not, of the Community of West African States, are heading in the right direction.
But resolutions are not enough; action is required.
We must be more resolute, we must be more effective with the States that have the capacity to intervene in Guinea-Bissau.
That is our obligation.

And I believe that the European Union, at this moment, is responding well in terms of principles, but is not responding as it should in terms of the practical instruments of operation on the ground. And that is what I ask of the Council and I ask of the Commission.

Madam President, Acting President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, globalization has brought with it a disproportionate growth of the financial sector, whose transactions are today, as is well known, 70 times greater than global wealth.

Opacity, very frequent transactions, high remuneration, and exceedingly high risk ultimately came to characterize not only the world in which we live today, but also to be fundamental reasons for the crisis we are experiencing.
However, this crisis demanded accountability and far greater effort from ordinary citizens than from the sector that had caused it.
Thus, today, this moment is important.

It is important, and I would personally like to see a situation in which the tax were generalized across all countries of the European Union and subsequently extended to the rest of the world, through the active involvement of the Commission and the European Union in general within the context of the G20.
I would like it to encompass, or cover, all products without exceptions.
I would like it to serve as a basis for the necessary reinforcement of the European Union’s own resources.
In the short term, commitments must be accepted, but the sense of where we need to proceed must not be lost.
And that can only be achieved with a clear identification of those objectives by this Parliament, by the Commission, and with a considerable spirit of compromise on the part of the Council.

This is what European citizens expect from us today, and I can only express my gratitude here today for the role of Anipolimata, which was tireless in this process, as well as for all those who managed to overcome differences to reach a common position.

Thank you, Mr. President, thank you, colleague Podimata. Today, we are discussing here for the first time the tax on financial transactions, and its approval is the first sign that speculation will not go entirely unpunished in this crisis we are experiencing.
This House and the European institutions must be accountable to people, not to financial markets.
For decades, the financial markets’ lobbyists have managed to govern the world without opposition and without any issues.
It is obvious to us that during 2008 and 2012, the crisis of the speculative financial market was at the root of most of the problems we experienced.

And yet, these speculative financial markets managed not only to prevent any action from being taken, but also to engineer a direct transfer from the pockets of citizens to those very speculative markets.

For many years, we have been fighting for this, Mr. President, but it was only when the peoples, more or less throughout Europe, began to say enough that there was finally some initiative on the part of the institutions that govern the European Union.
Therefore, that is the response we must give to citizens. It is a first signal we must give them.
The citizens of Europe, for whom everything has been paid, do not deserve to be treated with disrespect.
Therefore, this proposal is not complete, not perfect, and will not solve the entire problem of financial speculation, but it is an important signal.
We have been walking, we haven't, the European leaders have been apologizing to financial markets.
They should apologize to those they have affected.
And quoting, to conclude, Mr. President, a currently famous politician, it is of these markets that we are speaking, these markets that govern us without ever having been elected.

I sincerely hope that governments will give a sign of confidence to the people, and I sincerely hope that with this approval and the positive vote of my colleagues, we begin to speak of justice and solidarity in Europe.
Colleagues, muster your courage; let’s see this project through.
Thank you, Mr. President. The financial transactions tax should function as a means of controlling and discouraging high-risk speculative activities within the financial sector.
It aims to reduce speculation and expand healthy competition, the foundation of the single market, and also to generate revenue.
The Podimata report sought to bring the initial Commission proposal closer to the well-known Stamp Tax of the United Kingdom. Thus, we made this proposal more appealing to reluctant Member States.
It is expected that the Council will also understand the message.

If in the Commission’s proposal the tax applied to transactions of financial institutions located within the territory of the European Union, the intention now is that transactions of European assets, even if carried out by non-Europeans, should also be taxed.
This measure will broaden the tax base and reduce tax evasion.
It is expected that tax revenues will be considered as a source of own resources for the Union or the Member States, reducing the taxes of the Member States—a matter still to be decided.
Concluding, Mr. President, I commend the rapporteur for the quality of her work, and I hope that this symbolic text…
Madam President, we received another request this weekend to save the private banking sector.

They continue to offer the same argument, which is to avoid contagion to the Eurozone. And what I ask is: haven't we learned anything? Greece, Portugal, Ireland, and now Spain—yet the contagion persists.
But what kind of contagion control is this that is destroying us?

This policy doesn't work; we should have known it. It’s the same governing officials who claim there's no funding for culture, education, healthcare, public goods, yet it appears almost miraculously whenever banks request it or markets demand it.
This economic policy is not a remedy; it is a fatal poison for growth, for employment, for the European economy, for Social Europe.
The markets dictate, and governments obey and blackmail the people. And that is what governments are doing with Greece at this moment, during an election period.

I sincerely hope that it is in the best interest of us all, the Greek people, not to be blackmailed next Sunday and that they give us a lesson, because this recipe, Madam President, is a recipe for disaster. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, dear colleagues. Unfortunately, the proposals we have discussed here today confirm the prohibition of anti-crisis policies in the Eurozone and further embody the logic of the budgetary treaty.

There are some statements of intent, but they are very timid. I refer, for example, to the roadmap for a single day to begin considering ways to define potential legislation for the hypothetical introduction of eurobonds.
The problem is that this day is only when all the problems of the Eurozone have been resolved, and that is taking, and taking a very long time, to arrive.
We supported some aspects of this proposal, but at this rate, it will all be too little and too late.
Placing a country under legal protection implies maintaining rates and amounts, as well as prioritizing new loans. That is to say, it requires,
Member states that honour their debt, but from which all and every instrument that could enable them to grow and find the resources to do so are withdrawn.

Let's be frank with one another. The only legal protection that exists in these proposals and is stipulated is for creators. But even they will not be resolved, because it is not effective even for them.

As we have seen in Greece, Ireland, Portugal, and now Spain, this means condemning countries to recession, unemployment, and insolvency. And I conclude, Mr. President, by saying that the worsening of these situations and their spread to other economies bring us closer to a point of no return.

Faced with the complete failure of austerity, the European Commission or the German Government propose the same policy to us, but in overdose mode. It is neoliberal fanaticism that is killing the euro.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Given the extremely limited time we have, I wish solely at this moment to assure the Commission that it can count on—as it always has—this
Parliament in effective work to strengthen the euro zone and Europe, but that is only achieved when there are initiatives that focus on discipline, we

We have managed to add the conditions for a balanced sharing of gains and sacrifices among the different Member States and among the different citizens, and a hope, a hope that we will emerge from the crisis we are experiencing.
To ascertain the existence of this hope requires other initiatives, and these are what this Parliament is attempting to address. An initiative focused on investment, growth, and control.
of sovereign debt that has been the Achilles' heel of those – evidently – reflecting the fragility of the economic systems of some of the member countries.
Commissioner, you can count on us, Council, Madam President, you can count on us, but the agenda must be a comprehensive agenda, it cannot be an agenda that simply…
of the discipline the condition for everything else to follow, even if it makes discipline the alpha and omega of our European proposals.

Our citizens expect this from us, they can count on the Parliament, and I want to thank my colleagues once again, the rapporteurs, Mr. Gózesque, the other rapporteur, and all colleagues who, as shadow rapporteurs or merely active elements in the construction of this project, were able to contribute.
for a more balanced, more solid parliamentary project, one that I hope will earn the respect, the capacity for dialogue, and the spirit of construction and compromise that it has had until now

Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you, Madam President.
Thank you, Mr. Commissioner.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Beyond expressing my gratitude to all those who contributed to this outcome, I would like to request that the final vote be postponed so that we can immediately begin negotiations at the trilogue level.
We are confronted today with three agendas: the growth agenda, the agenda pertaining to bank management, and the agenda pertaining to sovereign debt management.
And treating the European semester involves including these three dimensions.
Regarding the issue of growth, I believe that at this moment it is important to emphasize that the Commission's recommendations cannot focus solely on
Countries with deficits. They must also address the countries that have surpluses. And if some have to suppress their internal demand, others have to release it.

I also believe that, at the level of growth, it is essential that the Commission controls the recommendations of the so-called troika. Because when a country enters a recession, it cannot continue to crush its public investment, to crush public expenditure as if nothing had happened.
The troikas must have their formula reviewed and adjusted based on the results. And I want to tell you, Mr. Commissioner, that we approved here today in the…
Parliament’s need to launch an instrument for growth and countercyclical activity amounting to 1% of the European Union’s GDP over 10 years.
A second fundamental dimension is that of what is now called Banking Union. We requested this in Parliament two years ago, in a report from June 2010. It remains unrealized to date.

A third dimension is the dimension of sovereign debt. Without it, there is no stability in Europe. And I want to tell you also that today we approved Tupac here, but introduced into Tupac, beyond austerity,
some other dimension that has been missing, and it is the immediate establishment of a redemption fund, using German terminology, so that sovereign debt exceeding 60% can be managed collectively.

This is a legislative text, and we anticipate the Commission’s favorable support for this initiative from Parliament so that we can control the entirely threatening spiral that is currently destroying the European Union. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. As we now intend to discuss a growth pact, it is essential not to forget citizenship and consumers, at its core the human and social dimension.

which gives it substance and which was the subject of one of the three reports on the Single Market Act of 2001. Because any growth pact should take into account the sacrifices and social benefits linked to it?

As important as an internal market test will be conducting a social impact assessment of all measures taken to realize the single market. A test, indeed an examination that allows us to measure the progress achieved for the benefit of the citizens of the European Union.
Since 2008, Europe has already lost over 6 million jobs.
In my country, Portugal, the economy is experiencing a counter-reaction without precedent, and unemployment among men, women, and young people is reaching historic highs.
According to forecasts from the Bank of Portugal, the situation will worsen over the next two years.
It is within this context that we support and welcome the initiative of the new employment package and congratulate Mr. Commissioner Andor.
Insisting now and always on the basic premise of the need for economic growth, Member States will truly have to concentrate their efforts on job creation.

The means to achieve this should involve subsidies for hiring that create new jobs, a reduction in the tax burden on labor, and support for the creation of new companies and entrepreneurship, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises that maintain jobs.

It is necessary that national employment policies take into account that the areas with the greatest potential for job creation are healthcare, information and communication technologies, and the green economy.
It is imperative, as stated in the communication, to reduce the gap between the qualifications provided by education and the competencies demanded by the labor market.
On the other hand, one of the solutions to combat unemployment involves worker mobility.

It is also crucial that the utilization of structural funds for job creation and the practical importance of the Euros portal as an instrument par excellence for recruitment and job offers in Europe are considered.
Finally, social governance must be on the agenda because our citizens anxiously expect concrete results. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Commissioner, it is true that six months have passed since this scandal involving GDP occurred, and the most incredible thing is that a private company could have managed for ten years
to operate in the market and to have introduced silicone implants that were intended for the construction and manufacture of mattresses and were used in women in 71 countries.
This has affected several hundred thousand women, as previously mentioned. An estimated 500,000.

Now, we are talking about estimates because there were failures and serious failures in this process. We know that what happened with this company is a criminal case, a fraud, a court case, but we also know…

There is a fraud here that must be controlled by the courts, and the courts will deal with it. But there is a legal flaw, a legal gap, and that is what we must address. We have responsibilities in this matter.

For 10 years, we were unable to identify what the criminals were able to identify. Therefore, there was a void in terms of control, in terms of traceability, in terms of files, in terms of records—everything failed. But these gentlemen at this company managed to implement what we were unable to control.

This process is not solely about the issue of lack of information, which is indeed very important—the lack of information in all matters relating to breast implants—but also about the humiliation of thousands of women, and in particular, the humiliation of those women who have had to undergo testing to determine whether or not they received correct implants.

We are discussing a public health issue, and we cannot be lax when it comes to public health. We regulate so many unnecessary things. We even control the authenticity of replacement parts in automobiles. Just recently, we approved a directive on this matter.

We must control what is fundamental to people's lives. The revision of the Medical Devices Directive is good news; it would have been better news not to have to do it, but now that we are going to do it, let us apply it with

conditions with traceability, transparency, control, sanctions, because unfortunately the sanctions, even when applied, will not be applied to the women who have suffered from this problem and States must assume full responsibility.

Thank you, President. I wanted to state very clearly here that, for us, the Council to be held at the end of June is fundamental, and what is essential is that a European solution be sought for this crisis.
From our perspective, the problem thus far has been that we have treated each of the issues as they arise in isolation and individually.

The time has come to have a global solution for Europe. A solution that entails, as President Douro very clearly stated, greater integration, increased cooperation, closer alignment of European policies, and a renewed appreciation for the Community method.
It is fundamental that alongside stability, there be growth, but that we do not abandon concerns regarding stability.
Therefore, we are counting on a global European response, and not on a response divided for each State or for each region facing difficulties.
The productive and increased production possibilities led to considerable increases in milk production, creating critical, descending situations and low prices in the milk and dairy market.

In many regions with strong productive potential, these surpluses were sold at bargain prices in the markets of other countries, originating even greater pressure for lower prices paid to producers in those countries.

This happened, for example, with French milk sold in France at twice the price it was sold in Galicia. And producers, with the sharp rise in the cost of raw materials and production factors, have today seen their ability to withstand low prices severely reduced.

This is a poor prognosis for many explorations and many productive territories in Europe, and it appears to be a clear indication of what the future may hold without quotas and without appropriate supply regulation instruments.

Therefore, there should be a detailed audit conducted on the territorial impacts of thousands of explorations throughout the European Union concerning the abolition of these instruments that we currently have to regulate supply.
Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating the rapporteur colleague on this report.
This is a matter of extreme importance for Europe.
At a time when we are experiencing a serious economic, financial, and social crisis, protecting intellectual property rights by combating counterfeit products is essential for the European economy.
This protection should enhance research performance and promote innovation. It should safeguard scientific and technological knowledge, contributing to the development of new products and services.
All of this with the aim of generating growth and creating quality jobs.

Unfortunately, in recent years we have witnessed a significant increase in the infringement of intellectual property rights in Europe, representing annual losses, as previously mentioned here, of 250 million euros for businesses and the destruction of 185,000 jobs within the European space.

But beyond these negative effects on the European economy, the violation of these rights also constitutes a serious threat to the health and safety of European consumers, since many counterfeit products, such as food, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, etc.,
are produced in unregulated environments.
Therefore, the customs authorities of the European Union play a crucial role in preventing counterfeit products from entering the internal market.
With the revision of this regulation, the aim is to strengthen the control over the application of the legislation in question, reinforce the legitimacy of its intervention, and increase the
legal clarity, adapting the provisions of the Regulation to new realities and new developments, thereby contributing to better protection of the European economy and consumers.
Intellectual property rights are, therefore, a crucial priority for achieving the objectives of the 2020 Strategy in terms of attaining smart, sustainable, and inclusive growth. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. Indeed, the election of the President, a new Egyptian President in the post-Mubarak era, is good news. But we must not delude ourselves; these presidential elections do not in any way close the process of transition that is occurring in Egypt.

It was well noted that the dissolution of Parliament days before the presidential elections places several risks on the table and, in this case, the power that is concentrated in the Superior Council of

The Armed Forces is, at the very least, an exaggeration. They have legislative power, have reduced the President's authority, and furthermore, hold in their hands the definition of changes to the Constitution.

Now, all of this raises some concerns and should raise some concerns because Egyptians risk becoming hostages to military power and a return to the past due to the absence of a fundamental element: a democratically elected Parliament.
It is not for us to make the change in Egypt, but for the Egyptians.

but I believe that we, Europeans, will have to stand alongside all changes that propose the restoration of what constitutes democratic legitimacy and a democratically elected Parliament. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Dear colleagues, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur, Lara Come, for the excellent work developed in this report, which is of vital importance for the future of Europe.
In a world and society undergoing rapid transformation, Europe needs a comprehensive, integrating, effective, and updated standardization system.
A system that ensures the proper functioning of the internal market, that improves consumer protection and their lives, but also that protects the environment, is essential.

As innovation, social inclusion, and the interaction and communication of networks and systems are also very important, particularly in the realm—as has already been emphasized here—of new information and communication technologies.
As Professor Monti stated in his report, A New Strategy for the Single Market, European standardization is essential for the governance of the internal market, highlighted by
the need to revise the European standardization process, which preserves the advantages of the current system and finds the fair balance between the European and national dimensions.

In this sense, the report we are now discussing follows and defends these objectives, which are the correct and appropriate ones. Eliminating the slowness and fragmentation that exists and that causes companies to incur costs.

to transaction costs and higher unit costs, to strengthen the participation of SMEs in standardization activities, particularly at the national level, as well as to facilitate their access to those standards, also to strengthen

On the other hand, the participation of parties representing the interests of society, such as consumers, environmentalists, workers, and people with disabilities, should be ensured, while maintaining financial support for European organizations created to represent public interests.

I conclude by stating that the approval of this report will contribute to the relaunch of the European project, to European innovation, and to the strengthening and competitiveness of our companies. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner. The future common fisheries policy must prioritize its environmental, economic, and social sectors.
in a synergistic and non-hierarchical manner, in support of sustainable development and in line with the objectives of intelligent, sustainable, and inclusive growth of the EU 2020 strategy.
As rapporteur for the third regime, I would like to highlight the particularity of certain regions, such as ultraperipheries, whose economies are strongly dependent on the sector.

In these regions, the reform of the common fisheries policy should seek to ensure the survival and future prosperity of their artisanal and small-scale fishing fleets, thereby safeguarding and defending the employment that depends on them.

I concur with the European Commission’s position regarding the necessity of adjusting this policy and implementing specific measures that should take into account the disparate realities of the fishing and aquaculture sector in various coastal regions.

I contend that this policy places emphasis on regionalization as a form of governance, through a strengthening of the participation of various stakeholders, to enable, in the future, a more appropriate response to the requirements and sensitivities of each maritime basin.
We are approaching the decisive moments in which we will shape the new fisheries policy in Europe. And we cannot fail.

The need and urgency of achieving sustainable equilibria in our fisheries resources, but also in the revitalization of our coastal fishing communities and the promotion of their socioeconomic level, in the modernization of the sector, and in the provision of quality food, demand as never before boldness and courageous measures.
Therefore, we must make choices and prioritize objectives.

I proposed protection for the fragility of my region, suggesting that the exploitation of its resources be carried out taking into account scientific data and giving priority to our coastal communities in their exploitation, while restricting external access beyond 100 nautical miles to the existing fishing grounds.
I proposed safeguarding the fishing capacity of our important fishing communities, rejecting proposals for transferable quotas.

I proposed that our communities have improved involvement in the management of their fishing affairs through the creation of a regional advisory council specific to them, more suitable for interperipheral regions. I hope that in this way we can have a better future.

Considering what we know about the application of the third package and part of this issue has already been discussed today, regarding the delay in the transposition of its directives, it appears the latest information I have is of

that 18 Member States were notified, likely this information is already outdated, due to a lack of transposition. The question I pose is how you view the possibility of, within the legislation being prepared, specifically concerning telephone networks,
trans-European, if it includes a device, an incentive that conditions a conditionality for the submission of PCIs, of projects of common interest or that is

Condition adherence by Member States to the obligations arising from the third package. Or, conversely, consider this an excessive mechanism and that it should be left to the regular mechanisms of competition, Article 101.
and their substitutes, all intervention in this matter. Thank you very much.
of the Commission and the tolerance, the spirit of tolerance that has existed in that area. But the question is whether, with legislation in preparation that may
Do you introduce an additional and much stronger conditionality, do you consider this conditionality to be an abusive instrument, or do you believe this conditionality would be acceptable?
I confess that I share much of the concern that was initially presented here regarding the democratic legitimacy and democratic control related to this proposal.

Banking Union and Banking Supervision, because an essential question remains to be clarified and resolved – a question that is the role of Parliament, the only institution elected democratically by citizens, directly.

But there is another concern that I also have, a fundamental concern, and it relates to the following. The instruments of monetary policy are controlled by the European Union. Monetary policy is the responsibility of the European Union.

Banking supervision is also becoming the responsibility of the European Union. And yet, if everything goes wrong, if banks fail, the responsibility for paying that failure continues to lie with the taxpayers of the individual Member States. It remains a national responsibility.

This is not a matter of seed importance; it is a fundamental issue that remains unresolved. And finally, I simply want to point out that the fact that we continue to tie monetary policy to what is a secondary issue in the context in which we live—inflation—and not to job creation and growth, as it should be, also remains unresolved. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. European leaders continue to exist within budgetary discipline, and I ask, budgetary discipline—so let's address that. Because what exactly are we talking about when we speak of budgetary discipline?

In my view, budgetary discipline is respecting contracts with pensioners and not abandoning state commitments midway. In my view, budgetary discipline is respecting the contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or cutting subsidies.

Budgetary discipline is respecting commitments in healthcare, education, and culture, and not closing services or terminating and cancelling projects midway. Discipline means putting banks in order and not taking from taxpayers to hand over to speculators to save their banks.
This is the budgetary area I would like to see implemented in the European Union, and not continue with this market party.

If an example is needed, the budget being discussed in Portugal, under the direction of the Troika, is a perfect example. It violates all the commitments any state should have with its citizens to not breach the agreements made behind closed doors that are uniting Europe and its countries.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Chairman of the Board, President of the Commission. First of all, I naturally wanted to congratulate you on the Council’s results. Although it appears somewhat delayed in time, the final decision is coming a little late.
The truth is that there is progress.
Now, precisely because I see myself in everything my colleague Cássio Lídez has said, I would like to pose just one question to the Chairman of the Council. The countries that are under assistance...
Countries facing difficulties have striven considerably for the possibility of a retroactive application of bank debts in their separation from state debt.
That was apparently not accepted.
But yesterday we heard statements from the highest German and French authorities stating that they would treat Ireland as a special case.
What I am asking is whether the Council approved any discriminatory treatment decision for Ireland different from that reserved for countries such as Portugal, Greece, Spain, and others.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, it is a privilege to present the report on the 20 concerns of citizens and businesses.
Regarding the functioning of the single market, precisely in this debate with Commissioner Barnier, where the twentieth anniversary of this market is marked.

A first word to express my gratitude to colleagues from all political groups and, in particular, to the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs, for their contributions, so constructive, and their attitude, so positive.
It was a pleasure working with everyone, and the report benefited greatly from our combined effort.

We are well aware of and proud that, over these 20 years, the single market has been a driver of significant economic and employment opportunities in Europe, transforming the lives of European citizens and European businesses.
Travelling, residing, and working within the territory of the Union are freedoms accessible to all citizens of the 27 Member States.
For European consumers, the single market means greater freedom of choice and lower prices.
For our companies, the single market means more business opportunities, with access to 500 million consumers, which translates to greater economic growth and more job creation.
To illustrate the progress made by the single market in Europe from its creation in 1992 to the onset of the crisis in 2009,
In 2008, it suffices to note the 2.7 million jobs created and the additional 2.13% growth in GDP.
Today, making or receiving a phone call while traveling in Europe is 13% cheaper than it was in 2005.
The freedom of movement of people finds its most eloquent expression in the Erasmus Programme.
Over 2.5 million students have benefited from this European Education and Mobility Exchange Programme.
Over the last five years, companies have also benefited from a 25% reduction in administrative positions due to single market legislation.
But a question arises. Is everything well in the single market?
No, not everything works well.
The economic and financial crisis affecting us has had negative repercussions on the functioning of this market.
Our citizens, in some countries experiencing the drama of unemployment and facing austerity measures, have developed a skeptical view of Europe and a negative perception of the internal market.
People still do not know or sufficiently understand their rights, nor do they know where to find information or assistance.
On the other hand, many Member States unduly delay the transposition of European directives and legislation on the single market, thereby hindering its full potential.

In certain domains of citizens’ daily lives, things as simple as, for example, the reimbursement of medical expenses following a temporary stay in another country of the Union, the opening of a bank account by a student in an educational program,

Erasmus, a change of energy supplier, the transfer of pension entitlements from retirement, the recognition of qualifications, and the registration of a vehicle in another Member State remain very complex, difficult, or costly procedures.
It is important to address these problems.
That was my concern as rapporteur.
Therefore, the message presented in the report is very clear. There is a need for greater political will, much greater political will from the Member States and the European institutions.
Council, especially Council and Commission, for better and collaborative governance. It is necessary to regain the trust of people and companies and to facilitate the exercise of their rights.

Finally, I would like to acknowledge the European Commission, represented by Mr. Commissioner Barnier, for the presentation of the Act for the Single Market 2, 12 priority actions for new growth, which marks, I am certain, a new stage for the future. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Mr. Barnier, and dear colleague Regina Bastos, my congratulations on your already very successful efforts.
When Jacques Delors presided over the European Commission, the Single Market of the Union was established in 1992.
Delors then synthesized the three basic principles of the single market: competition that stimulates, cooperation that strengthens, and solidarity that unites.
Twenty years later, the economic and financial crisis rekindled the threat of national protectionism, and it became clear that the domestic market is not a completed work.

And the celebration of these 20 years must be leveraged for a relaunch of the single market, with the concern of placing the market at the service of the citizen and not the citizen at the service of the market.
To that end, it is necessary to define priorities. And I would like to discuss one priority in particular.
A common policy is essential for producing and distributing energy at affordable prices for consumers, with a high level of energy efficiency.
through the European energy market, served by cross-border infrastructures with the possibility of community leverage of investment, representing added European value.
In energy as well, Madam President, the common market will be judged.
One of the European Union’s greatest achievements, undoubtedly representing one of its strongest pillars for the development of the Union, its Member States, and its regions.
However, for it to be effective and equitable, it is necessary to orient its policies toward the equal opportunities of citizens and of all regions, promoting the internal cohesion of the Union.

In this context, it is essential to recognize that we can only achieve greater development in our most remote regions, such as ultra-peripheral regions, through their greater integration into the single market.

Regions like the Azores need to continue increasing their competitiveness by improving their competitive conditions. But we will never achieve this if we do not better resolve our accessibility problems in the area of transportation.
We can achieve this through specific instruments that best address the problems raised by our estrangement.

We therefore depend on the Commission considering a specific program, of the post-and-transport type, as an essential instrument for the integration of these types of regions into the internal market.
Thank you very much, Madam President. I will begin by saying thank you for this excellent debate.
It was a very constructive debate, and one that demonstrated that the single market is truly a great achievement of the European project.

I welcome the presence of Mr. Minister Mavroianis and his participation in this debate. I thank all my colleagues for their constructive approach, and to some, a skeptical one, which is understandable.

and to say thank you very much to Mr. Commissioner Barnier for the commitment and enthusiasm he brings to the discussion of these issues, these internal market problems, and the political will to resolve them.
We still have much to respond to for the citizens.
Citizens are dissatisfied, they are disillusioned, and they expect more from us, expect more from the Council, expect more from the Commission, expect more from the Member States.
This assessment is very useful; this assessment of 20 years is important, but as many have said here, it is important to open the door to a future perspective.
And the gaze of the future passes through many of the questions raised here and through many measures already announced by the European Commission.
The Digital Single Market, the mobility of citizens, the reform of the Eurê portal, and the European energy market are examples.
eloquent reminders that we still have significant progress to make in the future, and that this progress is vitally important for responding to this era of crisis in which we live.
Citizens are suffering; citizens expect much from politicians and the responses politicians can provide to the adverse conditions they are enduring.
Therefore, it is important that the single market be one of the responses to the major challenge of competitiveness, employment, and economic growth.
I am certain that all of us, after this celebration of 20 years, are better prepared to provide the answers our citizens require. Thank you very much.

The Gozes report, together with the report we will draft on the European Union’s annual growth prospects at the end of this year and which will precede the Spring Council, are two essential components of the so-called European Semester.
This report addresses the recommendations made to each of the member countries by the Council under proposal from the Commission. And these recommendations frame, as was just stated, with the…
SIXPEC and the future TUPEC, an extraordinarily strong body that reinforces European control over the economic and budgetary policies of member states.

Finding the balance between this control and national-level autonomy and legitimacy is not easy, and it has tipped towards a level of imposition, primarily of discipline, and may ultimately give rise to a serious package of sanctions.

Concerning Tupac, I would like to briefly comment that it is important for the Council, which is absent here today, to grant a negotiating mandate to its negotiators, one compatible with the ambition of swiftly concluding this package, this Tupac.

But further European coordination, returning to the topic, means a diminished national control over one’s own destiny, which necessitates a subtle balance, but also an increased demand for the quality of the recommendations made to countries in at least three or four dimensions.

First, it is important to ensure coherence between medium- and long-term objectives, which include growth, employment, and real convergence, and short-term recommendations centered, above all, on discipline and nominal convergence. Second, there must be coherence

Drawing on the conclusions to be derived from the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, particularly regarding the asymmetric impact of common policies and negative externalities, the spillover effects of certain national policies on other countries.

Thirdly, it is essential that we agree that there is a minimum threshold of social, economic, and labor rights that these recommendations cannot overstep. And finally, it is important that the quality of the recommendations be assessed based on the results achieved, which is not the case so far.

Concluding briefly, Mr. President. I would simply like to thank Mr. Gozés for his spirit of collaboration and hope that he takes an even further step in that spirit, so as to broaden the base of consensus surrounding his report, and that this spirit continues with respect to the next one as well.
It is true, and has been mentioned here many times, that there are many things we do not know about shale oil extraction.
but there are also many that we already know and it is important not to forget them.
We know, for example, that each shale gas extraction operation utilizes over 19 million liters of potable water, enough to supply, in a year, a thousand European citizens according to their needs.

We also know that each shale gas extraction, in each of the operations, involves pumping 300 tons of chemicals into the ground—up to 300 tons—approximately 80% of which remain in the soil and do not leave it.

We also know that in each shale gas extraction, radioactive elements and heavy metals are released into the subsurface, which, together with the evaporation of toxic waste resulting from the process, constitute a real threat to public health.
This is a danger of contamination of potable water resources and is a contamination that is real and imminent.

Knowing this, we know that shale gas extraction is also a response that appears easy, that only considers the immediate, the industry, and profit, ignoring the populations, the future, and the environment.

But this is also the Europe that knows, within this House, that water is an essential, vital, and important resource, that knows how to protect the health of citizens and must protect it, that seeks to make agreements to avoid emissions and to promote energy efficiency, because we know that environmental standards are important, environmental standards and those of health.
Therefore, when one does not know everything, prudence is the least one can do.
And they may want to do so, but do not do it in our name nor in the name of the citizens who are here to represent us.

Mrs. Ferreira, please. There are always margins for progress, but the support of the European Union has been fundamental for Portugal in recent years.
Portugal has transformed from a country whose competitiveness was based on cheap labor into a country of highly skilled and highly sophisticated labor.
But when a country exports, it is necessary to have conditions for what?

And that is why it is important that some countries with surpluses open their doors to the re-qualified exports of countries that started from a specialization profile that was absolutely unsustainable.

Thank you, Mr. President, Chairman of the Board of Directors, Commissioner. I will be very brief because I believe that what is at issue here is essentially a political point, isn't it?
A financial point. And the question at hand is this: do we want the European Union to make a difference in the context of the crisis, or do we want to exacerbate the crisis?

Most European countries are currently making a tremendous effort, from the perspective of their public finances, to overcome the crisis in a competitive way, in a manner that can position their European countries.

Within the European Union, on a global scale, with significant competitive and competitive capacity, it is obvious, however, that without investment, there can be no growth and this crisis cannot be overcome.
If the European Union insists on these radical cuts, particularly in cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy, this will mean that countries that are making a tremendous
effort, they will not be able to grow and this plan that we have accepted in all countries for the European Union will fail. Sound accounts with growth and competitiveness prospects.

The sole and principal instrument for this is precisely this multi-annual financial framework. And therefore, if we want the European Union to succeed and this policy to be an exemplary policy for other countries, we must invest in the budget for the financial perspectives.
